150231904.review:
Yakuza 3 Remastered is the remastered version of the original Yakuza 3 (2009 in Japan and 2010 for North America), which was originally released to PlayStation 3. The PC version was released in January 2021 as part of the Yakuza 3-5 Remastered Trilogy pack. The story takes place in 2007 and 2009, after the events of Yakuza Kiwami 2 (or Yakuza 2) of which the Tojo Clan held out from collapsing and survived an all-out gang warfare against the Omi Alliance. Daigo Dojima became chairman of the Tojo Clan, but an internal conflict started to brew. Yakuza 3 takes a stark contrast than its predecessors, leaning on heavy character developments and interactions, extending to cinematic story structures, cutscenes, and different environments. Is Yakuza 3 worth playing?

Yakuza 3 and the remastered version aged the worst of all the titles releases so far. It’s not a negative, but in comparison to other titles, the game engine didn’t age well. The graphics were only upscaled from the PS3-era graphics to its modern standards. There shouldn’t be an issue for anyone to max out the PC settings. However, the environment, audio immersion, and game soundtrack are great and outstanding. Notable examples are the soundtrack like Fly, Aqua Sky, Clay Doll on the Cradle, and among others are top notch and notable. The composer, Hidenori Shoji (and the RGG audio team), has done an outstanding job. 

As mentioned in the introduction, the environment is different than its predecessors. Most of the story takes place in Okinawa, where the main character, Kiryu Kazuma, runs the Morning Glory Orphanage with his adoptive daughter, Haruka Sawamura. Many found the story pacing in Yakuza 3 as slow, boring, and/or unnecessary. However, I found it impressive, because the Okinawa setting gives deeper character development for Kiryu as a father figure for not just Haruka, but other orphans. A true, ideal masculine figure not just on responsibilities of being like a father figure, but also for selfless reasons in various situations. Additionally, I like Haruka Sawamura’s character growth in Yakuza 3 as she becomes mature and became the eldest sister figure to the other orphans. Those are the strengths in Yakuza 3. 

Yakuza 3 does have good and underappreciated strengths, but there are disadvantages, and few negative attributes need to be considered. The substories in Yakuza 3 are the most in all the series, but most of these were fetch quests and tends to drag. As much as I like the story in the game, I do find some plot elements a bit out of place when it involves an outside party. I won’t spoil it any further. The combat in Yakuza 3 is stiff and janky. There were arguments from the community, stating Yakuza 3 should get an “Kiwami” treatment. I agree. If Yakuza 3 gets a “Kiwami” remake with revamped combat and enhanced graphical environments, especially for Okinawa, that’ll be perfect. 

Yakuza 3 Remastered is certainly an anomaly compared to the other titles in the series because of the story pacing, different approach on the story – character development heavy, and extensive cinematic cutscenes. Most of the community didn’t like Yakuza 3 for a variety of reasons, and it’s fair. Yakuza 3 is a diamond in the rough. The combat gameplay and story can feel draggy at times, but Kiryu Kazuma’s character development growth, Okinawa setting and orphanage storyline, and overall plot blossomed. An underappreciated title to the series. Recommended but reservations on the negatives.

150215756.review:
I'm on the fence with this game. There are a great many things I really like about it, from the story, to the characters, to the graphics, and even, yes, to aspects of the combat that were clearly done in an attempt to raise the bar from the OG Yakuza 1 and 2 in many ways (more heat moves, more moves in general, generally smoother control of Kiryu, just more overall). It clearly wasn't lazy and genuinely was made to try and blow the previous entries out of the water in all regards. I believe the story and graphics certainly live up to what they were going for, me being a fan of it's more light-hearted start and slow burn to get things going in comparison to Yakuza 1 and 2. The only issues I really have are some story ones where a certain character is sent to the corn fields  and some of the plot points having weak or non-existent final conclusions (though not on the most major plot points to be clear).

HOWEVER, the combat doesn't live up to what it should be.

Honestly, I can't really blame the game itself COMPLETELY in this case. That is, when it comes to this port of the game. While Yakuza 3 has always been criticized for having enemies that block too much, have too much hyper armor, take too little damage, and so on, it's clear that this port has made those issues worse and caused a slew of new ones for one simple fact, the framerate. The OG's  framerate was 30fps, typical for the time given how new the HD era of gaming was. When porting the game to the new internal framerate of 60fps the game wasn't properly adjusted to compensate for that, at least in terms of the combat logic. 

Some of these issues include: 
 - The quickstep is halved on PC
 - Enemies recover their block FAR faster
 - Enemies react far faster
 - Enemies with the Majima style side dash do it CONSTANTLY (expect ironically Majima in my case at least)
 - Common pistol enemies can have issues even using their guns
 - The heat gauge goes down faster than it's supposed to, making it hard to keep heat up and causing fights to drag out longer as a result

In short, the game's combat is running at double it's intended speed and this causes it to wig out and cause a slew of issues as a result.
If you want a good video example of some of these issues you can check out this video by DillionT - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PI5UPxSKjKw

I will say that the game DID get more enjoyable during the middle and later portions, but that's mainly because some of the moves you unlock which help you delete enemies and get through fights you're being annoyed by faster. Interestingly I often found the bosses, the later ones anyway, easier to deal with than normal enemies due to often having less tendencies to block/have hyper armor on  their moves (though CERTAIN fights can be even more annoying given the combat logic issues). So I'm not saying it's impossible to enjoy the game, I beat it over a pretty short course because I genuinely found it fun and engaging for the most part despite the frustrations and did it all vanilla on Hard.

Despite me having done it vanilla, If you plan on playing this port then make sure to look up some mods like "Yakuza 3 Rebalanced" by bdslick and a companion mod "Yakuza 3 Rebalanced (but slightly better)" by UMP45GFL. From what they describe, they try their best given the mod limitations on the game to make it far less frustrating for the average person to play, even on Hard.

In short, I DO like this game. I personally found the combat FAR less annoying than Yakuza Kawami 1 despite it's MANY issues (which says more about that game really but I digress). I also found the story and characters to be fun and entertaining and certainly great for developing Kiryu's continuing story from Yakuza 1 and 2. I think it looks super nice and was almost a perfect transition from the PS2 era of graphics to the PS3 era of graphics for the mainline series. This game unironically has a great many things to appreciate about it. Still, if I could have an in between option I would rate it that, as while I DO like the game I really can't condone a port with logic issues this bad. Regardless, I would suggest playing it on normal or even easy (unless you use the previously mentioned mods) to experience an important step in the Yakuza story and appreciate the many aspects of the game I think it gets right despite its shortcomings.

150075820.review:
I hate this game.

I don’t enjoy leaving negative reviews. I prefer to sing praises instead of criticizing, since I know any piece of media might float some people’s boats, but I cannot for the hell of me give this any praise. The shock of coming to this from such an amazing game as Kiwami 2 is insane, and I think Yakuza 3 would really benefit from getting Kiwami’d.

Once upon a time, the Yakuza Series was at stake of not being localized due to low performance on the western market. It was laid in the shoulders of Yakuza 3’s success for a decision to be made about the localization of future Yakuza games. Now WHAT THE FUCK were they thinking in laying such a responsibility on THIS GAME, out of all of them?

This is a brawler game where 90% of your hits do not connect. Enemies are either blocking everything or in a state of invincibility. You are given absolutely no tools of fighting back, at least until you level up. Enemies can block while you’re in the middle of your attack string and you CAN’T DO THE SAME for theirs until you level up. I have spent most of my game time looking at Kiryu dizzied or laying on the ground, waiting for him to get up only to get downed again by some boss with the most annoying barks I’ve ever heard.

Kiryu hits as hard as a child here. In the beginning, heat actions do not cause enough damage to be worth the hassle. Regular attacks do chip damage. Your grabs are useless on a ton of enemies.

Your enemies, meanwhile, hit like a truck.

I have let myself get killed in a boss battle (Yes, it was [spoiler]Lau La Kong[/spoiler]) so the easy mode prompt triggered and I wouldn’t want to pull my hair out with the same fight again. I missed a QTE and lost what, about 25% of my health? Fuck that.

The chase minigame is dumb and I dreaded every time the POSSIBILITY of a chase or an escape sequence arose.

The story Is silly and I enjoyed it. I liked some of the new characters, Haruka is great here and the kids from the orphanage are annoying but not to the point of pissing me off. I played this game solely for this, and I’d STRONGLY recommend to just play it on easy from the get go, if you want to experience the story for yourself. As a story? I enjoyed my time with it. As a game? I hated every single second.

I have never rushed a Yakuza game so far, until deciding to skip all side content on this game because I couldn’t stand it anymore.

150059776.review:
Enemies in this entry are infamously block-happy, so throws and bladed weapons are particularly important. Buying and repairing a bunch of cheap knives can be a good investment, and you can also grab most downed opponents' legs for repeated throws.

Bosses are quick to punish longer combos with counterattacks, so focus on shorter hit-and-dodge maneuvers. Make sure to hold on to a good stock of healing items as well, as some boss fights can go on for a while.

While the description only mentions reduced damage, the "Gauntlets" accessory actually lets you block bladed attacks barehanded which is very useful in some fights (and remains true in the next game). A guaranteed pair can be found in the Ryukyu key locker #28 once the lockers become available in chapter 4, the key of which is hidden between some buildings near the central Ryukyu save point and requires first-person view to pick up.

You can learn Tiger Drop as early as chapter 5 after the substory "Return to the Dragon Palace", and as usual it is incredibly powerful once you get the timing down.

It's possible to miss certain substories, but they can be finished in premium adventure mode after you've beaten the game.

Remember your Heat Actions. You get all that Heat from punching dudes, so you may as well get fancy with it. They'll almost always cause major damage to one or more enemies. They can make the difference between a quick decisive victory and a long and drawn-out slog.

You can restore health in two main ways: by eating at restaurants or by consuming recovery items, which largely consist of energy drinks like Toughness or Staminan. Always have a few on hand, especially if you're going to tackle something in the story.

Take the time to do Substories. You'll be supplied with items, experience, and money that will make the main game that much easier.

Definitely seek out your "training masters". The abilities you learn will turn out to be invaluable in your struggle.
Save your money by not buying too many health items. Your encounters on the street will give you items. Also don't blow a lot of money on weapons or gear, either. Save it for important stuff like weapon modding and hostesses.

If you get something that looks relatively useless, save it anyway in your Item Box. It might be a cheat item or a crafting item. I'll tell you right now that the only completely useless stuff in the game are toys you get from the UFO Catcher.

149824993.review:
If youve ever watched anime (stay with me here), you'll know that at some point there's a beach episode.

Yakuza 3 is the beach episode of the franchise.

I'm a huge fan of this series. I played and own every single RGG studio title in physical copy and I've 100%ed multiple titles in the series. That includes spinoffs, the PSP games, the original ps2 titles, you name it.

With all of this in mind, I feel like I have some relative authority in saying that *you probably should not play this game*

Yakuza 3 is a filter that weeds out anyone who isn't committed to the franchise. 
Coming off the bat of the golden trifecta of yakuza 0, kiwami 1 and kiwami 2, anyone playing yakuza 3 immediately after that is going to have a rough time.

The combat is rough, there are none of the quality of life improvements present in 0, K1 and K2, the story is hot garbage and DOES NOT MATTER, and youll come away burnt out and frustrated. It took me weeks to push through this game and I was not having a good time.
Fans often call this one "blockuza" because enemy NPCs in this game will NOT stop blocking.

Please, do yourself a favor, look up the synopsis for yakuza 3 and move right along to yakuza 4. 

If you're really keen to play every title, I recommend playing yakuza 3 after you've played everything else.
(I'd even recommend playing the zombie shooter before this one)

149726350.review:
Disclaimer: I am not a native english speaker so mistakes are bound to happen, not just that, but I'm lazy and I got the ADHD thingy so yeah, I sometimes don't care enough to correct my mistakes. That being said, let's get started: 

Pros:
-Continuation of a great series
-I like Haruka

Cons:
-Ugly graphics
-badly aged gameplay
-tedious mission design
-not so well written story

Soo, After I've played Yakuza 0, and Kiwami 1 & 2 I've expected a lot, and there was the first mistake, you can clearly tell, that this game 12/10 would've benefitted a lot from the Kiwami-treatment. This game, when it comes to gameplay is a joke in comparison to the modernized remakes and I wish I would've had that. Apparently this game is known for splitting the playerbase from those, who stopped after this to those who continued to play it.

Now the reason I bit and stuck with it was one of my besties and me being stubborn to not wanting to quit, and see where this adventure ends. But I have to admit, I could not beat the endboss with the mechanics so I've used cheats to finish the game. Just a heads-up, everyone should enjoy the games the way they want, I only would ever condemn cheating if you ruined someone else's fun (e.g. multiplayer) but It was better and funnier for me that way when I had to beat mine.

So, the story starts interesting and strong, mind you, Ive completed Yakuza 0 so it was really interesting to see, what 1 substory told us about the future, about having all these children. The Setting really started strong but the story lost track soo quickly, became stale and boring, it forced me to do stupid shit like watching for a bunch of children, which was really unfun, probably so you care more for them and what happens in the story, but it was really more a bummer than anything. The Ending is pretty okay tho, it gives decent closure tho I am not a big fan of stupid redemption-arc's but I'll let it slide.

Visually speaking the game is not too bad, you can tell, some textures have been redone, some have not. The variety of NPC's is for a PS2 game pretty good, fedality not too bad and some animations were okay, BUT a lot of things felt and looked so stupid, prime example is Haruka's normal walk cycle or anything that is Smaller than our 2 Meter (6.75 feet for those who don't know what a kilometer is) behemoth, and it was quite weird. Also while I'm at it, the sound design was all over the place, you sometimes have really good immersive atmospheric sounds, and the music is quite decent aswell, but then you step on wood and it sounds like Kiryu is a damn horse, or some sounds being recycled and sounding just bad.

Back to music, overall it was a 7/10, not every track really a banger but overall pretty decent. I'd love to admit but 0 and 1 thus far were killa when it came to music and I liked the Joji Theme and Mine's boss fight too, just some parts, when it came to these atrocious chases with people, yikes, just no. Bad music, bad gameplay.

Because of the terrible mission design I really skipped the side content, not like in Kiwami 1 or 2 where I did plenty, or 0 where I did everything (with cheesing), I hated the engine soo much, that I wanted to get this game over with as soon as possible. My Mistake was to play at Hard difficulty, not knowing what I was getting myself into, and that may have ruined my experience since I've had to cheese a lot of fights (you see, I am really not a beat-em-up guy, more strategy games, but the story overall's just enjoyable) and therefore my experience may have been harder than necessary BUT even my best friend who LOVES THIS SERIES and is really atteched to it, told me this could've been a better game as a remake rather than remaster. So where does that lead us? Besides the story, the gameplayloop felt tedious and was unenjoyable, I was happy when I finished the main story, and apparently I only played 7% of the game. Technically speaking, I'll better avoid this game as a second playthrough.

Time for Story, that really struggled on some ends, why do we have Kazama back (the way they brought him back was just stupid), why would the CIA ever entangle in japans inner affairs, what are men in black, why do we have a dog now??? I cannot answer these questions. I feel like there were a bunch of ideas in a bowl and they just grabbed 4 main plots and knotted them together into a game. I really tought in the beginning the action's going to be great but meeeh. Merely the end, as mentioned before, gave some closure and even that was random as hell.

Now I think I've made my point clear that everything I've played up until now was superior, and I'd like to state that I had some fun with this game, but not enough to justify the times I've suffered from bad game design, I've hated the mechanics soo much, and yeah, I will probably never attempt to finish this game to 100%. I hope there may be a Kiwami remake at some point but until then, may this game rest forever in my library. I really hope Yakuza 4 gives me a better treatment.

149622159.review:
[h1]"After all he has done for the Tojo Clan... It wouldn't be right stealing the one place he belongs."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Yakuza 3 Remastered is the fourth chronological game in the series following the story of Kiryu Kazuma, and it's claimed as one of, if not the worst, the series has to offer. But does it put up a fight against these claims and unleash the dragon, or does it only prove that all good things must come to an end?

[table]
[tr]
    [th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
    [th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
    [td]🟩 Another action-packed, adrenaline-fueled story following the famous Dragon of Dojima, Kiryu Kazuma, as he fights once again for new friends, family and the future of the Tojo Clan.

🟩 A wide array of minigames to participate in, some new, some old, and some still infuriating. Nonetheless, it's still a pleasant way to recuperate between chapters.

🟩 Levelling has been simplified to allow Kiryu to regain his lost power more efficiently. Fights still provide experience, but you only have four categories to level up to 10 now that grant skills and techniques with each boost.

🟩 Access to a new region that helps broaden the already large amount of maps to explore.[/td]
    [td]🟥 To this point in the series, this is hands down the worst combat so far.

🟥 Y3R is a significant graphical step down from the Kiwami remakes of 1 and 2.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
With the events of Yakuza Kiwami 2 behind him, Kiryu Kazuma says goodbye to his old friends in Kamurocho to start a fresh new life on Okinawa island.

It is there where his story continues.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3073809042

With a new goal in life, the care of an orphanage called Morning Glory and its children that live there, Kiryu finally has the chance for true peace. But this peace is soon threatened by an enterprising expansion where some prominent figures seek the land the orphanage rests on and will stop at nothing to have it.

For the defence of his new family, the dragon once again rises to the challenge and charges headlong into battle against forces unknown.

Yakuza 3 Remastered is another gripping tale in the series following Kiryu Kazuma and his ever-persistent striving towards a peaceful life. It has been well-written and beautifully designed to deliver an action-packed series of twists and turns that persist to keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Blockuza begins.[/h3]
The general fighting mechanic of Yakuza 3 Remaster is pretty similar for the most part to Kiwami 2, so there shouldn't be an enormous shock to the system for players moving through the series sequentially. With that said, however, it does appear that some of the more intrinsic details of the combat have been tweaked to favour difficulty, and in doing that, it has become a far more tedious experience than it ever was in the past.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3073806461

It mainly comes from brick-wall blocking encounters throughout the campaign, with the later, longer fights almost entirely becoming chip-damage encounters. Enemies will block 90% of your attacks, break their block, take a minor hit to their health, counter hard and then resume their blocking stance. While this probably is a more realistic approach to street fighting, some later fights are 20-30 minutes long due to the mechanic.

But the new mechanics aren't all bad, as the latest levelling style works in favour of players getting right back to where they were powerwise by the end of Kiwami 2. Kiryu can quickly gain levels and power, putting you right back into the driver's seat. This can be a double-edged sword, as it does remove some of the minor decision-making players could do previously, as well as stops you from outlevelling the content.

[h3]A new region to explore.[/h3]
Early into the campaign, Kiryu migrates to another region of Japan to live and open his orphanage, Okinawa. With the move comes a new place to explore beyond the series limitations of Kamuchoro and Sotenbori. Okinawa is a far more tropical and tourist-type of location where everything is a little slower and calmer than the busy streets of Tokyo, but this doesn't mean it's boring by any stretch of the imagination. There are loads of activities to partake in, including minigames specific to the region, like golf (which is absolutely sensational, mind you) and pool, as well as the usual plethora of side quests, locker keys and secrets hidden amongst its many streets and alleyways.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
Yakuza 3 Remastered isn't an ugly game. It's simply a dated one. Immediately upon boot up, you will notice its dated character models and PS3-era style graphics, and overall lower quality than the previous titles in the series. It isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it's definitely startling coming from 0 and the remakes and should be considered before purchasing. I should state that one good addition to the series here is the implementation of blood and visible face damage on both Kiryu and his opponents after fights, which really helps immerse you into the whole experience, and it was not present in the previous games.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3073805646

The audio and soundtrack, on the other hand, are absolutely amazing! While still a little dated, the general audio experience helps immerse you in the illusion of the world being alive. The soundtrack is full of hard hits that will have you bopping your head through even the most tedious encounters the game can throw at you.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
With the game set to 2560 x 1440 resolution and as high as the quality can go, the frames never dropped below 60 FPS, and there were no signs of visible tearing or any graphical concerns to note.
RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 24%)
CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 44.9%)
GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 27%)

[h1]Final Thoughts - Good[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
While Yakuza 3 Remastered is far from peak Yakuza, it is still a pretty good game. Not quite as graphically pleasing, with plenty of tedious boss encounters along the way, it still manages to pull a positive rating here purely based on the fact that by this point in time, you're invested in the plot and characters and the general story is still exceptionally written which I've come to expect from the series. Far from a perfect experience, but it's worth it if you've already come this far and want more. For the amount of content you receive, the current price point is reasonable, but it's safe to say that I wouldn't recommend any player use this as a starting point for the franchise.

[quote]If busting heads across Okinawa has you seeking absolution, head to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/hellpurgatoryandparadise] Hell, Purgatory and Paradise[/url] to seek the inner peace you so desire.[/quote]

149301258.review: Yakuza 3... While I harbor an intense frustration towards it due to its unforgiving difficulty, surpassing the challenge of even the most formidable Souls-like games, there's a deep affection I hold for this title. It served as a crucible, imparting upon me the virtue of patience precisely when I needed it most. I adapted to the relentless combat, learning to thrive by prioritizing defense and nimble counterattacks while embracing my creativity through the artful use of grapples. In my estimation, Yakuza 3 stands as my favorite installment in the entire series. Yes, its combat is unapologetically demanding, but this adversity becomes a necessary mentor, a harsh yet effective tutor pushing you to ascend and grow accustomed to the franchise's combat dynamics in future titles, which will feel like a breeze in comparison. From a personal perspective, Yakuza 3 boasts the most remarkable soundtrack in the entire series, and its narrative narrative ranks among the finest I've ever experienced, complete with captivating boss encounters. I wholeheartedly recommend that others embark on this journey, and if you manage to surmount its challenges, consider it a rite of passage that signifies your readiness to tackle the entire Yakuza series, having demonstrated the fortitude required to navigate its intricate world.

149219058.review:
I'm going to be completely honest, if you came from Kiwami 2 like me, assume it has Dead Rising 1 movement, and expect nothing more than a mid combat system with a great story, then this falls within your expectations.

I am also going to remain completely honest with all of you; I cheated. YES, it's true. I cheated, OK!
For the first time, I played this game using a one hit kill. YEP! I know! Sue me! There's a big reason for this.
I really. Really. From the bottom of my heart, dislike this combat system. I dislike the movement. It is not fluid. The way Yakuza combat is build relies on fluidity and a lot of movement, the quickstep moves you less than a normal footstep would, the character movement makes you feel like a roblox character and the fighting feels so subpar I feel like I'm punching a pillow full of marshmellows.

But the story is fantastic. The kids are hilarious. The fat kid is my favorite, and Izumi is cute with her doge Mame, the nerdy kid in the green shirt is funny, there's a ton of loveable characters here for you. The fact they let you play whole chapters just focusing on the orphanage is fantastic. I adore it a lot, it's so sweet and makes me look forward to the idea of having a kid LOL. That's how much it captivates you. So if you're here for story like me, now you might understand why I used said one hit kill cheat, just so I could get through this game's clunkyness and remain entertained by what is the real focus here, its narrative.

And to be honest? I loved it. Certain things I can't comment on, even if I generalize and point to a specific section without being specific on what that section entails, it will spoil, so I won't say anything else.

Start with Yakuza 0, play Kiwami 1, then 2, then this.

And enjoy 4. Cos I don't think you will feel the same way about 3 as you do 4, it will only get better from here, in terms of gameplay! Story wise, amazing, enjoy it! Oh, and don't listen to those kids online who tell you this game sucks and overly critique it, none of them probably played ps2/ps3 and if they did they really are just hating for no good reason. All non spoiler pros and cons were addressed which were the main focus for all the hate this game got. So like me, make your own judgment.

Shoutout Morning Glory Orphanage!

149101487.review: Being the first mainline entry to come out on the seventh generation of consoles, Yakuza 3 successfully expands on everything that made the first two entries so great; the combat, exploration, and minigames have all been brought forward to a new generation and greatly expanded. Moreover, in my opinion, it tells the most emotional and well-rounded story in the series up to that point. However, even though Yakuza 3 did a great job bringing the series to a new generation, it certainly has its flaws. The biggest, in my opinion, has to be the orphanage sections. For the uninformed, the first few chapters of Yakuza 3 revolve around Kazuma taking care of the children at an orphanage he runs. As a result, there's very little combat, the pace is very slow, and the main storyline kind of takes a back seat. While this isn't necessarily a bad thing, and I did actually enjoy the first few chapters, the problem comes about a third into the game when it pops up again; the intense and fast pacing gets cut off very suddenly and doesn't return for close to two hours. Again, while these sections aren't necessarily bad and do help build Kazuma's character and give the player time to do some side-missions, they just go on for too long and cause the pacing to come to a crawl. Overall, though, despite a few questionable choices, Yakuza 3 is still a great game with a solid story, fun minigames, and a greatly expanded scope. For fans of the first two games on the PS2, I'd highly suggest giving it a try.

148392755.review:
I would agree with the other previous 'NO's here by saying this: only play it if you're attempting to go through the series one by one.

Also, play this game on easy. Why, you ask? Because the combat is so janky you'll want to pull your own hair out after the 60th random encounter. Trust me on this.

I think most of my frustrations lie within the fact that this is labeled as a 'remaster' when it's clearly a bare-bones port of the original title to PC. There are some very obvious bugs when it comes to combat that arise from frame-rate issues, as the 'window' for QTEs is insanely small and enemies will occasionally just phase through your attacks. Furthermore, enemy AI is predisposed to just hold block as you relentlessly flail doing zero chip damage, even with guns and swords. Combat is easily the most broken part of this title and I'll just leave it at that.

The story, as always, is full of intrigue, strange tonal shifts, and death fakeouts akin to a daytime soap opera. Y3 features some of the most interesting characters but the plot itself can't support them as everything just slows to a crawl for the middle 8 chapters. The finale is pretty damn fun, however, so you have that to look forward to.

Y3 often drags but there are some high points. Take my advice and don't ruin it by playing it on Normal/Hard.

148355641.review:
[h1]IMPORTANT NOTICE FOR COMPLETIONISTS[/h1]
[spoiler]You don't have to 100% the completion list. Do not waste time with crafting, heat actions, S ranking the Ultimate mode, Haruka dates, etc. You will hate this game even more than you already will and maybe quit the franchise.[/spoiler]

[h2]Why is Yakuza 3 a filter for casuals[/h2]
Yakuza 3 sits at a crossroads of the Yakuza franchise - artificially, but with meaningful consequences for the player. 

Imagine enjoying every Yakuza game from 0 to Kiwami 2 that are available to play on steam. You've honed your skills on all the minigames, you've adapted to different styles of combat, even if you miss the style changes and play styles you adopted in the canonically earlier titles. 

Prepare to be SLAPPED by this game. It will make you miserable. Everything from combat to pool is a less refined downgrade. You CAN master the mechanics and dictate any battle in this game, but it's a process of learning un-fun jank, not necessarily skill. 

The earliest jank you'll lean on is throwing enemies in combat. Enemies will often resist your throw, so you'll have to spam the throw button (B) every time you want to get any damage in - ESPECIALLY before you learn tiger drop and the throw counter. Worst thing in the world? No. But it turns easy encounters into button mashing slogs for the initial chapters of the game. 

Later jank involves running away from enemies to charge your heat bar. In a handful of the Ultimate Challenges this is necessary to proceed/preserve health for multiboss unhealable encounters. Again, not the worst thing in the world, just tedious and not fun. 

The combat can be mastered - it'll really click when you do the coliseum & challenges. Pro-tip, switch up between Tiger Drop (Y) and Grab Counter knee in the stomach (B) which both have the same trigger conditions. Combat isn't even really the problem here, it's just a slog. 

The real list of painful terrible things in this game are as follow:
- Club hostess minigame (I thought softlocked my game with this accidentally. 3+ hours of a cycle where I couldn't make any progress on this and every guide had no solutions. TERRIBLE, worst thing in ANY Yakuza game so far.)
- Hostess dates (Be prepared to sink 5+ hours into these even with a guide to complete the substories.)
- Pool (must use keyboard and mouse or artificially disable joystick inputs. Insane.)
- Back to the future guy substory (Lau Ka Long 3 v 1 fight.) 
- Batting cage expert mode 
- Orphanage focused content that locks the main story, especially Haruka's drug dealing side content.
- Trash on the beach pick up (doesn't always register as a successful pick up of trash. I went over 50 on my count, really janky)
- Knocking down pedestrians (again, doesn't register in the game engine when you knock people down. Unclear what the actual trigger is but eventually it works. Just takes forever.)
- Damage output in legendary craters, enjoy spamming heat actions and dominating fights that overstay their welcome. It's not hard, it's just annoying. 
- Heat finishers (Do you enjoy doing a quicktime minigame every boss fight? Get used to it sport.)
- No option to run in the overworld (this one feels like a reversion to the stone age.)
- Running minigames where any slight bump destroys Kiryu but not the person/thing you're chasing (The ultimate Mack race in ultimate challenges is a special hellish endeavor. I think these come back in Y-4...)
- THE STORY [spoiler](They did Kashiwagi so dirty in this one. If you've been paying attention since the early games, this story REEKS. Chapter 10 is just you sitting around for an hour and the game explains everything to you. Mine is by far the worst final boss in the series, so uninspired, his motivations barely make sense, and he ends by hugging you limply? Just silly. The CIA tie-in is weird and unnecessary, your dead adoptive father has a twin brother??? Compared to EVERY other Yakuza this game is insultingly bad.)[/spoiler] 

Good luck everyone. Praying for you all.

146811874.review:
If you heard the reviews about Yakuza 3, it ain't wrong
There's a good reason why people called it "blockuza"
And it's a great father figure simulator. (Crying in my Daddy issues)

Although I feel the frustration through out the game, considered using trainer, I finished the game completely in the end without any cheats, maybe slightly rushed through out the story though. 
But, looking back seeing the whole journey, something strikes me.

The game itself was more than just Yakuza, brawling, crime, humour, unlike previous episodes. Most of the things aren't even about any of those. 
- Yes the combat sucks, is there a way to get around it? Of course. But it doesn't have that combat feeling like any other  Yakuza games series always have, this will make you feel more like playing Dark Souls. 
- Yes half of the story is about the orphanage kids, drama wasn't really a roller coaster ride as half way the story some MF CEO will tell you almost everything you need to know. 
- Yes most mini games and side activities sucks like to run and catch, or even your typical darts, pool or what not. Using keyboard/mouse and Controllers wouldn't even able to save you in some situations. 
- Yes even the weapon modding or even using weapons are just straight out BS, most of the time you wouldn't even touch it unless it's a pew pew. 
I can keep going on if I have to. 

In the end, I adore and love the game. 
Not becuase it sucks, but how all those flaws become a true test of this Father Figure simulator. Everything is so hard to deal with and require such high amount of patience and precision, accuracy to what you do, just like a real father. 
Yes the combat can be encountered by looking for a good opening to hit it right on time at the right distance.
Yes everything you do felt like a grind but yet it make sense once you grinded the sub story and go back to main quest with all those exp, skills and money.
Yes the most difficult parts of the game wasn't in the end, it came at you unexpectedly mid game such as Lau Ka Long, and you need to go through it just to keep going on with the game or story knowing everything comes after just gets easier. 
Yes you can become powerful or even OP at a certain point like other Yakuza titles but not until you able to defeat the most difficult parts in the game. 

In a nutshell, everything you do in the game test your ability to become a true father figure. 
From the game play, story unfold, mechanics, challenges, everything require the same traits of a real father have. 
I grew from all those controller throwing keyboard flipping fights for sure. 

and that's how the bad become part of the game's essence, true to Kiryu situation being retired but have to deal with everything while being a father figure. 

Will i play it again? Maybe, maybe not, but no way you should skip through this chapter just becuase of those reasons.

Besides, 
It's still better than any Ubisoft game ever released. No regrets.

146436312.review:
As a longtime fan, I couldn't wait to step back into Kamurocho with the Yakuza 3 Remaster. This refreshed take on the PS3 classic had me hooked all over again on the series' gripping storytelling and quirky personality.

Visually, the remake really impresses. Kamurocho's neon-lit streets and Okinawa's sunny beaches look better than ever while retaining that distinct Yakuza flavor. The upgraded character models and textures bring everything to life in a modern yet faithful way. It was like seeing an old friend get a makeover.

Of course, visuals can only go so far - the narrative depth is what had me invested for the long haul. Kiryu trying to leave his past behind to run an orphanage tugs at the heartstrings. I felt even more connected to the motivations driving him and the colorful supporting cast.

Speaking of the cast, the localization and voice acting are top notch. I really felt immersed in every emotional beat and conversation thanks to performances bringing out that naturalistic Yakuza charm. The writing carries humor and gravitas equally well.

Combat still carries that satisfying brawler feel, letting you pummel goons with basic combos and environmental objects. It's easy to pick up but with enough heat actions and combos to master that veterans like me stay engaged. A few more modern quality-of-life improvements could've smoothed things out further.

In the end, even after completing Yakuza 3 multiple times before, this remaster pulled me back in with improved visuals and storytelling. Sure, some sections drag a bit, and it's not as polished as recent entries. But for longtime fans or newcomers, it's an offer you can't refuse. This remaster continues the Yakuza series' legacy of blending action, drama and humor into one stylish package.

146333494.review:
In this episode of "Kiryu Does Shit," we follow our bro on a super adventure and face the hardest task: taking care of 9 children. In the third chapter, we are busy with Super Mario and his child, with melon and pineapples as background characters. Super Mario's child, who is named after alcohol, was kidnapped by the Italian drug cartel, and we must save her. Then we become the third Mario brother.
In my extensive analysis of Yakuza 3, I discovered hidden easter eggs that only exist in my wildest imagination. For instance, during the epic boss battle in Chapter 6, Kiryu unleashed his secret martial arts move known as the 'Flying Noodle Fist,' where he flung ramen noodles at his foes with astonishing accuracy, leaving them both defeated and hungry.
In Chapter 8, there's a completely fabricated mini-game where Kiryu becomes a professional penguin wrestler, taking on the toughest penguin opponents in Antarctica. The penguins wore tiny top hats and tuxedos, adding a touch of class to this fictional bout.
The side quest involving Super Mario and his child took an unexpected twist when they revealed their secret power-up mushrooms that turned Kiryu into a giant, stomping his way through the streets of Kamurocho, causing traffic jams and chaos, while singing the national anthem of a made-up country.
Let's not forget the rare 'Singing Yakuza' sub-story in Chapter 9, where Kiryu and his Yakuza buddies formed a boy band and had dance-offs with rival gangs. The dance-offs were so intense that they caused spontaneous rainbows to appear in the sky.
By the time I reached Chapter 10, Kiryu had become a master chef, and there was a whole cooking mini-game where he competed in Iron Chef-style battles against other characters. His signature dish? Sushi made from fish he caught barehanded in the sewers.
All in all, Yakuza 3 is a game that defies reality at every turn, offering an absurd and fictionalized version of Kamurocho that kept me entertained with its bizarre surprises and completely untrue moments. It's a masterpiece of fantastical storytelling in the world of gaming [spoiler] and almost every thing i said was not in the game. or perhaps it was i dont remember im drunk [/spoiler]

145798366.review:
Returning to Kamurocho in "Yakuza 3 Remastered" felt more like a step back in time, not necessarily in a good way. While this remastered version attempts to revive the classic Yakuza experience, it falls short in several key areas, making it a less-than-stellar entry in the series.

Graphics and Visuals (2/5):
The visual improvements in "Yakuza 3 Remastered" are barely noticeable, leaving the game feeling dated and lacking the polish that fans of the series have come to expect. Character models and environments still show their age, and the attempt to modernize them feels half-hearted at best. It's a missed opportunity to truly breathe new life into this classic.

Gameplay (2/5):
While the core gameplay mechanics are intact, they also reveal the shortcomings of an older title. The combat system, which was groundbreaking in its time, now feels clunky and unrefined compared to more recent entries in the series. The lack of improvements in this area is disappointing and makes the game feel like a relic from a different era.

Story and Characters (3/5):
The storytelling in "Yakuza 3 Remastered" is one of its stronger points, but it still doesn't measure up to the standards set by later games in the series. The narrative lacks the depth and complexity that fans have come to expect, and while it explores Kiryu's personal journey, it fails to deliver the same emotional impact as some of the later Yakuza titles. The characters, while decently developed, don't leave a lasting impression.

Content and Extras (2/5):
While the remastered version includes all the original content, it doesn't offer much in the way of additional extras or improvements. The lack of new features or enhancements makes it feel like a missed opportunity to provide a more comprehensive and enticing package for both longtime fans and newcomers.

Sound and Music (3/5):
The sound and music in "Yakuza 3 Remastered" are serviceable, but they don't stand out in the same way as in later entries in the series. The voice acting is decent, but it lacks the exceptional performances found in more recent Yakuza games. The soundtrack, while fitting, doesn't leave a memorable impression.

Overall, "Yakuza 3 Remastered" is a lackluster attempt to revive a classic. While it may hold some nostalgia for longtime fans of the series, it fails to capture the magic and excitement of more recent Yakuza titles and struggles to compete with the standards set by modern gaming. this is going to take me some time to beat since i last beat it on the ps3

145349724.review:
For context, I'm writing this review from the perspective of someone starting with Yakuza 0 and playing through the series chronologically. I've played 0, Kiwami, Kiwami 2, and now, 3 Remastered. 
This is the most dated game out of the Yakuza PC ports, and it shows. 
The graphics are a little jarring at first, however they will grow on you, especially if you've played other PS3 era games.

The levelling system is very linear and the combat feels very restricting. Enemies block way too many attacks, which makes a lot of fights feel frustrating. Admittedly, I can't speak for how the Komaki moves affect combat because I completely missed him, however, I blame this on another flaw of the game. 

Unlike the more modern games/remakes, Yakuza 3 is lacking in incentives to engage with optional content. In the other games mentioned above, various events will interrupt your flow to entice you to do substories, play minigames, etc. Additionally, Yakuza 0's dual protagonists system creates a mild sense of FOMO for progressing the main story without doing side content while you have the chance (without making it too punishing). Yakuza 3 has nothing of the sort, and some of the side content is pretty well hidden in areas you mightn't think to check as you've already fully explored Kamurocho in 2-3 games by this point.

This game's biggest redeeming quality is it's story. While the story[i]telling[/i] isn't the best, the contents of the story are brilliant and it is a vital part of Kiryu's character growth. There are also some legendary moments, including one of the most emotional scenes in the series so far.

My review may seem quite negative, but I'm reccomending it because, despite its flaws I still enjoyed it, and it is essential for anyone who wants the experience of playing through the whole series chronologically. If you decide not to play it, you should at least watch the cutscenes on Youtube.

145346190.review:
RATING: 2/10
OVERALL IMPRESSION: Stay away from this game, and watch a lore recap. You will not miss any good gameplay.
DETAILS:
Positives:
- Facial Rigging and animations for talking/expressions during cutscenes is a lot better than they were in past games.

- Money grind is a lot less strict than past games, you'll find yourself spending significantly less to heal yourself at restaurants. 

Now that that's out of the way...

Negatives:
- You spend the first few chapters in an absolute slog being a glorified errand boy. Imagine all the really boring substories from past games, mash them together into a Frankenstein's Monster of garbage, and make them part of the main story, and you have the first 5 or so chapters of Yakuza 3.

- Combat is totally broken. Enemies will spam blocks all the time, so you better get a weapon that can break block early! Oh wait, you can't!

- Coin Lockers, which worked to benefit players who explored the cities regardless of what chapter they were on, have been reworked. Keys no longer spawn in the first few chapters.

- Heat Burn-Out was re-added. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if they didn't make it so you didn't get an absolutely pitiful amount of Heat per attack. Heat Actions are useless to the player until they obtain significant upgrades to their Heat skill tree. Getting grabbed by enemies is basically a GG for atleast half of your Heat Bar as well, because you lose Heat much quicker while grabbed.

- EXP System is bogus. You can no longer choose what upgrade you want to get next, like every single past installment, the game now uses a predetermined skill path for each of the 4 skill "trees": Soul, Heat, Body, and Tech.

- The animations are really clunky, stiff, and overall unnatural. Kiryu can now turn on a dime without needing to take a second to stop his forward momentum.

- Groups of enemies no longer show up on the map until they're sprinting at you. Better memorize their outfits and spawns, cause one unexpected enemy encounter can and probably will send you back to the main menu!

- The new city is cool and all, but it somehow manages to have less explorable ground than Sotenbori, which is a literal fucking square.

- Enemies do significantly more damage to an unprepared player if they play on Normal difficulty. You will frequently be using Staminan XX to recover from street fights instead of just using a Toughness L or two.

- The inventory system has returned to the Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 system of limited slots and non-stacking items. Refer to the points made earlier about Heat and Enemy Damage.


-------SPOILERS AHEAD-------

The story, if you can even call it a story, is utter horseshit. You start out, again, as mentioned before, as the orphanage errand boy, slogging through menial task after menial task for the first few chapters. The real story after Kiryu is done with the orphanage has no tension whatsoever, every single plot twist and weird ass plot device is forshadowed by a chapter or two, and the ending where Mine jumps off the roof for no fucking reason whatsoever is a stupid plot point.

144986640.review:
Yakuza 3 Remastered is the latest installment in the long-running and beloved Yakuza franchise. This game was released in Japan in 2009 and has been remastered and released worldwide in 2020. At its core, Yakuza 3 Remastered is a 3D action-adventure game set in the fictional city of Kamurocho.

The game follows the adventures of Kazuma Kiryu, a retired Yakuza boss, as he tries to solve the various mysteries, fights, and puzzles that beset him. As expected, the gameplay remains largely unchanged from its original Japanese release. Players control Kazuma Kiryu as he moves around the city, interacts with NPCs, and engages in combat with various enemies.

The biggest and most notable change to Yakuza 3 Remastered is the improved visuals. The game has been given a complete graphical overhaul, with higher resolution textures, improved lighting, and enhanced character models. This makes the game look and feel much more modern and polished.

The story of Yakuza 3 Remastered is still as strong as ever. The game follows Kazuma Kiryu as he tries to unravel the mysteries that have been plaguing him since his retirement. Along the way, he will meet a variety of characters, from Yakuza bosses to everyday citizens, and he will have to make tough choices about how to handle each situation.

Yakuza 3 Remastered is a great game for fans of the franchise, as well as newcomers who have never played a Yakuza game before. The story is still engaging and the improved visuals make the game look great. The combat is still satisfying and there are plenty of side activities to keep players occupied. Yakuza 3 Remastered is an excellent entry into the franchise and is sure to be a hit with fans of the series.

144693447.review:
Compared to other mainline Yakuza games, this one in particular is stands out as the worst. Overall the combat ranges from mediocre to dreadfully bad. The AI seemingly chooses its actions based off how angry it causes you to be. 95% of the enemies will simultaneously block every attack you throw at them whilst ogling blankly at you, not throwing out any attacks, barely moving. They essentially turtle throughout the entire game. Combine that with the fact that the majority of hard enemies can downright disallow you to grapple them, the lack of easy access heat moves, and the staggering realization that at no point in the entire game does Kiryu reach the point where he can breeze through enemies. I've 100%'d this game and at no point are you given an opportunity to tear through enemies, Kiryu just does so little damage. Overall this games combat is a major let down and massive annoyance for the player.
     Story-wise, the game starts out surprisingly strong. The new beach setting is extremely refreshing to see, though a large section of the game still takes place in Kamurocho. The dynamic between Kiryu, Haruka, and their band orphans is done really well, showing Kiryu's more compassionate and understanding side to contrast his more stoic attributes. The story is also considerably more goofy compared to the previous entries. Its very wacky, which for some could be a turn off, but this game handles it pretty well; It doesn't  overstay its welcome and is generally funny and creative. That being said, around chapter 8 the story begins to slow to a crawl and present a very generic C.I.A/F.B.I/W.H.Y plot. Overall the story of Yakuza 3 is probably the highlight, a shining light within the crust that is this game. 
     The last thing I want to point out are the mini games. Mirroring the combat, the mini games range from mediocre to dreadful. The crane game, arcade shooter, batting, bowling, gambling, massage parlor, mahjong, and shogi are barely any different from previous remastered installments. However, the other half of the mini games are very annoying to deal with, in particular pool, and darts. Both are extremely jank, with darts being so weird and precise to control that its nearly impossible to pick it up without the use of a guide. Pool is also pretty jank, with the shot preview literally just not working for close shots. On top of that, the AI just cheats, the harder players are literally omnipotent pool gods and can bank crazy shots without you even being able to retaliate. 
     Yakuza 3 is considerably worse than the previous remasters, it should've gotten the Kiwami treatment, but unfortunately it didn't and it suffers tremendously from it. Do not expect the same level of quality, you're not getting it from this game.

144499918.review:
Featuring firsts for the series that ended up being positive and formative changes, the game as a whole unfortunately doesn't hold up and a lot of it can be attributed to a very poorly made remaster which completely broke the combat. However, the game also suffers from poorly executed story elements, especially one that sits at the core of this games narrative - [spoiler]the orphanage[/spoiler]. As much as I personally love some of the things this game tries to do, I find it difficult to recommend as the core elements of this game are so lacking - combat and narrative. I recommend trying the game and if you aren't enjoying it getting a story recap in some fashion and moving on to the next game since it would be a shame if this game put you off from playing the other entries in the series.




------- SPOILERS AHEAD --------



Elaborating on story elements that I felt were poorly executed:
[spoiler]
[b]Morning Glory[/b]:
Kiryu running an orphanage is a story element I personally love as it's a very unique narrative point to have in a video game as well as other media. Unfortunately, it isn't executed well. Each kid in the orphanage gets their own part of the story. Their stories feature a variety of problems and are meant to display how Kiryu deals with their problems as well as introduce the kids as characters. The gameplay in these parts of the story comes down to talking with all the different kids about whatever the problem may be with an occasional odd job. On top of that, the issues these kids are facing are covered on a very surface level. Each kids segment is resolved fairly quickly and while not all of the topics covered in these parts are worthy of a more elaborate story part, stories like bullying with Shiro and not being able to do what you love because of an illness with Taichi are ones that have potential to be more interesting than they were in the game. It ultimately would have been better as a sidestory like the HLA since it ends up feeling like a chore when interrupting the main story and the stories arent fleshed out enough to warrant a mandatory main story spot.


[b]Focusing on the wrong thing[/b]:
Mine and Rikiya are this games greatest additions in terms of characters.
Rikiya is a classic Yakuza character archetype - loveable and determined young yakuza who looks up to Kiryu. His death only took away from the story. Kiryu had the most severe reaction we've seen him have so far to someones death and while it is a very sad death it feels a little off in retrospect. That reaction would have made a lot of more sense if it was in any way acknowledged why Kiryu is sad and this kind of reactions makes the most sense for Kiryu if it was because every time he gets involved in something the ones he cares about keep dying. However, that isn't something the story focuses on and it ends up being a death without much impact. Everyone moves on after his death and that's the end of that. No further elaboration on Kiryus feelings and the way he grieves him. It ends up being a meaningless death. Not only that, Rikiya gets killed in a frustratingly bad turn of events where all the characters just leave a loaded gun right next to a defeated Tamashiro.
Mine is another example of poor focus. He ended up being a very interesting and complicated character but was given very little time to shine as we only learn of his philosophy at the very end of the game. Had the orphanage content been cut down or maybe less focus was put on some other antagonists like Kanda who is very one-dimensional, he would have gotten the screen time he deserved. It's also a shame that the only scenes you see of him beforehand is him being cold and unstable. The story would have greatly benefited if there was a bigger focus on Mine much like the previous two games focused heavily on Nishikiyama and Ryuji. Mine is a great character but there should have been more of him. The lack of focus is intentional as this is the first game that tries to include multiple antagonists. However, it is strange as the game is large content wise. There are 118 substories, a few of which include cutscnes and are used to elaborate on main story characters, many minigames and the HLA sidestory. Even with all that, the story feels like it didn't have enough time to do everything it wanted. Hamazaki had a very memorable introduction but didn't do anything untill literally after the credits and Mine was in a simillar situation. The way you get to learn about the plot is by talking with a high ranking politician and asking him a bounch of questions. It's a very sudden huge info dump as opposed to a gradual, more natural flow of information throughout the story. Instead giving more time to all of that what gets the most screen time is the orphanage which would have been fine if this game was a lot bigger.



[b]Tonal shifting[/b]:
This is the first game in the series that features big shifts between a lighthearted and goofy and a serious tone. This ended up becoming one of the Yakuza series' most prominent elements and something the games later on execute really well but seeing as this is the first time it's been implemented it ended up hurting the story just a little bit. Kashiwagis death is handled in a strange way. He is meant to be a person Kiryu looked up to but his death doesn't seem to phase him as the only two moments you see his death having an effect on Kiryu is immediately after and when he's talking to Rikiya on the bench in Public Park 3. During that conversation with Rikiya, the player is given a choice to answer with a serious and non-serious answer. To be more specific, you can say the following:

"Honestly, Kashiwagi-san was..."
1. Great at leading from the shadows
2. Great at hiding from the shadows

"Amazing? Yeah. Yeah, I guess so. I was especially in awe of...
1. How level-headed he was.
2. How much he loved cold noodles.

The fact that you can pick between these two answers takes away from the impact of Kashiwagis death and makes it feel like the writers and Kiryu didn't care much for Kashiwagi, which is strange since he should be a much more prominent figure primarily because he's a role model to Kiryu but also because he's a very important figure in the Tojo Clan as the head of the Kazama Family and the person that carries on the legacy of one of the Tojo Clans most legendary figures.


[b]The combat[/b]:
I have not played the original but I have heard that the combat wasn't this bad in it.
Regardless, this games remaster has many issues:
- Quickstep is very weak as enemies will sometimes do 180s to rotate around and hit you. The tracking some attacks that bosses have look ridiculous and make the games combat feel even more clunky than it already is as they will fly towards you to catch up to you at really high speeds (ex. Mines running attack). Although this isn't a boss-exclusive issue since some types of enemies will do perform similar attacks.
- Enemy AI is poorly programmed since they continue to block for extended periods of time and attack very rarely making every encounter feel like a chore as you're forced to either grab them to death or wait for them to attack and parry or hope your quickstep doesn't bug out and get tracked.
- Random encounters are too difficult to dodge as enemies will stand in your way and if you pass next to them immediately trigger a fight as opposed to the later games giving you time to avoid the fight if you don't want it by alerting you that you've been spotted first.
Overall, these issues and the inconsistencies it causes makes the combat feel like a chore rather than something to enjoy.
[/spoiler]

144397006.review:
If you want to actually enjoy the combat of blockuza, follow the following steps:
- speed through to chapter 6
- Do a sub story called dragon palace
- Get Tiger drop, Komaki back fist and Komaki parry (espacially parry and tiger drop)
Now if any enemy even looks like they will throw a punch, just parry them and get a free combo attacking from their back
For more flavor:
- pick up knuckle, dagger and katana type weapons 
- Bring lots of stamina type meds
- Blow people up with heat moves for fun
For the most part, spend upgrades on technique and body in early chapters to have an easier time, especially the double finishers in the technique tree.
If you don't mind 30 fps, the game is quite fun. There's also a mod for 30 fps combat for 60 fps which is highly recommended if not playing on 60 fps.
Later in the game, getting drunk and abusing a certain charged move that generates heat is the way to go.
Enjoy and have fun blowing up bosses with tiger drop!


Also note that this game is using any integrated graphics card as the default graphics processor. As such, go to Nvidia control panel(or the AMD equivalent) to switch the graphics processor to your graphics cad before playing!

143828477.review:
Sadly the point where many people get filtered in their foray into the Yakuza series. Fair enough, I'm on 4 now and consider 0 to be the best entry so far so you're a bit spoiled quality wise. After 0 people go to the even more modern Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2, and then if they still wish to continue the story, this. 

Unlike 1 or 2 Yakuza 3 received no Kiwami upgrade (Kiwami means extreme) meaning (gameplay wise, at least) it's no different from the day it was released back in early 2009. Yes, the graphics are going to be inferior, the gameplay is a bit clunkier than the newer entries that people will have played first and despite being the third entry on the list in areas you get the feeling the writers and game designers were still perfecting the formula for a Yakuza title, but I like it. Alot, actually. It's my second favourite after 0, with a very decent story. In my opinion, the strongest story in the series since 0 (and arguably the best antagonist so far, including 0)

I found it a bit bemusing, if not downright jarring at first considering just how much of the story doesn't revolve around violence. Not to spoil anything specifically but a considerable portion of the game revolves around Kiryu performing menial tasks at his home and for the orphans. It's different, but comfy. If you pick this (and presumably 4 and 5 as part of the remastered collection) don't get confused by the "Remastered" title. It's purely a cosmetic remaster. Don't be discouraged because it's a little old, Yakuza 3 and the following games should be played just as much as 0, Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2. Please do not get filtered like so many were.

Also Yoshitaka Mine is literally me

"Rush through it and get to 4"

...

I think this might be my favorite, second only to Zero (Because, come on, its Yakuza Zero) Okinawa is such a nice location and it really feels like they tried to capture the spirit of the place as much as they could, Characters are good, story's relatively clear (sans a few points where it seems like they wanted to make it longer but had to make due) and seems more... idk "relevant" to the characters involved? So what do I think about Yakuza 3? The black Sheep of the Yakuza family?

...

Play it.

Like, really play it.

Don't get though it just cause or skip it so you can play 4.

Just.

Treat it like a normal Yakuza game, and you will have fun.

Anyway, as for me Ill move on to 4 now that I have finished 3 and given it a fair shake. Theres supposed to be four frickin playable characters in that one. Dunno how Ill keep track...

P.S: Used a very small mod that adds higher quality cut scenes and adds back in some licensed music from the original, as well as removing some mild censorship, and other fixes. Can reccomend.

143416905.review:
Yakuza games are silly. From their nonsensical plotlines to the bizarre minigames, none of these games are, in my opinion, meant to be taken entirely seriously. Because of this, my general expectations of these games are not high, but oh boy does this one take the cake.
Before going into this game, I already knew it had been deemed as the worst one in the entire franchise, but believe me, I was not prepared for just how bad this thing was. Now, is it the worst thing in the world by itself? No, far from it, but compared to all of the games you've probably played before this one (0,k1,k2), this one just sticks out as a sore thumb.

I gotta talk about the visuals first. If you had told me that this got released in 2021, I wouldn't have believed you until I fact checked it myself. I understand that unlike kiwami 1 and kiwami 2, this game is simply a remaster and not a rework, but even for a remaster this is a bit tragic. Especially with the whiplash you're gonna get when you switch from kiwami 2, a game that looks absolutely gorgeous and will have your graphics card fighting for it's life, to yakuza 3 which looks like it was made at least a decade ago, if not more. I don't understand why they called this Yakuza 3 "Remastered", when this game, in my opinion, lacks the fundamental part of a remaster: improvement of visuals. Sure, they increased the resolution from the original 2009 release for the PS3, but besides that it all looks the same. Remasters can update character models, environments, etc, if the developers bother to do so. Again, as a standalone this isn't bad but compared to the other games, this one's definitely got the weakest visuals.

The combat in this one is also probably the worst so far. The combat in these games is typically braindead, and this is coming from someone who is terrible at beat em ups and has so far in all of the Yakuza games i've played, while playing on the normal difficulty, only died on two boss fights (once on the 1st Kuze fight because I was still getting used to the game and once on Y0's So Amon who is a secret boss meant to be ridiculously hard). If you shove enough medicine up your ass you are pretty much guaranteed to pass every fight without breaking a sweat (except if you're fighting Jingu, this one might give you a mental breakdown). This might sound like a complaint, but it's not. While I enjoy difficult games, I like how easy these games are, it's relaxing.
But the combat on this one, besides being the most braindead so far, is also the most frustrating. The amount of blocking the enemies do is insane. You got 1 hit in on the boss? Good, now get ready to spend the next minute waiting for him to stop blocking so you can hit him again and take off 1% of his health. This doesn't only go for the bosses either, regular goons on the street also block any chance they get, tho these are way less frustrating. The more frustrating part about said goons is that, unlike in the other games, it's really hard to avoid them on the street. They will see you and catch you before you even register that they're near you. It's also harder to spot them because, unlike in the previous 3 games, they don't stand in groups. It's just a single goon standing and he will magically spawn in his companions when the fight starts.
Besides the blocking issue, hitting the heat actions is also a bit of a pain in the ass. It feels like you only have a split moment for some of them and you have to be in the pixel perfect position to execute them (especially the one you can do to a downed enemy).

The plot of this one is also the worst in my opinion. If any piece of media has a 30 minute scene where 3 characters are sitting in a room, while one of them is giving a massive info dump about the game's entire (pretty boring) plot while your visuals are limited to watching them in this room from different angles, yeah that's just an immediate sign of a bad plot. These games are, as I've already said, pretty silly (which I love). But this isn't even silly, this is just boring.
This game also uses one of the world's biggest and most boring cliches, [spoiler] turns out character A actually had a twin that was never mentioned the whole time... The whole Kazama has a twin thing is so stupid. Especially because, [b] they're not even twins [/b] . Kazama is supposed to be about 3 years older than his brother, so tell me then why do they look identical (spoiler: the answer is lazy writing). Not to even mention the fact that his brother really doesn't add much to the overall story. I feel like he was added purely for shock factor. [/spoiler]
There were, however, things I liked about the plot:
[list]
[*]Kiryu running the orphanage
[*]the Ryudo Clan (especially Rikiya)
[*]Majima (feels like this is the first time where he has a pretty big role in the plot since Yakuza 0)
[*]Mine (this game gets extra points for having an evil gay antagonist)
 [/list]

I gotta mention the karaoke real quick, because I'm a sucker for this minigame and it's the one thing I go and do as soon as I can in every game. It's lackluster and this makes sense considering that this is the first game that introduced this mechanic, but I'm still going to complain. All of the songs besides Kamurocho Lullaby are forgettable and generic, but my real gripe are the input visuals. Really struggled with them (for the record, I play on a keyboard and from what I've seen, the inputs seem to be easier to read on the controller).

Another mechanic this game introduced is the Revelation system, and it's honestly phenomenal. Kiryu will whip out his flip phone, capture a few images of something absolutely ridiculous happening in front of him, think of a witty caption and then post it onto his online blog. Besides being funny, the revelation system also lets Kiryu learn new skills. I never know what the fuck to expect in these Revelation cutscenes but I'm always a bit baffled after them. Whoever came up with that shit needs a promotion

In conclusion, so far this is the weakest game in the franchise, with a wonky plot (even the creators themselves are aware of this given the fact they joke about it in Kiwami 2), boring combat and underwhelming visuals. However it still manages to carry that usual Yakuza charm the previous games have. I'm glad I didn't skip this one tho I don't see myself revisiting it in the future (at least not any time soon).

So, is it worth playing?
Yes, this game is worth playing if you've played and enjoyed the previous ones, if anything, it's worth playing just for the infamous Majima pink garbage truck scene.

142081265.review:
Starting off with saying that Yakuza 3 is incredibly overhated. It's rough around the edges to be sure, but it was the first PS3 Yakuza title, so judge it in it's context. Main point to address is the joke about excessive guarding. Yes, enemies guard a lot. But you can also very easily just break guard with weapons, use X, X, X, Y, Y to crush guard and utilise back attacks. Its not that big a deal as Redditors make it out to be. My brief summary is as follows:

Good:
- Score is very good, battle tracks are very funky.
- Setting is very nice to look at, even if it's mainly used for the orphanage stuff which can get a teensy bit tedious. It's all story-building though.
- A lot of things can be unlocked from the Revelations system and upgrade system, and most of your repertoire is available from light time investments, you don't need to grind for hours doing one type of content just to get your full move set like in Kiwami or 0.

Bad:
- The narrative I felt was a bit silly and kept introducing twist elements that felt a bit desperate. A lot of it is frontloaded in the last two chapters too. I also feel that the villains introduced were untapped potential. You're shown a set of ruthless, cold-blooded Yakuza heads and... they get one boss fight after their initial introduction. I really liked Kanda's intro, I wish there was more of him.

Overall, a solid entry with many fun points. It just takes some getting used to. Again, it is an early PS3 game ported mostly untouched.
