141864471.review:
[h1]Yakuza 3[/h1]

Yakuza 3 is the third installment of the Yakuza franchise, this being a remaster of the original PS3 game.
Being a remaster, it has its ups and downs, but I'll get to that later.
It's a big graphical upgrade from Y2 to Y3 using the technology the PS3 had back then, as it's also a way bigger game overall compared to both PS2 games.
Funny thing aside it's not the first Yakuza game on PS3, that goes to Yakuza Kenzan a spin-off samurai game which also introduced the beloved mini-game of the Yakuza games, Karaoke.
Still being a beat em up, the way they made the story was quite a refreshing take and I absolutely loved the story this game has. I also just love this Kiryu design, giving so much expression compared to the Stoic and cold lookin classic Kiryu.
You'll notice that he smiles like a lot, but man, this Kiryu can also be quite emotional...

([b]Short story summary[/b])
We see a beautiful blue sea and a beach, we see Haruka waving to Kiryu as he comes out of the sea having caught a big fish and his hair ain't even wet lol,
he tells Haruka to make dinner ready and hopes to not let anyone waiting, as we are wondering who does Kiryu mean with everyone? It's dinner time, and we see a lot of children playing ball, and Haruka is calling everyone to sit on the table,
one of the children notices a person coming that they all know, all the children go to him, altho the man doesn't really seem so happy, it's like he's here to tell something to Kiryu.
Kiryu asks if something happened, and the man responds by telling that their boss got shot, a quick fade to black, and we see Daigo Dojima again in a car, and it looks like he became the next chairman of the Tojo clan, his assistant gets a call telling them about a deal of some sort.
Daigo keeps telling them that he ain't interested in it and that his answer is final. As he discusses with his assistant to stop speaking about considering he ain't interested, his assistant tells him if it has to do because of the fourth chairman, as Daigo tells his driver to take him back to Tojo HQ and cancel the banquet.
Daigo arrives back at HQ as he is tolled by someone that a mysterious person is here to speak with Daigo, as Daigo didn't believe when he said to Daigo who wants to see him. Daigo enters the room and meets the mysterious person, they talk about letting Daigo have the deed instead Daigo kept refusing and to Daigo's eyes it looks like the mysterious man goes for his gun, so he picks his gun trying to shoot him....
Back at Okinawa, we see Kiryu and the man that tolled him about his shot boss run to the operation room, as he confronts a little girl and she lets Kiryu see how the man looked drawn in her sketchbook.

([b]Gameplay[/b])
Now before anyone goes at it saying stuff like blockuza 3, you're wrong and just bad at the game. (just kidding)
Yes there is a lot of controversy with the gameplay of Yakuza 3 for the amounts of blocking the enemies do in this game, the sad thing about it is
it was totally normal in the original PS3 version of Yakuza 3, in the remastered version however enemies block almost the entire fight, what's more frustrating is that when you try to dodge to the back of the enemy or boss, kiryu makes a whole spin which is so dumb beyond belief,
this was also not an issue in the original PS3 version of Yakuza 3. Let's just say the beginning of the game might be a lot of doing the same moves but trust me when having komaki moves asap like the 
[u]Komaki Parry[/u] and [u]Tiger Drop[/u] the game gets fun as fuck with its combat system and trust me you're going to use Komaki Parry a lot! Imo the combat is way better than the DE DOD combat (sue me). The combat is so technical you have no idea the possibilities of doing combos, like mf WALL COMBOS, that shit broken af and very useful against bosses.
Progression is again with XP in this game, you go to the [b]UPGRADE MENU[/b] when click on [b]START[/b] and upgrade your move set from there. A new thing that is added in this game are [b]REVELATIONS[/b], strong deadly heat moves and [b]FEEL THE HEAT[/b] moves against bosses that are very useful and cool af not so late in the game do you get to learn about it. Another new thing that is added to the game are [b]CHASE SEQUENCES[/b], where you go and chase enemies or normal people as they are running away from you.
Overall combat is the same as the OG Y1 and Y2, but more refined.

([b]Substories, Minigames and Side content[/b])
Most of the beloved substories return from the OG PS3 Yakuza 3 in Yakuza 3 Remastered, as some substories are completely removed as they were against modern times.
As always, you can come across them randomly, and they are fun as always. One of my favorites being one where Kiryu goes full detective mode in a murder case that happened in Café Alps.
Most of the minigames return as well, with Karaoke and Fishing being a first for the Yakuza title and let me tell you fishing in this game oh man, be ready to put some hours into catching that darn tuna.
Pool and Bowling return in this game, but man does bowling suck in Y3, on the other hand pool feels fine and playable. The Purgatory returns as well with a new mode having TAG-BATTLES and like I said you can still learn moves from Komaki but not a lot this time.
A small part of side content is back that went missing in Yakuza Kiwami 2 and that is the Cabaret Club, you meet a woman on the streets ask them if they'd like a job as a cabaret hostess and complete the side activity by having the hostess rank to S, it can be annoying in the beginning but when you find a perfect look for the hostess it's going to be fine.

([b]Enemies and Bosses[/b])
In Yakuza 3 we have a new location called Okinawa, it's also a lot smaller compared to Kamurocho, but it's still a nice location never the less.
In both Kamurocho and Okinawa you can come across enemies, but holy shit do they appear very fast when you're just walking in each location, and the annoying thing is they are everywhere and not even have a unique design that it's an enemy, they look like basic residents.
Enemy variety is also less in this game, just Angry Guys, Yakuza and Punks, yeah not a lot, The Story does have lots of enemy variety on the other hand.
I also like how some groups in the story you fight against have their own theme and not everyone has the exact theme, altho you do hear one theme almost every time when fighting groups of enemies.
Another thing added is the HLA, an organization that tries to hunt killers, as you get bounties to hunt each killer and take them back to the HLA. The final boss in that is a nostalgic character from Y1/Kiwami.
As for bosses there are really some enjoyable bosses in this game especially in the final act as Y3 is also technically the first Yakuza game having a Dynamic boss intro, and some bosses have also a great boss theme.

([b]Soundtrack[/b])
The Yakuza 3 OST is louder, hardcore, rocked, metal, techno, beat, mixed into one. Also being one of my favorite ost's in the franchise,

141834699.review:
[h1][b]The Black Sheep of the Ryu Ga Gotoku games is still a fun, if very flawed and frustrating, game.[/b][/h1] 

Even when it was released on the PlayStation 3, Yakuza 3 was seen as a black sheep. Not because of (at least for the western release) cut content but due to the mechanics, the change in location and how the game feels somewhat stiff at times. 

This is not to say that Yakuza 3 was seen as a terrible game or a misstep. Far from it. It was just that it was something that felt different and took a while getting use to but also paradoxicality not feeling like much has changed in the formula (this was felt even more in the West, due to how long it took for us to get it and again cut content.)

Which is what puts Yakuza 3 Remastered in a weird spot. 1 and 2 got revamped with Kiwami, but Yakuza 3 Enhanced is basically just updated graphics with all content from the Japanese version. But the gameplay remains unchanged from the PlayStation 3 version. No revamp to the awkward combat, the experience and many of the mini-games are a shell of what you’d come to expect from Yakuza Zero, 1 and 2 Kiwami and the visuals don’t leap out like before. And if you’ve come from those games, it’s going to be an even rougher experience. 

There’s the level up system which feels very restrictive. It may have been done to prevent grinding to make Kiryu into a near-overpowered badass early into the game but it also feels gated. 

The same feeling goes for getting heat actions, weapons and armour, with the game’s modding system not being noteworthy until very late into the game and even then the available options still feel limited. It’s justifiable to not have Kiryu once again become overpowered early/midway into the game, but it’d be nice if Yakuza 3 Remastered was more generous in what you could unlock. 

The combat feels off. It feels like they had to nerf Kiryu and so you don’t feel as badass as before. Some heat actions don’t feel as epic and it does have an awkward feel. This is especially noticeable against bosses and tough opponents (e.g. the ones you face in the Coliseum activity), where it seems you have to cheese them more than use what you’ve learned up to that point.  It’s not a total disaster, as its still solid enough to be enjoyable but you do feel like a handicapped badass. 

Visually, even considering the time frame and how this is only a remastered and not a remake/overhaul like the Kiwami games are, it’s still a let down to an extent. This wasn’t a huge leap back in the PS3 and you can see the age and rough edges still present, such as sudden pop-up and sometimes NPC’s having derpy or dead-eyes look. 

And of course, it has its own set of Yakuza restrictiveness: Save points are really far apart, you can’t accept more than one hitman mission, can’t buy more than one food at a time, item inventory is always a pain and other, somewhat archaic game design choices.  

Again though, this must be stressed that DESPITE these issues Yakuza 3 Enhanced is still overall a fun game. When it hits its stride, the dopamine hits hard and you remember why you love the series; 

Kamurocho feels like an old friend, vibrant, looking different but also similar and hiding its share of secrets underneath all the glitz and glamour and while Ryukyu isn’t Sotenbori (Osaka), it still has its character and charm, feeling like a place to visit and absorb a different aspect of Japan. While the visuals might not pop out, its still an impressive showcase of packing cities with details and small touches that still make it fun to explore and just run around. 

The music is banging, as expected with the Ryu Ga Gotoku library (and this being Sega, who rarely drop the ball when it comes to music,) with a mix that ranges from techno to J-pop (and that’s not getting into the Karaoke songs.) 

There is always moments that are dramatic or comedic (sometimes swinging around in the same scene) that make one actually care what is taking place and invest in characters, even those who just appear in a small substory. Speaking of those, the substories once again reveal the soul of Yakuza/Ryu Ga Gotoku series, with some amusing (and even downright heart-warming) scenes. 

And yes, some of the activities aren’t that engaging or fully fleshed out (hostess ones spring to mind) but Yakuza 3 still has a lot of content that it hits more than it misses and just when you begin to flag or tire of one thing it throws something else to keep you hooked. 

Yakuza 3 Enhanced is often seen as the “worst” of the games in the franchise and it is justifiable line of opinion. But it also hides a truth about it; That even the “worst” games in the Ryu Ga Gotoku franchise are still solid b-tier fun. This is enhanced (ahem) by the fact that the price of the game is dead-cheap (it’s also part of the Yakuza Remastered Collection, again a fantastic bundle). 

It is best to come to Yakuza 3 Enhanced with expectation in check but also the fact that you’re still going to have a lot of enjoyment pounding solutions into people’s faces. 

[h1]Rating: 7*/10[/h1]
(*More towards a 6 than an 8)

141649132.review:
Title: Enchanting Musical Menagerie - My Singing Monsters Review

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

My Singing Monsters is a delightful and unique mobile game that combines adorable creature collecting with musical creativity. From the moment I started playing, I was drawn into a charming world filled with colorful creatures and catchy tunes.

The concept of the game is simple yet captivating: you collect and breed a variety of monsters, each with its own distinct appearance and musical sound. The monsters are visually appealing and come in all shapes and sizes, from fuzzy to spiky, each possessing its own charm. Breeding monsters to discover new species kept me engaged and eager to uncover the next whimsical creature.

The heart of My Singing Monsters lies in its music. Each monster has its own musical note, and as you place them on your island, they create a harmonious symphony. The sounds blend seamlessly, creating a relaxing and enchanting atmosphere. The game's music is a true highlight, offering a soothing experience that's perfect for unwinding.

Customization is another strong point of the game. You can design and decorate your monster's island to your heart's content, adding structures, decorations, and arranging the monsters to create your own unique musical landscape. This personal touch adds depth to the gameplay and allows for creative expression beyond breeding monsters.

While My Singing Monsters offers a captivating experience, it's not without its downsides. The game's progression can feel slow at times, requiring patience as you wait for your monsters to earn coins and generate resources. In-app purchases are also quite prominent, tempting players to speed up progress with real money. While this is common in many mobile games, it can be a drawback for players who prefer a more balanced and less pay-to-win experience.

Overall, My Singing Monsters is a joyful and engaging mobile game that's perfect for music lovers and fans of cute creature collecting. Its combination of charming visuals, enchanting music, and creative customization options make for an enjoyable and unique gaming experience. While the pacing and in-app purchases might deter some players, the game's charm and musical magic are well worth giving it a try.

141553537.review:
Yakuza 3: A Promising Yet Flawed Entry in the Series

Rating: 3/5 stars

Yakuza 3, the third installment in the beloved Yakuza series, brings players back into the seedy underbelly of Kamurocho with its trademark mix of crime drama, intense combat, and immersive open-world exploration. While it retains many of the elements that made its predecessors so engaging, Yakuza 3 falls short in several key areas, leaving fans feeling somewhat disappointed.

One of the biggest letdowns in Yakuza 3 is its pacing. The game starts off slowly, taking a considerable amount of time to build up the main plotline. While this deliberate approach can be appreciated, the excessive amount of filler content, including repetitive mini-games and side quests, bogs down the experience. These distractions often feel disconnected from the main story and lack the depth and variety that fans have come to expect from the series.

Additionally, the localization of Yakuza 3 suffers from some questionable decisions. The English translation fails to capture the nuances of the original Japanese dialogue, resulting in moments of awkward dialogue and a loss of emotional impact. This issue is particularly evident during crucial story moments, hindering the player's ability to fully invest in the narrative and connect with the characters.

Another major drawback is the combat system. While it retains the satisfying brawling mechanics from previous entries, Yakuza 3 feels somewhat clunky and outdated compared to more recent installments. The lack of fluidity in combat, combined with limited move sets and repetitive enemy encounters, makes the combat segments feel monotonous and uninspired.

Despite these shortcomings, Yakuza 3 does have its merits. The game's setting, Kamurocho, is meticulously detailed and beautifully recreated, offering a visually stunning and atmospheric backdrop for players to explore. The main story, once it picks up, still manages to deliver engaging moments of suspense and drama, showcasing the series' signature storytelling prowess.

Additionally, Yakuza 3 introduces a new focus on the protagonist's personal relationships and explores deeper character development, which adds emotional depth to the narrative. The side quests, although excessive, do provide some humorous and heartfelt moments that further flesh out the world and its inhabitants.

In conclusion, Yakuza 3 is a mixed bag. While it retains the series' charm and strengths, it falls short in crucial aspects that hinder the overall experience. The pacing issues, localization problems, and outdated combat mechanics prevent it from reaching the heights set by its predecessors. However, fans of the Yakuza series may still find enjoyment in the game's story and exploration elements.

140220747.review:
As a [b]die-hard fan[/b] of the Yakuza series, I was thrilled to dive into Yakuza 3 Remastered and relive the adventures of Kiryu Kazuma once again. However, while the game certainly had its strengths, it also had some noticeable weaknesses that dampened the overall experience.

Let's start with the positives. Yakuza 3 Remastered delivers an engrossing narrative, packed with compelling characters and intense moments. The story takes players on an emotional rollercoaster, exploring the depths of Kiryu's past and his struggles with the Yakuza lifestyle. The remastered visuals breathe new life into the game, making Kamurocho and Okinawa vibrant and immersive. The attention to detail is commendable, and the world feels alive with its bustling streets and intricate shops.

However, the game falls short in certain aspects, particularly the combat system. While Yakuza titles are known for their brawling action, Yakuza 3 Remastered's combat can be [b]frustrating[/b]. The enemies seem to have an unfair advantage, often blocking your attacks indefinitely, leading to a repetitive and dull experience. It's disappointing when you want to unleash Kiryu's full power but are met with relentless blocking.

Another drawback that impacted my enjoyment was the abundance of filler content. While side activities have always been a part of the Yakuza games, Yakuza 3 Remastered takes it to another level. There were numerous times when I felt these filler moments dragged on for too long, disrupting the pacing of the main story. As a fan, I felt compelled to push through, but it did detract from the overall experience.

That said, despite its flaws, I would still recommend Yakuza 3 Remastered, but with a specific audience in mind: [b]Yakuza enthusiasts[/b]. If you're a fan of the series and eager to delve deeper into the lore, Yakuza 3 Remastered provides valuable insights into Kiryu's past and the world of Yakuza. However, I wouldn't recommend playing this game casually or as an introduction to the series.

In conclusion, Yakuza 3 Remastered is a mixed bag for fans. It excels in storytelling and visual enhancements, but falters in its combat system and the excessive filler content. If you're a devoted fan seeking more Yakuza goodness, this remastered version is worth exploring, but be prepared to endure some frustrations along the way.

140088436.review:
In Yakuza 3, Kiryu Kazuma returns for more wacky and exciting yakuza adventures. This time he'll.....learn how to be a good father figure? That's right, Kiryu's taking care of an orphanage full of a rag-tag bunch of kids out in Okinawa, when suddenly real estate disputes threaten to shut the whole thing down. Kiryu investigates further to stop all this, only to get rolled back into yakuza affairs when he realizes that this real estate dispute may be a cover for something much more impactful.

Yakuza 3 is rough for sure. Not only coming off the backs of Yakuza 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2, but also just the bangers of Yakuza 1 and 2 in general, this game very often falls flat in delivering that iconic Yakuza experience. Story-wise, as wholesome as it is seeing Kiryu finally form a life outside of the yakuza, it's boring to put it simply. The first third of the game is spent almost entirely dealing with everyday tasks and problems all relating to the kids and the orphanage, and it is rarely entertaining. The story does pick up after a little while, but becomes muddled with how many different parties become involved in these various conflicts that I lost track of who was the antagonist I needed to focus on at any given time. Gameplay-wise it is not great either. Combat is dull and lacks unique moves, with only three different finishers available for boss fights, two of which you have to unlock from side gameplay. Lack of incentive to eat at restaurants to refill health due to easy combat and prevalence of medicinal items. One of the worst skill "trees" I've ever seen in a videogame. Terrible karaoke minigame (this is very important to me). The one notable positive I can think of from Yakuza 3 is that they actually made a gun-wielding boss not frustrating to play against for once, which was a welcome surprise.

A lot of people will say that you have to take everything with a grain of salt, especially if you play these games in chronological order, considering Yakuza 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2 are all stellar games, and the Kiwamis were both remakes as opposed to remasters. They're completely right. That being said, Yakuza 3 is still a really rough game on its own, remaster or not.

I would recommend you play Yakuza 3 if you're really invested in Kiryu Kazuma's story and want to see his arc from start to finish, but otherwise this is a skippable game. 4/10, maybe pick it up on sale for like $8 or less.

139872912.review:
[h1]You have to make it fun yourself[/h1]


The game honestly wasn't as awful as I thought it would be or as bad as some reviews say at least for me. I came in with an open mind after reading some negative and positive reviews and I could say for certain that this one Yakuza entry isn't for everyone, gameplay wise, and story wise. Yakuza 3 Remastered is a really really old game so I would not be comparing it to 0 and the previous Kiwamis. The best way I can put it is that you [b]you have to make it fun yourself[/b]. I'm gonna talk about the positives first and then get to the negatives of each section.


[b]General Things[/b]

I seriously do not get why people are complaining about the graphics, like everyone is saying that this is awful, what??? The cutscene graphics are amazing and the general in game graphics aren't all to impressive but you are overreacting if you say that this is awful it's good for a 2009 game. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing even with what people argue is "the worst in the series" the Yakuza series cannot make a game with a bad soundtrack. For new things, The game has the revelation system like in Yakuza 0 with some QTEs for them but they are learnable instead of story progression which can be bad or good. For the negatives, I would say the movement is pretty awful, you don't have a run for some reason you only jog. Adding to this, A truck load of people walk the streets like their purpose is blocking you and Kiryu flinches so easily that it was pretty irritating to get anywhere. This one should be in combat but this is [b]that[/b] important. The encounters, the encounters with street fights are completely ridiculous, there is no notification whether there is someone coming after you or not, not only that, they also go after you [b]immediately[/b] after they see you. The closest thing you can have to a notification is a voiceline and a small unnoticeable chat bubble. They will stop you in the street give you 3 lines of dialogue, and then fight you. I'm almost certain I have 2 hours of me jogging around the map and getting into almost unavoidable street fights. The progression is pretty awful too, it's basically required to get a certain amount of moves to have fun in the game.


[b]The Infamous Combat[/b]

With positives first I like the fact that I can't mow enemies down with the same attacks over and over again because they  block everything that's the thing that always bothered me about the Yakuza series so far is that it's really easy to defeat the enemies with the same things. The real problem is your options, you don't have any. It's either a weapon from the street or grabbing them if the square-triangle combos don't work. It's such a chore to fight a large crowd especially if there is large/obese enemies mixed with the fast ones, the grabbing system only works if your enemy is doing [b]absolutely nothing[/b] and that is such a huge problem because this Kiryu is already struggling with big crowds with his bare hands now he can barely grab anyone? The damage too, it's extremely garbage you barely do anything to them, on top of playing pretty mediocre with bosses and smaller enemies you barely do anything to them and it's a completely awful experience when you are fighting a boss with a group of smaller enemies. I do like the boss fights, this one is a personal opinion of mine but I really like that they put up more of a fight than Kiwami 2 where I explained it was extremely easy. The combat itself is extremely tedious and arguably boring, but I did have some good fun and entertainment with getting around to their weaknesses and openings.


[b]Story and Gameplay[/b]

With the story, it still follows Kiryu and the problem of The Tojo Clan being in ruins after he left to start an orphanage. The villains were honestly pretty good. The Big Fool Kanda, The smart but broken Mine, And funny English Black Monday guy. I think the villains were okay at least, and the main villain was pretty good but didn't have enough screen time to fully care about him. The kids of Morning Glory (Kiryu's orphanage) were pretty much irrelevant and their identities didn't really matter, but their existence mattered to show in contrast the other side that isn't a beat them up passionate manly man. The only complaint I could have with the story is that they gave the kids more screen time than Mine which is a really bad decision in my part because the main villain was supposed to be this guy you cared for in the end but they didn't give me enough time to understand and to give any care for him. Gameplay wise, it's pretty bad, exploration is a chore and the combat is a chore everything just feels super slow they also make you do these ridiculous searches for items, people and other stuff it felt like a chore every single time. I cannot say a positve that doesn't come from my own interpretation, hence the title [b]you have to make it fun yourself[/b].

[b]Conclusion[/b]

I was expecting it to be bad, but it sort of met my expectations and slightly pass it. Nothing fun comes from this game and even the story without your own interpretations and opinions, so it made sense that people keep saying this is bad because of the justifiable bandwagon saying everything about this game is bad. Personally I found some good fun with it, but you should know that finish this game won't make you say [i]"That was a good game."[/i] you would say to yourself [i]Finally, it's over"[/i] and that says a lot about how much of a chore I felt of this game when I wasn't defending it with an open mind.

5/10 I only played it because I wanted to get through all of the Yakuza games myself and be a fan. I would recommend it if you are doing the same.

139824012.review:
Good, but not great. Give yourself a break between the first three games (0, Kiwami 1, Kiwami 2) and this one, because this is a much older game and while it feels pretty similar to the other games at first glance, you'll start to notice a bunch of small nitpicks that will add up to a bundle of annoyance. 

You're going to have to accept that a significant chunk of this game is an exploration of Kiryu's character and that a bunch of chapters aren't going to be what you might have expected after playing the first few games. It's much slower, and I can see why this game generally gets ranked pretty lowly when people talk about the series as a whole. The combat is also a lot more frustrating, because enemies love to block. Ultimately, for a huge chunk of the game, you're hanging out at an orphanage and dealing with kids and their problems. It's not really as riveting as watching Yakuza argue over territory or whathaveyou. 

There's also the issue of the latter half of the story being a little incomprehensible. I'm not sure if there's something missing in translation or what exactly is going on, but without getting into spoiler territory, a bunch of character's have wacky motivations for their actions and it was a bit difficult to figure out what was going on. 

But I still really did enjoy this game, mainly because the Yakuza series has a great story and the side missions remain incredibly amusing. As much as this game gets a bad reputation for the slowness of the early chapters and one of the later chapters, I genuinely enjoyed watching Kiryu navigate the situations presented in them. I also liked taking breaks from major dramatic story beats to go get drunk at the Hostess Club, or to take Haruka to karaoke while a bunch of people were waiting on us.

139308844.review:
[b]100%ed the game over 75 hours of play.
Just saying that first, before any basement goblins try to come along pretending they know more about it than me.[/b]

[i]Yakuza 3! The behated, the infamous! The jump to the 7th console generation, with the worst development cycle in the entire series!
[b]And it shows![/b][/i]

It's the third game in the series, released back in the year of our lord 2009 for the PS3. If you're this far into the series you've probably played the previous games so I don't need to give you a summary of what these games are like. If you're new just stop reading this and go play Zero.


[i]All good? All good.[/i]
Everything you've heard about this game's combat. It's true. But it's not even my main gripe with this game. I'll get into the other stuff later, because somehow [b]EVERYTHING this game does, it does wrong[/b].

Yes, it's slow and stiff.
Yes, you deal literal single-digit pixels of damage with every attack. No damage upgrades ever.
Yes, bosses have added resistance to weapons and heat actions, just to waste your time.
Yes, enemies block everything you throw at them from the front. Two thirds of the enemy types (there's a grand total of three) either resist or counter your grabs.
Yes, [i]"dashing around to hit them from the back"[/i] is not even remotely a thing with this game's pathetic-ass dash that moves one millimeter.
Yes, you need to grind your ass off to even make Kiryu remotely playable by the time you're 2/3 done with the game. Your combos aren't even true combos until you have every "combo speed" upgrade at your disposal so you can keep a single chain going without an enemy casually walking out of it.


[b]The combat engine in itself is entirely busted.[/b]
Hitboxes are the most inconsistent in the whole series.
Grabs go through enemies if there's even the slightest height difference (inclines, stairways), grabs also go through enemies if they're in any kind of attack state.
Heat action requirements are INCREDIBLY picky, and generally require enemies to be at a complete standstill, giving you only a frame or two to trigger them before that enemy's AI decides to do whatever else it feels like doing (usually dashing out of your way or otherwise moving out of range to be defensive and waste your time, because they HATE being aggressive in any way, so you're never even in any danger of dying, outside of dying of boredom).

You've heard all of this before if you've seen anyone talk about this game, it's nothing new. We know.



I would like to talk about this game's STORY though, because it is genuinely insane to me that any deranged person can go out and pretend that it's anything close to good, let alone "one of the best in the series".

[spoiler]This entire game is filler. The entire game is pointless. It starts by hitting you in the nuts with 6 hours of ORPHANAGE FILLER. Then it hits you with THREE MORE HOURS by chapter 10. 9 out of my 19 hours of playthrough, with minimum side content done. Literally almost half of this game is filler.
And the story itself doesn't have much better to say for itself.

The whole story gets kickstarted by a generic [i]"ooooooo evil business wants to demolish the POOR ORPHANAGE to build a BIG BUSINESS RESORT, THINK OF THE CHILDREEEEN"[/i].
It's the cheapest way to try and gain your sympathy.
Also children in my Yakuza. [b]Get out.[/b] Haruka's terrible enough on her own.

Sayama gets unceremoniously removed from the series, axing all her development from the second game. Sure, whatever.

The two main villains of the game do not interact with the main character until the tail end of the game. Richardson is Jingu 2.0, as if the original wasn't a bad enough villain. And Mine's entire motivation literally boils down to [i]"I'm lonely and have no friends :("[/i].

The other three main villains get ZERO development, and are simply evil for the sake of being evil (you could replace them with cardboard cutouts and it would make no difference). They also get unceremoniously removed from the plot without your involvement. Two of them offscreen.


Yakuza 2 EXPLICITLY avoids the shitty trope the first game had, of leaving a bad guy alive next to a gun just so they can kill off a good guy.
Daigo just shoots Shindo before he can get any funny ideas.
You know what this game does with that writing development?
They roll the whole thing back!
They have this dumb babby Yakuza in the form of Rikiya who instantly falls in love with you, starts following you around, and gets killed off suddenly by a bad guy Kiryu knocked out and left next to a gun!
And it leads to the worst, most overacted, most unwarranted death scene in the franchise!
This [b]sucks[/b]!


The game sets up the "OOOOO KAZAMA MYSTERYYYYYYYYY" at the very start just to hit you with the 6 hours of orphanage filler, only for the whole subplot to go nowhere by the time you get to it.
You just find out that the "Kazama" you see in this game is actually the [b]EEEEVIL AMERICAN TWIN BROOOOTHER OF KAZAMA THAT WORKS FOR THE CIAAAA[/b]. The literal, single, most terrible, Hollywood-ass way they could have taken this subplot. A literal """uncle""" that Kiryu never found out about, that just happens to be a bad guy here.

You fight him ONCE. There's no emotional payoff for any of it. He has a change of heart, gives you a plane to move between towns quicker, and promptly disappears from the franchise.


Not to mention how stupid and gringo-pander-y the entire American/CIA story is to begin with, or how much of a non-character Richardson is. Or how Black Monday (the organization he runs) is literally introduced to you near the end in one of the two FOURTY-MINUTE EXPOSITION TEXT DUMPS that the main story forces on you.

This entire plot is an active insult to the intelligence of anyone that plays this game. It's easily the worst-paced plot in any game I've played, and I've played some CRAP, alright.
[i]It's the most garbage story this series has ever, at any point, had, somehow finding a way to combine the worst tropes from both anime and Hollywood and playing them completely straight, expecting you to care.[/i]

Also, THE knife scene.

I cannot believe anyone would in good faith like a story this abjectly terrible, outside of being blinded by the nostalgia of having the misfortune of playing this... THING as a child.[/spoiler]

Needless to say I was mentally tuning out by the end from boredom.
Immediately forgot most of the character names as soon as they were unceremoniously removed from the plot, too. That's how unmemorable everyone in this game is.


The music's nothing to write home about, either. JUST finishing the game, I remember... two or three songs at most. Anything that isn't generic ambience is just generic Yakuza "rock" themes that are like four notes in total and have no memorable melodies to them.


Easily one of the quickest ALT+F4+Uninstalls I've done, soon as I was done 100%ing to avoid the blemish in my series 100% journey. Minigames and side content were the most bloated and miserable in the entire series BTW. 119 bland substories, censored/removed content notwithstanding.


I was THIS close to waiting for a Kiwami 3 after seeing the bad reputation this game had. But caved in and bought the remaster pack. [i]And it was the right choice.[/i]
This game does NOT deserve a remake. It does NOT deserve a Kiwami 3.
And if I had waited for something like that to happen, I would have simply never got around to playing the rest of the series.
Ripping the bandaid off now so I can play the games after and actually have anything [i]resembling[/i] a good time was the best choice here.


[b]Unironically, skip this game. Every single aspect of it is irredeemable in every way. Even the PLOT is completely inconsequential, to the point where you'd be getting the gist of it from seeing a plot summary on YouTube. Or just looking up who dies.[/b]

Fans of this game are actual insane toxic gatekeepers too. Stay away from them.

138918492.review:
Back in 2009, [I]Yakuza 3[/I] was a huge step forward for the [I]Yakuza[/I] game series in terms of gameplay and graphics. It’s the first main series game to feature a controllable game camera for the adventure portion, and to introduce more elaborate side content that would become synonymous with [I]Yakuza[/I] games. Visually, the power of the PlayStation 3 allowed major characters to be depicted with greater detail and realism, cementing their iconic designs. These advancements laid the technical and stylistic foundation for future [I]Yakuza[/I] titles in the main and spin-off series.

The technical and stylistic similarities between [I]Y3[/I] and future [I]Yakuza[/I] games meant it didn’t require the major overhaul that [I]Yakuza 1[/I] and [I]Yakuza 2[/I] needed in bringing it over to modern platforms. It’s therefore understandable that developers at Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio decided to remaster [I]Y3[/I] than to remake it, especially when they were also working on [I]Judgment[/I] and [I]Yakuza: Like a Dragon[/I], as well as remastering [I]Yakuza 4[/I] and [I]5[/I] around the same time.

Sadly, [I]Y3R[/I] is not a great remaster, in part because of the uneven remastering workmanship. The flaws of [I]Y3[/I], on the heels of the superb [I]Yakuza 0[/I] and the excellent [I]Yakuza Kiwami[/I] and [I]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/I], were also amplified in comparison and with time. What we ended up with is a game that showed us that [I]Y3[/I] should have been remade – that is given the [I]Kiwami[/I] treatment – instead of remastered.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2980100332
[H1]Graphics & Framerate Issues[/H1]
[I]Y3R[/I] is a decent looking game on modern platforms. While it’s obvious that the character models have fewer polygons than those in more recent games, they look good enough even when upscaled to 1080p from the original 720p resolution. However, some textures, such as those for male hands, still appear low-res. In-game cinematic sequences also look decent, but pre-rendered cutscenes were simply resized from 720p without any additional image sharpening or colour adjustments done. The contrast between in-game and pre-rendered visuals is quite jarring, making [I]Y3R[/I] look unpolished.

The visual inconsistencies could be forgiven if the gameplay is solid. Unfortunately, [I]Y3R[/I] is a bit of mess under the hood. Although the PC version can run at framerates higher than 60 fps, it’s not fully optimized for it. A few minigames (e.g., fishing, massage parlour) are actually harder to play if they’re run at above the original 30 fps cap. I suppose you can play [I]Y3R[/I] at 30 fps at the expense of smoothness in graphics, but that would defeat the point of playing a game that was specifically and supposedly refurbished for modern systems.

[H1]Semi-Broken Combat[/H1]
The inherent framerate issue also affects combat, which is the core of [I]Yakuza[/I] games. For some reason, basic quickstepping doesn’t put adequate distance between you and your enemy, making the technique rather useless until you’ve upgraded it. Quickstepping behind your enemies so you can strike them from behind is also difficult to pull off at above 30 fps. These are flaws that should have been detected and fixed during the remaster, and not doing so only made [I]Y3R[/I] feel like an unfinished product.

Yet, two of the biggest problems with combat in [I]Y3R[/I] (reportedly carried over from [I]Y3[/I]) are enemies blocking attacks too often and swarming you in all directions at the same time. I guess these are meant to add a touch of realism to the game, but they don’t make it fun. These become a major problem when you try to build up Heat for special moves and takedowns. You can’t build up Heat when enemies are blocking, and Heat also depletes if you get hit or if you’re idle. Downing a couple of Tauriner or Staminan drinks is a quick workaround, but even with sufficient Heat, timing your Heat Action execution can be tricky – again, possibly due to framerate issues. It’s often frustrating, and I did finish the game at normal difficulty by learning to circumvent this semi-broken combat system. But, it shouldn’t have been this way.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2980100030
[H1]Story: Gem in a Bloated Mess[/H1]
[I]Y3[/I] was originally the third part of Kiryu’s story, with him now running an orphanage in Okinawa. On the surface, it’s a tale of Kiryu going up against the yakuza who wants to seize the land on which the orphanage sits. At its core, it’s about vulnerable and abandoned people looking for love, support and acceptance. In fact, the first third of [I]Y3R[/I] focuses on Kiryu being father figure to the orphans he is looking after. It’s actually a refreshing change of pace in line with Kiryu’s post-yakuza life. It’s not until Chapter 5 of 12 that he returns to Kamurocho to take care of business.

Unfortunately, outlandish plot devices and set pieces muddle the otherwise awesome story of one man versus the yakuza to protect the children he cares about. Although [I]Yakuza (Kiwami)[/I] and [I]Yakuza (Kiwami) 2[/I] are bizarre and incredible in their own ways, [I]Y3/Y3R[/I] dials the absurdity up to eleven[SPOILER]by adding a doppelganger plot twist, the CIA, international arms dealers, a sexagenarian flipping a bull, and stealth fighter jet commutes to name a few to the plot[/SPOILER], so much so that it’s more like a story dreamed up by prepubescent boys, with story beats clearly taken from prominent films, including a couple by Francis Ford Coppola.

The story’s pacing is also very uneven, necessitating in dedicating a whole chapter three-quarters into the game for exposition by a single character to explain the convoluted plot. Instead of revealing the main antagonist’s motivation bit by bit throughout the game, it has him describe it in full prior to the final showdown. The ending feels like a quick fix for a major plot hole, and any tension and significance it might have had is then quickly resolved with a post-credit scene. It’s such a mess that I feel [I]Y0[/I], [I]YK[/I] and [I]YK2[/I] form a better, more complete story arc for Kiryu than [I]Y(K)[/I], [I]Y(K)2[/I] and [I]Y3/Y3R[/I].

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2980099225
[H1]Final Thoughts: A “Kiwamissed” Opportunity[/H1]
[I]Y3[/I] might have been good back in the day, but in the decade that followed, many innovations and refinements have been made to this game franchise’s gameplay and graphics. Remastering [I]Y3[/I] without fixing flaws that negatively affect the original gameplay, and without doing a thorough job in upscaling the graphics is simply inadequate for a title that follows the [I]Y0[/I], [I]YK[/I] and [I]YK2[/I]. No wonder [I]Y3R[/I] feels dated, unpolished and incomplete.

Considering [I]Y3[/I] was a pivotal title for the game series, it deserved better. But, I get why RGG Studio and SEGA didn’t give [I]Y3[/I] the [I]Kiwami[/I] treatment: it made no sense for them to spend time and money on recreating assets that won’t be used in future titles. After all, [I]Yakuza[/I] games are lower-budget titles made to look like AAA games. But as a result, [I]Y3/Y3R[/I] is now seen as the worst game in the series for the wrong reasons.

A properly made remaster could have salvaged [I]Y3[/I]’s reputation, even with the absurd plot elements that didn’t age well. At the end of the day, [I]Yakuza[/I] completionists would buy this game – likely as part of the [I]Yakuza Remastered Collection[/I] – regardless of its quality. I may give it a thumbs down in this review, but I think at the very least it’s worth playing the first few chapters to see Kiryu’s gentler, loving side that contrasts his Dragon of Dojima persona. It’s really too bad that the rest of the game couldn’t be as straightforward as Kiryu’s life in Okinawa, but instead become more unnecessarily complicated, much like his time in Kamurocho.

138750632.review:
If you're here reading this, chances are you're probably on the journey of playing through this series in chronological order. There's not really any other point in playing through this. If that is you and have started with Zero, well, this is not that.

[b]Combat:[/b] As others have pointed out, the combat is slow and can be very frustrating. Finding Komaki and his training is not optional - it's fundamental. With that, it gets a little more enjoyable, but you'll likley need to put in some hours until I got used to it. Bosses can be challenging. Random encounters are one of the most tiresome and annoying parts of the game, since they're inescapable, they take a long time and you can also just spot the guy waiting to kick you on the street, so most times it felt like I was just running away from them, hoping they wouldn't see or catch me.

[b]Story:[/b] I have mixed feelings here. You're probably used to it by now, but Yakuza continues its tradition of being overly cryptic and complex and introducing way too many characters than it has time to explore. That said, I found the story to be better than that of 2. Yes, that's right. It starts slowly at first, but then it just goes all over the place and by the end it feels like you're not actually justified in doing anything else apart from the story missions due to how urgent they feel. I'd say it was worth it though.
Aside from Kamurocho, you also get to experience Okinawa which was really chill and enjoyable and had the distinct feeling of being a different place.

[b]Substories:[/b] Way too many. A lot of fat that gets in the way. There are some notable highlights that are really good and/or explore main characters. There is also one that's a murder mystery and feels like the prototype for what would later be Judgement. I recommend those but the problem is that you have to dig through some very boring ones to find them. And the hostesses, once again, get in the way of completing everything. Idk, I just didn't enjoy them at all.

[b]Minigames:[/b] Yea nah. Overly difficult. Don't even get me started on the cabaret minigame here - even with a guide I just couldn't get anything to work. Some people may enjoy them, but I've always found minigames to be unnecessarily challenging and grindy.
There's also an odd reliance on modding weapons and finding or purchasing catalogues and items to combine and enhance weapons. I didn't get it, personally - and I didn't find it useful in any way.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] It's hard to play this in the current era of gaming where there's better out there, but if you're here to experience Kiryu's third chapter, then I'd recommend it for the story if nothing else. If it gets too tedious, try Easy difficulty and don't worry too much about the side content.

138738584.review:
Kiryu is an old man and no longer sprints in his day to day life. 

Prepare to jog everywhere, because unless you're chasing down someone or running away from someone, 


Outside of the story and the karaoke, Yakuza 3 Remastered is mostly enjoyable, but at times, it's very frustrating with the lack of quality of life features, combat, and mini-game polish the previous games had.

Combat is OK if you're facing your stock standard enemies, but I've never faced so many enemies that block for days, and some that dodge quickstep for days, so your best option is to grab and to throw them, or wait for them to attack you and you try to parry them. Sometimes boss fights will refuse to allow you to continue fighting for an extended period of time and continually stun you or keep you down. This game really limited your options in terms of combos and fighting styles, and the ability tree is more or less non-existent. I don't care too much about the combat in comparison to others, but I'm sure the combat system hurts replay value.

That being said, the story is good as always. While I have some issues with pacing (especially when the main plot really gets going, it slows to a crawl and drags unnecessarily with the orphanage kids. As much as I like the orphanage kids, the story structure definitely needed a little shuffling. I liked most of the new characters, and a lot of the character development is quite rushed. Standouts were Rikiya and Mine, but Mine's character development is rushed. And as always, every now and then, Yakuza 3 manages to get a laugh from me every now and then. Revelations in particular, was great, and I hope to see more of that in the other installments. 

Unfortunately, the minigames are nowhere near as good as the others. Karaoke and talking to hostesses are the two exceptions. 

Hostess Maker is monotonous and boring. Dressing up is awful when you realise that there's only one combination to make your hostess as good as she can look, and there's only one bland route to optimise your training sessions/breaks with her. The grind is tedious, and none of the girls are distinct enough for me to grow attached to any of them. It's frustrating to walk around at a snails pace to see my hostess lifelessly feeding a grown man a piece of fruit. 

Aroma Massage is nothing to write home about, but at least it's funny in concept. 

Batting is alright, Bowling has some weird physics; sometimes the game refuses to give you a strike when in other games, you absolutely would have gotten it. Darts and Billiards are extremely frustrating in this game until you look up a walkthrough (and even then Darts is still not really fun if you're looking at anywhere except a triple 20 or a bullseye). Fishing is the most frustrating and tedious trying to catch a stupid bloody tuna. Golf is really infuriating trying to put the ball away. 

There are also a few smaller quality of life features that I miss from other games such as knowing how much health a particular food item or drink restores, but it's not that important.

I recommend Yakuza 3 Remastered if you're a Yakuza fan, but just be prepared that it's not refined as the rest in terms of core gameplay and minigames. 7/10.

*I've played Yakuza 0, Kiwami 1 and 2 at time of review.

138527778.review:
Ah, the black sheep of the series. With even the most common street thugs blocking pretty often, the pacing being an issue for some (very slow at the start, then picks up on Chapter 5 only to slam into a wall on 10, then picking up again to wrap up the last 2 chapters), and bosses having a bit too much damage reduction - especially on the harder difficulties - it's understandable why some might become disappointed with this game, especially if they moved on from the Kiwamis. However, I wouldn't say that this is a terrible game by any means.

I honestly didn't mind the the slow pacing for the first half of the game, especially since it allowed the game to have the caring side of Kiryu on full display, a stark contrast from the rugged badass we knew him as in the previous games. That being said, it did make my Legend playthrough quite a slog, even with me running NG+, so it's especially hard to recommend a subsequent playthrough for this one.

I haven't really talked much about the antagonists when reviewing the previous games, but Mine in this game is actually one of my favorite villains in the series, being a complex and tragic character who can be terrifying when he snaps out of his calm and composed state, not to mention he steals the show whenever he's on screen, with a rather intimidating presence.

To my surprise, there isn't an achievement for completing everything on the Completion List like with the previous games, but there's one for completing all minigames, which is usually the hardest part, so it was pretty much the same to me. If there's any chance you changed the controller configuration to have the right stick only register vertical movement due to pool, I don't blame you for doing so at all.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend getting this on a sale if you can, but play through it at least once, even if for the story or just out of curiosity.

138448364.review:
Yakuza 3 is a weird game to recommend, not because its bad, but becaise its tecnically the oldest of the franchise available to play.

If you played this right after finishing 0 to Kiwami 2, you will notice how mechanically dated the gameplay feels, since most of the quality of life improvements still have to happen and the gameplay feels stiff and simple.

Kiryu moveset is very basic and pretty much every goon can be dealt with button mashing. The combat lacks the stance system from 0 and Kiwami and lacks the dynamic system from Kiwami 2 to become interesting.
Punches lack weight and you are mostly repeating the same 4 combos over and over and over.
It can still have a few satisfying moments, but you will want to go back to the other games.

Bosses on the other hand are annoying since they mostly play the same: block every attack, immunity to throws, can attack immediately after blocking and usually have a counter attack that always hits you before you can dodge or counter.
As soon you get Tiger Drop, most bosses turn into a joke. Punch them twice so they counter, then Tiger Drop.

There is still a bunch of minigames scattered, but there is little to no reason to do them. Kiryu also moves at a fast walk at most, so getting around gets a bit annoying, even worse that enemies can't be seen on the minimap and instead stay still on several spots around the map, so avoiding fights is a pain since you have to go into other streets since most places are far too tight for you to maneuver.

The Hostess minigame makes a return, or better yet, its debut. Its very rough, boring and takes a lot of time for almost no payoff.
All you do is go back and forth two rooms about three times, just paying attention on 3 lines of dialogue and then changing the hostess clothes a bit. It gets boring really fast.

Talking about the minimap, some substories don't show at all until you stumble upon them. I have found a few of them during the last chapter because I never had to enter most buildings.

The story is ok. Not bad, but nothing to write about, there is some plot and twists to keep you invested, but overall it feels rather weak after 2.
Characters come and go, deaths seem to happen only so there is some drama and eventually the plot barely matters at the end. Even the twist they do right at the end gets resolved post credits, so there was no point.
The story feels pretty short, since half of it is Kiryu taking care of his kids.

The 60fps improvement of the remaster also brought a few problems, since a few things were tied to frame rate, the quickstep distance is halved and button prompts require you to mash way too fast, causing some counters to be basically impossible and the "Feel the heat" moments not charging fast enough.
Some mods are available to fix the quickstep problem at least.

Music is still very good, "D 2 A" was so out of place that it became one of my favorite songs of the franchise. There is no song at "Receive you the madtype" levels, but that one is on a tier of its own.

Overall, not a bad game like I said, but the wrinkles of time are very apparent on this game and unless you keep in mind that this is basically the mecanically oldest game in Steam, it will feel like a letdown.

138321860.review:
Spoiler-free and long review:

As someone who is relatively new to the Yakuza series and who has started getting into it through Yakuza 0, Yakuza 3 Remastered feels different from the previous games due to the Kiwami-treatement of Yakuza 1 and 2. This can be good or bad depending on who you ask, but personally, there are aspects to this game that felt new and groundbreaking and there are some aspects that felt annoying and boring. When it comes to the review, I have to point all the good and bad points of Yakuza 3 so that its easy for you to understand. 

The Good:

As some other reviewers have mentioned, Yakuza 3 is a substantial improvement from the original Yakuza 1 and 2 games, making the shift to the Yakuza 3 a lot easier for most of the players who have played previous polished games of Yakuza 0, Kiwami and Kiwami 2. The combat is easy to adapt to, albeit not diverse, the inventory shenanigans are the same as they were in 0 and Kiwami (although you have to share your item slots with gear and weapons), the heat actions still feel visceral and Kiryu still kills people with his spectacular karaoke. Some of the places in the Yakuza 3 Remastered can be stunning, some of the characters introduced in this game can be unforgettable and some of the new mechanics to weapon building and heat actions are fun.

The plot is intriguing when compared to the previous Yakuza games and I know that many people don't really like the pace change that they did in this game, but personally, it feels great to finally see Kiryu spending some time being a dad instead of constantly being involved throughout the story in some sort of drama with either Kiryu's family and friends or with some sort of international mafia that is constantly a threat. It allows for players to experience a more peaceful and dad-like life of Kiryu. To add to all of this, newly introduced characters go through great character developments that makes you cheer for them whilst the antagonists in this game, except for couple, feel humane and relatable as you can understand where they are coming from and why they are doing the things they do in the story. So overall, it's still a Yakuza game, but with a different pace of portraying the story. 

The substories in this game remain the same, at times great entertainment, at others a chore. Certain substories have cutscenes and some of them help the player to get closer to some of the new characters, which is great as there have been so many additions and deletions of characters in the series thus far that you can become numb to some of the new additions. 

The new mechanics that they added into this game, and later into the series, with Revelations, additional Heat Actions, IF7, and Hitman missions are actually fun. Whilst it is not necessary for you to complete and collect all of them, I highly recommend doing at the very minimum Revelations as those are great entertainment and provide great Heat Actions and Finishing moves that will help you immensely in the story. Very easy to understand where to go and they do not feel like a chore! IF7 is a cool idea, where you can re-engage previous battle fights and get upgrades or ingredients. Hitman missions are a neat idea and are easy way to get money and fight unique mini-bosses.

Talk about minor details, I genuinely think that this is the second game where I actually love the entire OST in Yakuza series thus far, Yakuza 0 being the first. Every single track feels fun, blood-pumping, stressful or emotional. Fly, Pure Malice, Sound's Storm, Receive and Stab You, D2A, and other songs are unique and unforgettable, making some of the fights actually feel inspiring and fun. 

Last, but not least, KARAOKE. I think that this is the first Yakuza game that I have played so far that allows you to reminiscence some of the animated moments of karaoke, even those when you sing with friends or hostesses. I think it is a neat idea as sometimes you just want to listen to and enjoy the song without having to sweat on the QTE. 

The Bad:

Oh boy. As you most probably have heard, the fights and encounters in this game, while might feel great at times, are not as fun due to uncanny amount of blocking. You are either forced to constantly grab enemies and send them flying, counter attack, or have items that can allow you to bypass their blocking (sharp items such as knifes on enemies with no weapons or guns). This sucks as it does not feel as great to fight as it usually is in any other Yakuza game. The only fights that actually feel fair and fun to fight are only by the end of the game as those bosses either don't block or are susceptible to block breaks. 

In regards to the plot and characters, it's the same old Yakuza. Some of the moments in the story can be genuinely dumbfounding and some characters are just boring and undeveloped. Kiryu in this game feels more isolated in his own agenda, which is sometimes nice but at the same time infuriating, when you progress through the story. To add to that, the entire removal of previously established characters and their connections with Kiryu in the previous games also questions as to why writers have completely forgotten or have changed the narration entirely, as it downplays important events that happened in the already established storyline. 

The game has its usual high amount of minigames that everyone love and expect to see from the previous corresponding games of Yakuza, but has outdated mechanics to them that feel sometimes more difficult than they ever were in other Yakuza games. Some of these, especially batting center's Extra Hard, Golf's Competition Completion with a score of -5 and Pool's Broken AI can be very challenging and soul-consuming if you are going for the 100% achievements in this game. Probably one of the most frustrating achievements I had to deal with in a while as the last time I felt this frustrated at my time wasted would have to be at Yakuza 0. To add to that, I have no clue as to why they added one of the worst minigames in the entire series, Hostess-making. It feels confusing as the game does not tell you the crucial information you need, so you have to use Google to find the most optimized way of completing or even playing this minigame. I had to play this minigame for a quite bit for the achievements and it felt like I was wasting time. I understand that not a lot of people are here for the 100%, but I believe that even if you are going to play for the entertainment value, you will not get a lot of fun out of these minigames, unfortunately.

Getting to Amon fight and the fight itself are disappointing. As mentioned, you have to date hostesses to unlock substories and have to complete certain hard levels in some of the aforementioned outdated minigames to get to the substory completion, which sucks. The Amon fight itself was boring as he uses same fighting styles as some of the bosses in the story, making it easy to win against as he is probably the weakest Amon in the series.

Conclusion:

Overall, for anybody who has been enjoying the Yakuza series so far, you should try this game out. It has a different pace from the rest of the Yakuza games I have played thus far, and it feels great. The addition of a new city, Ryukyu, the OST, and some of the new characters make it worth playing at least once. On the other hand, poor mechanics of enemy blocking, minigames and some sidequests are the most disappointing parts of this game and can be by themselves a put off for many people. Whilst I enjoyed this game despite its flaws, my recommendation for casual enjoyment would have to be play it for the story and not for the side-activities!

I apologize for any mistakes here as it is my first time writing a review, so I hope this helps!

137029380.review:
Yakuza 3 is a difficult game to evaluate. The mainline Yakuza series is now up to eight entries; ask people to rank all the titles, and most will put Yakuza 3 at the bottom (while noting that the worst Yakuza game is still a solid game on its own terms). I think this is fair, and yet simultaneously, I think this is one of the most important and visionary Yakuza titles, and will only get shortchanged by modern audiences because of the Kiwami remakes. Let me explain.

The first two Yakuza games were an ambitious attempt to combine a Shenmue-style dense, simulated world with low-brow brawling and a serious, melodramatic Yakuza story ripped straight from Japanese cinema. The fact that they were obviously stitched together from these disparate parts was part of their charm, but the underlying technology couldn’t fully support the vision; Shenmue was able to make its detailed world on the Dreamcast only through a truly stupendous outlay of time and money and clever use of the Dreamcast hardware. Yakuza had a budget the fraction of the size and was forced to work with the difficult-to-program PS2. The end result is more of a zoomed-out brawler playground that a richly detailed slice of Tokyo.

Yakuza 3 changes this. It returns to the exact same location—the semi-fictional red light district of Kamurocho—but renders it in lush detail (as well as the new secondary location of Okinawa—more on that in a sec). A first-person camera is implemented, and used in a few game modes, but is really there just to show off the detail. The pacing is tremendously improved by allowing battles and exploration to seamlessly blend, without the traditional black loading screen; a wider array of minigames are implemented, bringing the total up to 20. These changes would carry through to every subsequent game in the series, and ultimately be “backported” to its predecessors via the full remakes of Yakuza Kiwami 1 and 2.

This means that someone who started the Yakuza series today, playing the games in chronological order starting with Yakuza 0 and working their way through the Kiwamis before hitting Yakuza 3, would find Yakuza 3 a substantial step backwards; the “remasterings” of Yakuza 3–5 are simply HD ports with redone localization, and so are a substantial graphical downgrade 0/Kiwami. Without the freshness and awe of its advances, Yakuza 3 can feel like a filler Yakuza game, a final spin of the wheels before the series realizes it needs to start changing to avoid becoming stale.

But I have a fondness for Yakuza 3 even coming off Kiwami, and that’s almost solely due to the brave, divisive turn it takes with its story. One of the most common tropes of the “honorable criminal” is the criminal who leaves the life of crime behind to Do Good, but then gets Pulled Back In because somebody wants to make a sequel. Yakuza 2 already pulled this trick, and at the end of that protagonist Kiryu went “okay, for real this time, I’m running an orphanage on Okinawa and not beating up any more dudes.” You’d expect Yakuza 3 to find some flimsy excuse to reverse this off the bat once again, but it doesn't; the game spends an extended period of time with Kiryu fully in Orphanage Dad mode, helping take care of kids and dealing with the occasional financial or local crime issue.

I love this; Kiryu’s always at his best when his natural warmth is allowed to shine, and I bluntly didn’t take enough of a break between this and previous Yakuza titles, so the variety was welcome. A lot of players felt that this isn’t what they signed up for, that the Okinawa segment was a series of pointless sidequests and character moments divorced from the larger stakes of the series. And yeah, if you’re here solely to see more Elaborate Yakuza Opera, you’re going to be disappointed with the game’s first half.

I felt the opposite; eventually, Kiryu is pulled back in and goes to Kamarucho, and while I appreciate that the game took the time to ‘earn’ this and it felt consistent with Kiryu’s character, the actual story and gameplay is a forgettable retread; I can barely remember the plot writing this, and what I do remember is mostly just a variation on things we’ve seen in the first two. The villain in particular, while a notable attempt at making a more intellectual antagonist for Kiryu, is at the end of the day a thinly-written finance criminal.

The developers clearly realized that they were getting into a rut; Yakuza 4 substantially shook up the series and it never looked back. But I wouldn’t skip Yakuza 3; some of the best character moments in the entire series are found with the children of the Sunflower Orphanage.

136939939.review:
Coming from Kiwami 2, adjusting to the aging Yakuza 3 is something of a tall order. From the dated visuals, to the frustrating combat, even the rudimentary side activities, Yakuza 3 is by far the worst gameplay experience in the overall series by 2023 standards.

With that said, Yakuza 3 has one of the more interesting stories in the overall series, offers added variety with the setting of Okinawa, has a banging soundtrack and, most crucially of all, has the batsh*t lunacy the series is beloved for in spades.

If you can endure the rough edges, Yakuza 3 has plenty to love and is well worth your time. But if you're coming straight from Kiwami 2... it's going to be a bumpy ride.

TECHNICAL / PORT: Port is solid. Locked to 60FPS but holds this consistently. Has a good range of visual options considering it's a 14 year old PS3 game, but beyond simple things such as button prompts for Xbox controllers, this port uses the same assets as the PS3 version. The game has aged decently, though the lower detail textures and lower poly models are glaringly obvious. The texture work here is excellent despite the lower fidelity though which prevents the game from looking muddy or blurry. Uses a deferred renderer so lacks support for MSAA, but offers CMAA (or FXAA if you hate your eyes) as well as increased render scaling and FidelityFX CAS. I noted frametiming seemed a little off with the built in vsync though this wasn't noticable in gameplay. All the same, disabling vsync ingame and forcing 'Adaptive' vsync via the nvidia control panel smoothed this out. I experienced no crashes, glitches or other issues during my playthrough.

RE COMBAT DIFFICULTY: I played this through on Hard. It sucked. Y3 is 5x harder than YK2 on hard, and this largely comes down to how the combat functions here. From what I can tell online, even Normal difficulty can be quite rough, Hard is just worse. From my playthrough, here's a few observations and recommendations to help smooth out the journey. First of all, the hardest boss fights in the game are earlier ones, notably Tamashiro and the two back-to-back boss fights you endure once arriving in Kamurocho. I recommend engaging with as much side content as possible to generate exp, healing items, weapons and money. The coin lockers are your friend. In Y3, some coin locker keys can only be obtained in first person mode, so if you see one you can't reach, try this. For these first few difficult fights, stock up on strong weapons and recovery items and save them for the actual boss encounters. Get in the habit of eating at restaurants to restore your health as this will generate exp - not a lot mind you, but it adds up. Once you're able to begin Komaki's training, make this your priority and master the Komaki Parry - this is done by being in combat stance (RB) and pressing grab (B) just as an enemy attacks. The timing for this is very tight, so this may take practice, but once you lock it down, this is the single best move in the entire game. You can also buy a sword from the Dragon's Palace which is one of the strongest weapons in the game - obtain this and save it for boss encounters. It's expensive to buy (using chips) and just as expensive to repair, so I recommend getting the various items that essentially allow you to cheat in the casino and use your winnings to buy the sword and generate a ton of cash. A Zero Jewel can generate roughly 3.5m yen in a single game of roulette if you're willing to save scum on a 50/50 chance, or half as much as a safe bet. Things will get much easier from here on. Some boss fights like Lau Ka Long render weapons largely ineffective and will require good use of the Komaki Parry to get through smoothly. The final boss on the other hand is easily torn apart by that sword you bought earlier. Good luck, and have fun!

136449337.review:
Technically the oldest Yakuza game you can still buy, so going to this from Kiwami 2 feels very jarring. 

Combat is slow and clunky, the graphics look like dogwater, the minigames feel rough at times, substories are abundant yet uninteresting, and the game is unwieldy even down to minor things like only being able to buy one food item at a time and random encounters having their own, deliberate, slow dialogue.

The story is really good, and its a slow one that takes a backseat for the first half of the game. It’s a calm slice-of-life story that slowly devolves into a crime thriller and another ploy to save the Tojo Clan.

After playing through the series, I still adore this one the most, especially when you consider it’s essentially a prototype of sorts. You can see what RGG (or CS1) were attempting to do here, and its a valiant effort. 

The remaster is naturally the best way to play, with tons more content making an appearance after being cut from the original Western release. The PC port suffers from some issues that are fixable through SilentPatch, such as high CPU usage, and demands AVX and SSE instructions weirdly enough despite its age. It’s still stellar, and its great seeing the series on PC.

136190374.review:
Yakuza 3 remastered is fine but not as good as the earlier re-releases. The remaster has given it a face lift but the underlying game play feels a bit long in tooth. It shares similar systems with the previous kiwami and yakuza zero but in certain aspects make it feel slower. Kiryu's running speed, for example, is variable sometimes its fine, other times its like watching a man run with weights under water. Chapters can be ridiculously short (eg go here beat up this guy) or padded in length (eg you need to track this person down and time is crucial, oh hey boss, I'm new to this town can you show me around?). In fact the game starts in media res then flashbacks but by the time I get to the section leading to this point I was confused because I had forgotten how it started. Side quests attempt to liven up the world but creates a somewhat limited world experience as outside of side quests the npcs are pretty wooden. While I was heavily engaged in the kiwami and zero, yakuza 3 doesn't pull me in the same way. Several of the early chapters are rather mundane. The focus is on the day to day life at the orphanage which is meant to create an affectionate air around the children but feels slow and bloated. It tries to spice up the average day of an orphanage director with mystery and story twists that rather feel like a soap opera. The main character runs the orphanage and takes care of the kids - sort of. Interaction with them can be a little inconsistent. I was asked to buy a copy of the in-game version of Shonen Jump by one kid and when I returned home he never asked for it and my character never gave it to him. It felt like I should have taken an extra trip just to hand him the comic magazine if I wanted that task resolved which is bizarre because the trip only took a few days and the magazine wouldn't be out for weeks which is why it was requested in the first place.
Combat is serviceable but not quite as fun as the revamped earlier editions. It feels basic with a lot of later enemies blocking - a lot. There are mods that improve it but playing stock port is less fun compared to zero, kiwami 1 or 2. My advice hit the weapon store before the final chapters and buy guns. Lots and lots of guns. On the flip side, you can still pull off a decent amount of sidestepping counters and power attacks with a bit of timing on bosses. Skill gain appears to be a one way street. You gain skills as you upgrade for experience and choose which skill as you go up. However once picked there doesn't appear to be an option to get the other skill.  Inventory management is less forgiving and it's still ok but it's not as good as the others that were re-done before it. There are still quick time combat events which did happen in previous fights but feel so much more pervasive in this one. Some of the button mashing events being the most annoying.
Another annoying part of the game is the psuedo option. It pretends to give you a choice but it either forcibly tells you to pick the other one or events make the choice moot. Its a waste of time for no reason other than making sure you don't fall asleep. 
Lastly its short. There are a number of side quests I could have taken to expand the length but I just didn't find them interesting. To get the full view of the Yakuza timeline, I would encourage playing through the game at least once,
