136138035.review:
If you don't care about gameplay at all and just want to enjoy the story, by all means give this game a spin. The plot is certainly a Yakuza plot. If you are coming off of 0, and Kiwami 1 and 2, and are hoping for more fun brawler gameplay above all else, stay far far away from this game. I wouldn't even recommend it if you got it as a part of the remastered collection if you're someone who prioritizes gameplay over plot. This game will literally just disappoint and irritate you if you aren't someone who gets invested in the story. You can move on to Yakuza 4 without missing much, outside of the fact Kiryu is running an orphanage in Okinawa, which is something you learn in the first chapter of this game.

The combat in this game is the worst I've seen yet. Enemies are super passive, and will often just stand around you holding their fists up. The thing that makes this a problem is that they also like to block constantly. Combat is boiled down to spamming grabs on enemies or just cheesing them with weapons that deal chip damage through their blocks, and not any of the fun stuff you're accustomed to from the games you've likely played before this point. 

The vast majority of your attacks and options are entirely useless since they wont deal any damage through an enemies guard, and enemies re-guard before you can continue a chain without fail. Even waiting (a long time) for an enemy to attack to get behind them isn't a valid strategy, since enemies in this game can turn around while you're combo'ing them.

On top of that, many enemies including bosses take an obscene amount of damage to knock down, don't give you any good openings to deal real damage, and they can't be grabbed. Combat in this game is more of a menial chore than a challenge or fun task, and the random encounters that happen on every single city street quickly become irritating as a result.

TL;DR - This game's combat is as deep as a dried up puddle, and is actively monotonous and irritating. It is not at all a combat system that is worth experiencing by any degree.

If you don't care about any of that and just want to see the substories and plot, do yourself a favor and chunk the game down to easy. The less time you spend in this game's monotonous and boring combat, the better. You'll thank yourself later. Having completed the game on hard, I can tell you there is absolutely no reward to be had in the higher difficulties. The story is worth seeing if you enjoy other Yakuza plots, so for those people I'd encourage them to bear with it.

If you're interested in Yakuza in general, and haven't played a game yet, please don't start with this game. Start with 0. One of the best games I've ever played.

136061570.review:
[Spoiler-free review]

Above anything else, the biggest thing to know about Yakuza 3 Remastered is that, unlike the previous Yakuza games available on Steam; Yakuza Kiwami and Yakuza Kiwami 2, which are remakes of the original Yakuza 1 and 2, Yakuza 3 Remastered is effectively a direct port of the PlayStation 3 version with minor graphical upgrades. If somebody was coming from the original PlayStation 2 versions of Yakuza 1 and Yakuza 2, this game would be considered a significant upgrade in nearly every way, but obviously the vast majority of people these days will be coming to Yakuza 3 directly from Kiwami and Kiwami 2 as I did. This means that the consistency is quite off; you're playing a much older game, and it shows.

I went into Yakuza 3 Remastered knowing this ahead of time, and it rightfully feels like a significant downgrade coming directly from the much more modern Kiwami 2 engine. The combat controls feel quite stiff and not as free-form, which tends to make fights a bit frustrating and more difficult than they need to be, especially in the early game when you are weaker and don't have access to many Heat actions, recovery items, weapons, or upgrades.

The graphics themselves have clearly been cleaned up and remastered for the PC release, and are decent enough given the origin is a PlayStation 3 game from 2009. The environments are nice and bright, and lighting effects, especially with neon signs at nighttime, are as pretty as they always are in Yakuza games. 

One small complaint I have regarding the remastered visuals is that, while it appears some of the story cutscenes were quite well-remastered for this release and look amazing, others appear to have been left completely untouched from the PS3 version, with somewhat-grainy and low-quality video. I'm not sure why this was done, but it seemed to only be like that for cutscenes with many things going on at once or very large environments. Given this is the most modern way to experience Yakuza 3 right now, it would have been nice if all the cutscenes in the game received the same remastered treatment.

I don't go into specific story details in my reviews for the sake of avoiding spoilers for those that are interested in the game, but I will say that the story is very enjoyable. I can't say it is quite as good as the previous chronological games, Yakuza 0, 1, and 2, but it is still very good and beyond a worthy addition to the Kiryu saga of Yakuza games.

As far as the PC port and optimization goes, I never noticed any issues. Just like Kiwami 1 and 2, the game is very well optimized and ran perfectly on my system. As always, I give Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio a massive thumbs up for adding PlayStation button prompts for DualShock 4 controllers through Steam, even in this release of an older game. It's a small thing but it's really nice for many parts of the games to have proper PlayStation button prompts, rather than the generic Xbox-style button prompts most games display.

Unlike the previous games, I admit I didn't really get invested in a lot of the sidegames in this release, as I didn't find them as engaging. But even so I very much enjoyed Yakuza 3 Remastered, and having got it on a very good sale for less than $10 CAD, I will say it was more than worth the purchase price.

That said, in the future, I'd like to see Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio give the proper Kiwami remake treatment to Yakuza 3 and 4, as out of the entire Yakuza series, 3 and 4 are the only ones with very dated PC ports originating from the PlayStation 3 versions. I think it would really breathe new life into these games and complete the entire Kiryu saga experience in a more consistent, modern feel for players.

135852698.review:
From what I heard and what people made this game out to be, I thought this would be either a snoozefest or a travesty to play through. So keep in mind that going in I was expecting a mess, but I was pleasantly surprised and shocked that people are waving fans away from this game, and to "skip it". Don't get me wrong the game definitely has some rough edges, jankyness, and slow combat. But despite all of that this game isnt bad at all. In fact I enjoyed this game more over kiwami 1 and 2.

World and Gameplay - Im going to be honest I did not like the idea of another game taking place in Kamurocho again since by now fatigue of being in the same location was now starting set in playing the whole series in chronological order, however once I did set foot and dipped my toes into Kamurocho within chapter 5, the feeling completely vanished as I was barraged with content to do and new places to see. I'll say it again, it is impressive how they make a same location for a game different to play through each game. But Okinawa is probably one of my favorite locations in the series so far. Maybe im just a sucker for tropical locations but I was immersed and amazed with the new decor. I was actually stopping to admire the view in this game despite it being pretty old.

Combat - Now being the oldest Yakuza title in the series on steam, this is most stripped down Yakuza game that I have played, and that isnt even that bad. Had me using weird strats and things I wouldn't really use in the other games at times and got me experimental. With that mindset I had a lot of fun with street fight encounters. Now playing on hard has never really felt anymore tense then it did in this game, enemies even normal thugs would block FOREVER, your ass will get chain attacked for a century, and damaging a boss in this game is liking chipping away at a stone. But despite all of that, it was not impossible as people claimed, in fact I ended up first trying the secret Amon fight in the end which if you dont know is usually the hardest boss in the game. Combat definitely was a mixed bag but I enjoyed it despite a few big hiccups, like the Lua Ka Long fight, seriously screw that fight.

Mini games - Now most of my hours and enjoyment come from the side activities in these games if you couldnt tell from my hours of playtime for one playthrough, whether it is Yakuza's fantastic substories (actually best side content in any franchise), or climbing the ranks through the collesium. But most of it comes from the mini games, and hostess clubs, and wow do I have some things to say. First off, fuck pool and darts in this game. I was never good at pool but holy shit was the aiming inconsistent, I even looked up a guide for it and it sent me to a photo of a cat crying. The tips for that shit was be patient and maybe you'll get lucky, and guess what I did after three whole days of playing nonstop, the AI ended up missing the 8ball twice and lining up the ball for me to get an easy shot, and dont get me started with darts, the guides for those told me i needed a ruler to be pin point accurate with that shit. A lot of these mini games demanded perfection out of you, and I am proud and ashamed to say that I now legally have the bragging rights to say I completed all mini games and have the achievement to prove it. Now other from those 2, all the other mini games werent that bad and were actually pretty fun. Golf was a vibe, boxcelios was comfy for some reason, and the hostess night life establishments are quite fleshed out and lengthy, though it did start to get repetitive near the end. I enjoyed how much variety they gave us with the choices of hostesses you can request but I do miss the simplicity of just one or two like in Kiwami 1.


As you have read, the game has rough edges but does not deserve to be ignored or passed on by. If you give this game I chance like I did you might just also fall in love with it. Thank You .

135705694.review:
Oh dear, how we have fallen. I really didn't want to give this game a negative rating, but I am gonna have to , else I would have given yellow neutral rating, because while the game isn't terrible, it's mediocre, probably the most unfun yakuza game I have played.

To start of, my previous experience was Yakuza 0, Kiwami and Kiwami 2. I am not going to judge the game based on graphics, in fact for PS3, they are pretty good. Let's get the positives out of the way, because this game does have some positive sides.

For starters I think the music is pretty great and I think the story is actually good. I like the change of setting how Kiryu wants to start a new life with kids, so it's a pretty good setting overall. Sure there are some cliche moments, but every Yakuza game has them to this point. There are a couple of really great substories, some might even say these are one of the best substories.

But, the main reason why I am giving the negative review is the gameplay. The gameplay is absolute trash. Combat is notoriously bland, especially since most people are going to play this after Kiwami and Kiwami 2. The biggest complaint is the blocks. In previous yakuza games, blocks were not as common and Kiryu could easily break them with some moves. Here it's just block, block, block, block... You just have to run around the enemy and punch him for openings. It becomes really boring, but thankfully, last boss is not terribly hard.
On top of combat being boring, the thing I hate the most are ENCOUNTERS WITH THE ENEMIES. Now you might be telling me "But TTC, all Yakuza games have encounters". Let me clarify. In the previous yakuza games you usually had a bunch of gangs walking in the street, they would spot you and they would give you time to either engage them or start running away. They gave you a huge window of opportunity: Run or fight. This is especially useful in late game when money is not the issue and encounters are useless. In this game, a single enemy likes to stand at the left or right side of the street and just waits for you to pass until he starts chasing you, and then engages encounter. Now there are ways to run away from that, but their reaction to start chasing you is like in nanosecond, unlike previous games where they give you a few seconds time. It goes on and on and on. These are the worst random encounters I have ever seen in Yakuza. If it was Majima like in Kiwami, I would have no problem. Majima's encounters in first yakuza were random but unique.
Third main issue are the mini games. Almost every minigame here has been downgraded: Bowling has stupid physics, the batting has no strategy and is just hit and aim, the arcades have only one game that is... pretty odd and kind of boring, and the hostess, oh dear let me tell you about the hostess. There are 2 hostess minigames in the game, one is the standard artificial dating from the first yakuza, and the second one is hostess management. Now I love hostess management in 0 and Kiwami 2, I love how you easily earn money and how satisfying is it to watch it flow, and I when I played this version of hostess management, I was like "...Wow this is utterly boring". What sucks about it the most is you don't even earn any money from the hostess management minigame! It really sucks.

Question for Sega... Why did you not do Kiwami 3? You know that this game is a big downgrade from the 2 others, so why did you not remake it? Was it too expensive, was it because it was first PS3 yakuza game where Kiryu looks identical to the newer games and not low poly kiryu from PS2 era? I don't know why, maybe they were too lazy or just wanted to make a quick buck, because they did release other remasters relatively fast.

So my final recommendation. I would only recommend this to people who played the original PS3 game, grew up with it, and want the exact same experience. Well there you go, this is a game for you, and it's pretty cheap.

For others like me who started from 0, then played Kiwami 1 or 2, I would advise that you just watch the entire gameplay on youtube or just rush through this entire game and ignore the minigames, solve a few substories and move straight to Yakuza 4, because this aged like milk.

135526942.review:
I waited until I had completed absolutely everything there was to do in this game before writing this, as such, I'm doing so well over a year after I originally started this game.
As I had been playing the games in their chronological story order, I knew that from 0, K1 and K2, 3 was going to be a step backwards, as this version is simply a remaster of the original release, hence it mainly has enhanced graphics and perhaps a few tweaks.
Of course, this is immediately noticeable as some systems are reverted back to how the series was handled back then. The combat system is a single set of moves that need to be further unlocked as you gain experience, the combos are pretty different from the ones I was accustomed, but they were easy to adapt to and learn what worked. Unfortunately the game suffers from the known issue of "enemies block too damn much". No sugarcoating it, it's a fact. A lot of dislike is given to the game due to this, but I personally took it as a way to adapt how i'd often played the series before: try to use grabs more often, or even weapons. Dodge around enemies, or simply go all out on your rush combo since the last finishing hit almost always breaks through their block. Enemies also tend to be damage sponges and it can get annoying, but I personally tried to adapt to this way of combating enemies.
Now the reason why i was able to look past the combat was actually the story, and specifically, the Okinawa sections. These parts of the game change from the usual action heavy gameplay and storytelling, to more mellow paced segments that almost become a slice of life story. Kiryu is simply enjoying his newfound life as an orphanage director and spends time with his kids. I personally completely adored these moments and a lot of their parts even brought me tears of joy. I can't find the words to say it but it just fills me with happiness, and I give the game a lot of points for all of these parts.

The game is not perfect by any means and I can understand part of the hate it gets, but I'll be bold to say its my favorite entry in the franchise so far because of some of the smaller aspects of it that form the whole product. And as I said at the beginning, I did literally EVERYTHING, including the entire completion list and all of Haruka's Trust, so I know well how unforgiving some objectives were. If after all of that I can still keep a positive attitude, its because of how much the game resonated with me.

134875156.review:
Just to preface this review: This game is widely regarded as the weakest Yakuza game. As we all know, though, weakest doesn't necessarily mean it's a bad game.

Everyone says the combat is bad and that dissuaded me from playing the game initially. But so far it's nothing crazy judging from the first two bosses on normal. And anyway, whether or not I believe this game's combat to be good or bad by the time I finish it, can we really make this criticism about Yakuza 3 ALONE? Because Yakuza 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2, the only games I've completed so far, definitely all have their fair share of unfun combat. Yakuza 3 is, just off of hearsay, unique in that enemies spam block... but why are we ignoring the fact that so many bosses in Kiwami 1 and 2 just spam quicksteps and counters, making it impossible for the player of a BEAT-EM-UP GAME to confidently attack without worrying about being punished? 

Like some of them pretty much had their own Tiger Drop... some, LITERALLY. Notably the damn "Man in Black" from Kiwami 2 that you fight MULTIPLE TIMES. In Yakuza 0, this was Sera and Shibusawa. In Kiwami 1, pretty much half of the bosses. And don't get me started about the evasiveness of Kiwami 1's finale enemies... who designed the MIA colonels? If you decide to look up No Damage boss runs, most people rely on quickstepping and countering to initiate their combos because so many bosses have their own counters that make throwing EVEN ONE attack risky. And... in a beat-em-up game? Why? It doesn't help that they're random either; thank god there are some bosses in all these games that do some stance or something that shows they're gonna counter you if you attack.

On to the story... I've pretty much spoiled myself for the story and am pretty much playing to experience it myself. If I had to comment on the story, it's actually very good. It's definitely better than Yakuza 4 and 5 (I also spoiled myself for these games as well... got no clue what happens in 6 yet tho). The end got me feeling some type of way... [spoiler]I will forever hold Mr. "Okay Got It" in my heart :( .[/spoiler]

Something really stuck out to me about 3 coming from Kiwami 1 and 2 in terms of its writing: it is so, so, SO MUCH LESS CHEESY. For Kiwami 2, "the cheese" stuck out so much because the main plot without it was actually interesting. Spoilers on Koji Shindo: [spoiler]pretty much up to the point where you fight him you really get the idea that he wants revenge for Nishikiyama... but it turns out he's an insider trying to take the Tojo Clan NOT because he wants revenge over Kiryu for having some role in Nishiki's death, but BECAUSE HE JUST WANTS TO SLEEP WITH YAYOI DOJIMA[/spoiler]

So yeah, unlike Kiwami 2 and 1, Yakuza 3 actually manages to have an interesting main plot and not have it play out with Romeo and Juliet levels of cheese. That makes it in terms of the story an 8/10 game.

134865938.review:
So, two caveats with Yakuza 3:

1. It is easily the weakest stick in the entire game series I have experienced so far.
2. It's still a good game.

A lot of the complaints are around the relatively simple combat controls. Which, honestly, I consider a plus rather than a minus, given how I'm not particularly keen on fighting game systems.

Many other complaints have to do with the non-Kiwami treatment of this game when 1 and 2 have it. Which, again, not a huge deal to me. Sure, you have some graphical scaling inferiority, and some people look ridiculously ugly when compared to the Kiwami engine's face rendering tech. But still, these are pretty minor details in what I consider an overall fun game.

So, what is inexcusable in this game?

Anything, and I mean ANYTHING, involving the Okinawa orphanage, be it quests, characters, backstory, or interactions of any kind, are SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO BORIIIIIIIIIIIIIIING!

Everything involving that damn orphanage is so drawn out and needlessly long! It takes HOURS to leave it the first time so you can get on with the main story, and each time you come back for sidequests and such they are easily the most obtuse and stupid parts of the game. 

Sure, it's great that Kiryu is running an orphanage, but I didn't purchase Yakuza 3: Bullshit Orphan Problems Edition. I bought a game that would continue the series. And, while this game certainly does that, I hope to everything that they never involve another damn inane orphanage to eat up so many hours of wasted gameplay.

Oh, also, the final boss is the easiest in the series I have faced so far. But that's okay, I exploited the relatively simple battle system.

Overall, great game, hate orphanages. The end.

133858894.review:
I've played Zero, 1 and 2 Kiwami, 6, 7, and Judgment Eyes, and now I'm onto 3.

While the combat is certainly /different/ , it is not so difficult to get the hang of it. Enemies do block a lot but I find that once you unlock double finishers in combos or even use a weapon, it is not that much of an issue. 

The story as always, is interesting and I think if I compare this to the previous storylines, 3 feels way more cozy. Who knew setting the game in Okinawa would make it feel so comfy? 

There's definitely pros and cons of having to go back to an older version of what Yakuza/ Like A Dragon's design philosophy was but if I had to put it simply:

Older games had more blood during fights, you don't have a hunger bar that limits your eating (I think you can only eat as much as your HP is missing), combat feels heavier and more punishing but it also feels like the more I level, the more powerful I feel compared to the newer games. The Graphics may be outdated but it's a nostalgic feeling to be looking at a game that looks like this. 

I would say if you've played the newer games and beat them, you can definitely enjoy this old gem.

133648960.review:
The game is a 7/10, I won't touch on the graphics, as they aren't very important. Mechanically, the combat can be frustrating at the start, the excessive blocking can be countered more easily in mid game, I got the double finishing move and it breaks through blocks pretty effectively. Make sure to get the parry and get used to it asap, as it's no doubt one of the best counters to enemies with a high block rate. Utilise your environment!

The story is good and intriguing, kept me interested the whole way through, the characters are fun, lovable, and hate-able to the point where you love them again. It takes a bit of time for it to actually get going, but when it does, you're in for a good time. I have some gripes with how some events play out, it feels like the writers just needed something to happen but they couldn't work out a way to do it in a way that makes sense, it doesn't happen most of the time but there are things I am very salty about. For clarification, I'm not talking about the coincidences that happen a LOT in the yakuza series. Oh, and the sidequests, as always, are fun! Chase missions aren't as terrible as people make them out to seem imo.

[b] HUGE SPOILERS AHEAD [b]
[spoiler] The thing that annoys me the most about the story is Rikiya's death. It was emotional and still saddens me, sure, but it also makes me angry, because it makes NO SENSE! Tamashiro for the entire boss fight was fighting with a gun, but when Kiryu defeats him, they completely forget about that and Tamashiro shoots at Kiryu (Rikiya taking the bullet of course) when their attention gets drawn elsewhere. They knew for the entire time that the gun was there, and at that moment, there was no real dire situation for them to just completely disregard Tamashiro's existence. And the gun's. Kiryu's whole talk to Rikiya before leaving to fight Tamashiro was that Rikiya isn't allowed to come as his death would be for nothing, but with a simple picking up the gun or knocking Tamashiro out cold, it all could have been avoided. Instead, the writers could have found another way to go about it, hell, I wouldn't have been too mad if Tamashiro had a hidden gun on him instead, or maybe have one of the bulls kill him, e.g. one woke up and went wild, the crew needing to escape asap and Rikiya distracting it, getting hurt and Kiryu saving him at the last second, dragging him out of the bull pen and the death scene happening there. oh and that would leave Tamashiro getting crushed by the bulls. He deserves it. [spoiler]

133547498.review:
TL:DR Play this game, but the combat doesn't do it for me.

This will probably be the only Yakuza game I write a review for, because it's generally the most mixed game for me. The story is great, typical Yakuza story stuff, you get the idea (Except the Morning Glory stuff. That went on for way too long) But the combat is something that annoys me. Don't get me wrong, you should play this game if you are playing in order, but the combat is something that I personally dislike. so, if you care, here me complaining about yakuza 3 combat for what could honestly be 2 paragraphs.

The games combat is typical older Yakuza combat. If your playing in timeline order, its basically the Legend/Dragon style from Y0 and K1. Kiryu feels fine to control, and I like the dragon style so its whatever. My real problems come from the enemies. You may have heard the joke "Blockuza 3" used before, and I can see why. Enemies will block basically any (raw) attack thrown at them. Plus the dragon style is JUST slow enough so the enemies can block between hits if you try and punish from the front. Many people will claim it just "button-mashing noobs who don't know how to counter properly" This is correct in a sense, in that you can't just mash to kill people, you need to counter. HOWEVER, the quickstep in this game is bugged, and the 60fps breaks the quickstep so you gain hardly any distance. But you could always use the Komaki abilities, right? Well you don't get (most) of the Komaki abilities until chapter 4 (roughly). This makes some of the hardest bosses in the game the earliest ones you encounter, just because you can't properly counter their attacks or dodge spam (another issue that some bosses have. Looking at you, Majima) Komaki Parry essentially carries this game, as the strategy goes: 1. Komaki Parry. 2. Run around the enemy and land a full combo. 3. Repeat. The other issue is heat actions. Heat actions do so little damage its insane. A normal combo does about the same damage as a heat action with 3 different quick time events. Heat in general in this game also regenerates so slowly, and goes away very quickly, another issue i believe caused by the 60 fps.

The combat in this game isn't great. It's basically Yakuza 4's combat but with the issues I mentioned before. Now you might have noticed "This guy sure has a lot of issues with the combat, why is this a positive review?" Well, because of the story. It basically carries this game. Sure, some of the substories are a little lacking (especially when there is over 110 of them. Y0 had 100 split between two characters) but man the story is to die for. Whatever you do, do NOT skip this game. Play it on easy difficulty if you are really worried about the combat, then sit back and enjoy the story.

133217838.review:
Yakuza 3 Remastered it's a game, the third entry in the Yakuza/Ryu Ga Gotoku series and fourth entry chronologically speaking, on that I think everybody can agree pretty much. Me, personally, have to say that this game is "an experience". It's really hard to say if it is a really bad good game or a really good bad game, it sits in between which is also kind of ironic since it's also the "in-between" point in the franchise were it evolved from the ambitious games from the PS2 era to the style the franchise is most known for. On that fact alone, Yakuza 3 does deserve certain recognition for being sort of a testing ground of ideas that would work better later, kinda like Shenmue but not dry and lame and f-cking boring.

Having mentioned the good stuff, this game is one of the weirdest things you can ever play in a "bad good" way. It's not a train-wreck or anything (don't expect Sonic 2006), but the whole thing is so jarring and theres such a huge disconnect between main plot, the B-plots, the story progression and the gameplay that it just keeps you wondering and wondering what the f-ck were the writer/s doing. The plot basically could be summed up in "Villain wants a lot in Okinawa where Kiryu has his orphanage", yet there's so much unnecesary stuff around it: there's a whole political subplot around two politicians clashing about building a resort vs building a military base in Okinawa, a doppleganger of Kiryu's step dad that starts shooting people, a weapons dealer infiltrated in the CIA even though the CIA is after him so they should know his face but whatever, a main villain whose motivation is not really clear even after it is explained (he wants to make money but doesn't care about money because who cares, we need a bad guy), and in between all that they shoe-horn stuff from the previous games because this was after all the third entry in the series.

I say play it and have fun wondering at the end of every chapter why the hell did they story progressed the way it progressed when it does not make any f-cking sense.

PUTA MIERDA DE SISTEMA DE COMBATE
De momento he jugado Yakuza 0, Kiwami, Kiwami 2 y lo que llevo del 3 avanzando en Kamurocho, y solamente este juego está siendo fácilmente el más tedioso de toda la saga.

- Los bosses son mayormente inmunes al agarre, o empiezan a hacerlo una vez los logras agarrar dos veces, por lo que tampoco les puedes hacer daño a menos que los pesques en el frame perfecto, que tampoco les puedes pegar mucho porque después del primer golpe comienzan a bloquear

Había escuchado que a bastante gente le disgustaba la tercera entrega, pero no había querido creer que fuera malo. 132802632.review:
Yakuza 3 is a strange one. It’s commonly called the worst game in the series while also having tons of diehard fans for it. I at first skipped it and played 4&5, but I caved and bought it, and what do you know, I nearly completed this game in less than a week, not because it was short, but because I couldn’t put down the controller. With most of the series in mind, Yakuza 3 is overall the worst game in the series, in both gameplay and story structure, but by no means does that make it not worth playing. It’s still pretty good, if not, great at times and its major flaws can be easily avoided. So if you like Yakuza, get this game!

GAMEPLAY

Yakuza 3 is most hated for its combat, mostly because enemies blocked too much and had too much health, making boss fights and normal encounters last way too long. Strangely, this can be easily remedied by playing the game in easy mode. It pretty much makes combat feel totally normal, aside from it being easier. Though the combat is by no means perfect. Compared to the games that came after, it’s not quite as involved. I can now see why Y4 took the multiple protagonists approach since Kiryu’s gameplay was growing bland on its own. The combat ain’t all bad though, I found the Komaki training rewards pretty entertaining, especially the final heat move which is pretty difficult to pull off. All in all, the combat feels mostly normal, the only issue is that it outstays its welcome. But there are other parts of this game, like the side content, I actually think this is the real black sheep in Yakuza 3. Most of the substories, while straightforward and easy, just don’t need to exist. I did most of the side quests because I previously made it my mission to defeat every iteration of Amon in the series. In a way, adding other requirements (like hitmen missions and IF7 fights) to fight Amon made the substories less valuable to me. None of them are bad, just not worth the time I spent on them. Overall, the greatest problem with Yakuza’s gameplay is that it tries to squeeze so much of it in where it isn’t necessary. If the game was just a bit lighter in content, or if its requirements to fight Amon were the same as the rest of the series, I think I’d have a lot fewer problems with it.

STORY

Now, this is what makes Yakuza 3 truly worth experiencing. Its story is the most intimate and wholesome in the series and Kiryu smiles here more than he probably does in the rest of the series combined. Parenting and getting to know these orphanage kids was a real treat and it gave me something to lose later in the story. Plus, there’s Rikiya and the rest of his family, he was a pretty likable guy even though I knew he was going to die at some point. Kiryu’s relationship with Haruka is interesting too. Just as a 6th grader, she’s pretty much in charge of everyone and she reminds Kiryu of chores and such. If they are met with a big story-related problem, they just look at each other and nod. I really like this silent trust that crescendos by the end of the game. Like most of the Yakuza games, their relationship is one of the best parts of the game, only being outshined by Yakuza 5&6. I’ve seen complaints about the first few hours of the game, saying that it’s “boring” and “goes nowhere” but it is actually the most valuable part of the game. If you get invested in these characters as I did, you will be pissed, sad, and glad like I was as shit happens in the story. Ironically, the political side of this game is my least favorite in the series. Yakuza is normally the best in the industry at tonal dissonance, Y0 especially, but Yakuza politics really don’t mesh well with the intimate Morning Glory part of the story. The story could have been much simpler while possibly being even better. Just like the gameplay, they just shoved too much unnecessary stuff in the story. But those are my only gripes with the game. Since I’m not a fan of the Yakuza politics, I’m just going to highlight moments I really liked. Majima was GOATed in this game. For the first time in the series, he and Kiryu treated each other as friends. They speak out of understanding, which is absent in the rest of the series. Unlike Yakuza 2, their fight in the Coliseum was entirely consensual, Kiryu was actually excited to fight Majima here. Majima’s dialogue is hilarious and him saving Kiryu in that massive pink truck was funny as hell. Not much else interesting happens until the third act of the game. Mine, the main antagonist who before this point seemed cool and brutal, brought a whole Yakuza family over with a bulldozer to trash the Morning Glory. At this point in the game, after connecting with all of the characters and enjoying Kiryu’s new home, this is probably the most anger-inducing scene in the game, if not the series. In a flash, I went from thinking Mine was cool as hell to realizing he was a heartless bastard. Afterward, Kiryu goes to the bullfighting area to save Rikiya’s boss Nakahara, who was already in recovery from a gunshot wound. A Yakuza boss that we fought near the beginning of the game threatens Nakahara’s life by putting him in the middle of four bulls. Up until this point, Nakahara seemed pretty sickly, but when his surrogate daughter, who has been mute for the whole game, yells for him, he flips a bull by its horns and achieves a new purpose in life. Kiryu flips a bull, fights the boss, and Rikiya comes to his side. That’s when the Yakuza boss tries to shoot Kiryu in the back, which Rikiya prevents with his own body. As Rikiya lies dying, asking Kiryu to show Mine what for, Kiryu can do nothing but wail and beg for him to stay. This is the most emotional he has gotten in the series and it really sends home Kiryu’s fear of being involved with the Yakuza. Even when he’s many miles away from Tokyo, the people he’s close to still get hurt. I felt something in my eyes when I watched this even though I knew of Rikiya’s fate beforehand. I think Kiryu’s reaction is what truly got me, not Rikia’s death. Now, Kiryu is on what he thinks is a suicide mission to save Daigo from Mine. So in what he thinks is his last time to wander with Haruka in Kamurocho, he selfishly takes her with him. Haruka understands this though and encourages him by hugging him in the middle of the street. Kiryu leaves her at New Serena and fights his way up the hospital to Daigo’s room, he finds out Daigo was taken up to the roof by Mine and reaches them. Mine threatens Daigo’s life, saying Daigo doesn’t have to struggle anymore. This gave me Y0 Nishiki flashbacks and Kiryu diverts Mine’s attention to himself. They have a cool shirtless battle on the rooftop and Mine finally sees that money isn’t everything. In a moment very reminiscent of Like A Dragon, he calls his secretary and refuses a billion yen deal. The Black Angels attempt to kill them, Daigo deadeyes all of them, and Mine sacrifices himself thinking he doesn’t deserve a second chance, despite him already making progress moments ago. As Kiryu’s about to leave Kamurocho with Haruka, one of the Yakuza patriarchs, Hamazaki, comes to him and sabs him as revenge for ruining his life. In a moment that feels a lot like Yakuza 5’s ending, Haruka leans over Kiryu yelling for him to stay with her. Hamazaki really could have gotten more screen time. I wanted to fight him but we never got the chance. At least we get that chance in Yakuza 4. The credits roll with what’s probably the best song in the game, and we see Kiryu living peacefully at Morning Glory with his orphans again. Although the game is riddled with flaws, Yakuza 3 has one of the best stories in the series. The gameplay is dated, but it has its high points and it deserves credit for paving the way for the games that came after. This game may be disregarded as filler to many, but like ATLA’s filler episode, The Tales In Ba Sing Se, it is still a highlight in the series nonetheless. Yakuza Kiwami 3, please!

131685841.review:
Yakuza 3 is probably the weakest entry in the series. If you're playing in chronological order, it definitely feels like a step backwards in everything; graphics, game design, gameplay, etc., because it's literally a PS3 game that came out in 2009, albiet slightly touched up. It's by no means a bad game, it just suffers in the shadow of previous games. This shouldn't be a huge issue because the real 'point' of playing this is the story, but if for whatever ungodly reason you don't care about that and only want good gameplay, don't bother with this. Gameplay seems to suffer slightly from the old engine and their shit job with this port. And if you're really bothered by it feeling dated and just want to experience the story, watch the cutscenes on YouTube. If you do like the series for its story and gameplay formula, it's probably safe to assume you'd at least enjoy this one, but there are a number of things worth noting, ESPECIALLY if you're playing in story order (0-6) so as to temper your expectations, otherwise you're more likely to be disappointed.

[h1]The Fix(es)[/h1]
Despite being a remastered port released in 2021, there are some things that are screwed up that they never bothered fixing, that YOU need to either get mods to fix, change the FPS, or deal with. I really have no patience for this kind of shit these days and cannot stand relying on modders for quality of life features and especially to fix broken mechanics. These are primarily related to the 60fps upgrade that breaks some physics and mechanics. Most of the minigames (bowling, golf, pool) are much harder because their physics are tied to the framerate, but it doesn't seem like there are any mods to fix this. If you're going to attempt 100%ing this game, for the love of God lock the game to 30fps. I have no interest in the minigames outside of karaoke (which doesn't seem to be negatively affected) so if you're like me you're probably OK with leaving it at 60fps, HOWEVER...

Get the "Quickstep Restoration" mod, ESPECIALLY if you're playing on hard. Because of issues with the framerate upgrade, they halved the distance of Kiryu's quickstep/dodge. You could probably live without this fix for most of the game on normal, unless you want to try and beat the harder bosses like Amon, but if you're on hard you NEED it. Enemies will block way too much compared to the previous games on this difficulty. Without the original quickstep distance, you are forced into a more time consuming fighting style that feels tedious compared to 0/K1/K2, relying on the cheese of your Komaki moves that unlock in chapter 5 or 6. I didn't know about the quickstep nerf and simply restarted on normal because I could just easily envision this shit getting untenable late game. Quickstep is integral to how you'll be successful in this game THE way to efficiently counter hard difficulty's blockspam.

You also need the "Yakuza 3 Restoration Patch" too. There was a bunch of licensed music they cut that this restores, but most importantly, the cutscenes in the PC version are much lower quality than the remastered PS3 version and look horrific. This mod restores them and the difference is ridiculous, almost comical that the developers didn't do this themselves. And there's also a really stupid bug where the Ryukyu street noise is much louder than other parts of the game so you should probably get "Fix for the loud ambient car sound in Downtown Ryukyu". All of these issues are laid out on the PCGamingWiki, but who would've thought you'd need to check there for a so-called remastered version released in 2021?

[h1]The Fight[/h1]
Gameplay is the typical Yakuza format of watching cutscenes, running around the city, beating up enemies, doing side stories, and fighting a boss or two, then doing the same in the next chapter. This game is much shorter, between 16 and 30 hours depending on how much side content and minigames you distract yourself with. As for that side content, I found myself taken out of the 'main quest' more than other games. They felt more tedious, boring, repetitive, less interesting, consequently less complementary to the game's storytelling, and more vehicles for leveling up and getting items. Some are missable unless you know how to initiate them by checking walkthroughs. They're technically not 'completely' missable as you can go back in Premium Adventure (free-roam after the story) to finish them up, but to me that's kinda pointless; the 'point' is to level up and to give you things to do between major story events. They've always been diversions, but it's way more noticeable that they are in 3.

You only have one fighting style and enemies are drop dead stupid, even on hard. Hard is less of an actual 'hard' difficulty and more an exercise in tedium; it only seems to turn up enemies' block frequency, health, and damage output, NOT intelligence and stuff that matters like attack frequency, combos, etc. Besides boss fights, combat is pretty boring, and since you do a LOT of it, most of the game can feel pretty boring. But like I said from the beginning, you're here for the story. I personally think it's strong enough to warrant playing through and dealing with everything mentioned previously, but it's not free from critique.

[h1]The Plot[/h1]
The story is definitely weaker compared to previous games. It's not bad, but again, just not as good. Kiryu leaves Kamurocho for Okinawa and sets up an orphanage with Haruka, but it's existence is threatened by a land development deal involving people in the Tojo clan, the Japanese government, and spoilers but not really: [spoiler]the CIA and some weapons dealing organization[/spoiler], who all have converging interests in setting up a resort, casino, and military base. The characters are all fine, obvious standouts being Kiryu, Rikiya, Date, and of course Majima. None of the few antagonists are as compelling as those in previous entries. All of the Tojo leadership are lame and the main bad guy who is revealed later in the game is really uninteresting. The whole plot is a little predictable, but there are a couple effective deaths. The orphanage thread was a fun change of pace, but it seems somewhat out of place. Sure, there are glimpses of this kind of Kiryu in 0/K1/K2, it just gets a little too goofy and feels slow. Like I'm here for a crime drama full of intrigue and doing Yakuza things, not raising kids and being a great dad. Also I wish there were more fully voiced cutscenes. This wasn't as noticeable in previous games but it feels like there were more of the static in-engine "press X to read more dialogue" stuff. Again, probably due to it being a remaster, but I would much prefer all of the story segments as full cutscenes to not break the flow and interfere with tone.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Despite everything I've said up to this point, it's still fun and I enjoyed my time with it. To sum things up, Yakuza 3 is just an older, dated game that suffers in comparison to 0/K1/K2. This game is rooted in the context of it being the third entry of a young series that was still finding its footing for storytelling and character development. It's significantly shorter than 0/K1/K2 and despite my playtime, not a 77 hour investment, I just really enjoy taking everything in and seeing as much of this game as possible (minus some of the minigames, I'm not that masochistic). A better estimate is 20 hours if you're focusing on the story and somewhere between 30 and 100 if you the more substories, minigames, crafting, collecting, etc. you want to do.

131387437.review:
Its the black sheep of the series. Yakuza 3 crawled so Yakuza 4 could run.

Yakuza 3, for all intensive purposes is not an unplayable game by any means. However it's gameplay is a far cry from the high points of the franchise as many of the games aspects were the first iterations, thus they're very hard to stomach if you're playing this after the newer entries, or didn't grow up / live with games that came out between 2000-2012.

For the guys reading this that are considering getting this game for the story and aren't sure if they want to go through the hoops themselves or watch a longplay online, I won't sugar coat it.
If all you want is story, just play it on easy mode.
If you're feeling brave and want to know hurt similar to your loved ones being the reason you're feels like its ending, play on normal to get the emotions out.

Why has this one in particular aged poorly exactly?
Gameplay, and solely gameplay. Don't be fooled by criticism over the writing as most qualms for better or for worse have smoothed over as the series went on rather than take strides to retcon this out of the canon.
tldr, if it was still 2010 and the series future was up in the air, you'd be right to be cautious. but, thats not the case.

like previously stated, many of the aspects of this game are now staples of the franchise, however this was the game many were introduced and as a result are clunky or obtuse to figure out.
Hostess maker / cabaret club manager is the biggest example of this as far as minigames go...

Combat is especially jarring. Yakuza 3 doesn't reward the more aggressive or rush down play styles some my be accustomed to, which requires taking time to learn its more...Reserved combat that relies more of waiting and punishing enemies through use of countering, parrying, or learning the weapons system, which are essential if you intend to brave Hard or legendary difficulty.
Things most will be aware of right out the gate:
-enemies will attack you from off screen
-the heat meter drains quickly, more so if you happen to get grabbed
-QTE's are everywhere
-enemies will often spam sidestepping to avoid attacks which ultimately makes them invulnerable
-enemy guard can't REASONABLY be broken with normal attacks.
-when enemy guard is broken, they will put back up again immediately.
-And last but not least, due to the games pacing, it takes upwards of 6-10 hours before you're able to really get into the meat of the combat.

Progression is earned through EXP similarly to yakuza 1 & 4. you have one resource to divvy up between 4 skills trees in a fixed order. Getting through the skill trees isn't hard of course unless you're b-lining it through the story and skipping everything else. The problem is, even if you fulfill it, you still won't have your full tool set to fight with. Certain tools that are more or less necessities aren't able to be unlock through exp.

Perhaps one of my biggest nitpicks is how additional moves can be earned. through out the game kiryu meets different characters who for the most part are upfront saying "I have something to teach you. come back when you have time." sometimes you can earn health or heat upgrades, other times kiryu can handle certain weaponry better (his or his enemies), however my least favorite is Mack.
You meet Mack early on, he tells you to find interesting moments in the overworld and make a not twitter post, and as a result, kiryu learns a new move. 
The problem is, when you've unlocked the ability to do these, all you're given is a vague clue as to what or where you need to look. you must then go into a first person mode and zoom in on the moment of interest, do a small series of QTE's, then make a timed decision on what to caption the event with (only one out of three being the right response). If you fail, you have to leave, and come back.
As much fun as hidden unlockables can be...In an beat em up, the last thing I want is my tool set being locked behind obtuse puzzles.

Theres also a chase "minigame" lets call it.
the premise is simple, chase someone through crowds and tights spaces and tackle them. do it enough times before you run out of stamina.
you have to play it on a couple occasions in the main story, but fortunately for completionist out there and handful of these moments were cut from the remaster (if you don't know why, don't worry. neither gameplay or related side quest story was worth it.)
Its cluncky, its mandatory to play, its unforgiving at first, its not fun. plain and simple.

final verdict: 6/10
TLDR:
if you're gonna play it just for story, play easy mode.
This ones rough, we need a Kiwami 3 to happen

131175212.review: Yakuza 3 is a very interesting game, from its tone to its gameplay. For the time, its visuals are stunning, and even now its art style and settings differ completely from the other entries in the series. It purposefully depicts the two sides of our main character's life as being entirely different, with the dirty backstreets of Kamuroucho being their own world away from the sunny beaches of Ryukyu. You get to play the role of a father figure to a group of orphans, much like Kiryu himself once was, and see how he continues to struggle with the aftermath of the first two games. It has one of the saddest and heartfelt stories in the series, let down a bit by pacing that has a hard time slowing down. Seishu Hase was not present for this game's story, and his oversight over the first two games' plots were most certainly missed a bit here, but the strong direction without his presence really does lend itself to a bold new direction, coinciding with Kiryu's new lease on life. I would recommend Yakuza 3 remastered as long as you grab the quickstep mod and restore the original soundtrack, as Eikichi Yazawa's opener is an absolute killer.

130803262.review: As Date-san once said "In for a penny, in for a pound." If you have played 0, (maybe) 1, and 2; might as well keep going for the story. Graphics-wise this remaster looks okay on 1080p, not sure about higher resolutions. The main story was good but near the end had some small issues. Most of the substories were decent. Now for my grievances... Not going to say anything new here but the combat really sucks the fun out of the game. Just really love the constant blocking that gives bosses almost full immunity. Also appreciate how easy it is to get knocked down / stunned and then repeatedly stunned. The street thugs were a nuisance, yes they were in the previous games as well but in this game they love to run up and engage in a dialogue with you, wasting time. Plus, in past games you could sweep them in 3 button presses by using a bike or whatever object laying around, in this game these objects felt almost completely useless. The host club was a snoozer, might as well have been a capsule hotel mini-game since I was falling asleep in my chair trying to play it. Finally, don't waste your time like me collecting the locker keys past whatever the first achievement is (I think collecting 5 or so) since there's no achievement for opening all the lockers. Just really loved the gimmicky first-person camera mechanic for finding the keys. Overall... I give this remaster a 5/10, don't think I'll ever be replaying it. Sayonara aniki.

130788596.review: While going from Kiwami two, to just a remaster of a 10+ year-old early PS3 game is definitely jarring at first, the story and very likable characters mostly made up for the drop in gameplay. I had to sort of change how I played, focusing more on getting a few hits then dodging while waiting quite a while for heat to build, and using weapons much less than previous, while also having a pretty low overall damage output. Even so, I was expecting the game to feel much more tedious to get through, but it was still very fun. The story is what made me enjoy the game the most by far though. You get introduced to all the kids at Kiryu's new orphanage he takes care of, and although they seem annoying at first, there were lots of cute and wholesome interactions between them and Kiryu. You also meet the Ryudo family dudes and as the story goes on, they became my favorites. [spoiler] Rikiya's death [/spoiler] is still one of the saddest moments in the whole series for me, personally. As well as [spoiler] Mikio nearly dying, and seeing what's in Saki's notepad and her speaking for the first time [/spoiler] this game is filled with very many tear-jerking moments in the story. A very solid entry in the Yakuza series that I ended up liking far more than I thought I would. Still waiting for Sayama to come back. 🗿

No sé si merezca la pena completarselo al 100%, solo si eres tan fan de sacar los logros puede que si, pero el estilo de combate no te genera mucha motivación, lo digo porque en los ultimos duelos del ultimate match es complicado efectuar una habilidad, literalmente tienes que operarte los ojos y ponerte unos de halcon para ejecutar un parry o tiger drop, no la muelen. 130686202.review:
[h1] [b] Yakuza 3 Remastered [/b] [/h1]

As a recent buyer of all of the mainstream Yakuza games, I will admit that this series has it's highs and it's lows.  I have found that these lows typically come through the means of mediocre gameplay, weak storylines, or even just crashing issues (looking at you, Yakuza 0). However, Yakuza 3 breaks this lowly mold by simply being... really boring. 

Don't get me wrong, I know for a fact there are people who enjoy Yakuza 3. For some people, a very relaxed game where you essentially just solve children's problems, fish, and walk around city while once in a while beating someone up might be fun. However, compared to other Yakuza entries, this time around I find it nothing but disappointing, boring, and lackluster. Out of the whole series, I would certainly make an argument to skip Yakuza 3.

130472920.review:
This is the cursed one.

Pros:
Generally speaking, it's fine. The substories are fun, the plot is as cheesy as a yakuza 3 can get, which made me laugh loudly in some instances and all the minigames from other yakuza games seems to be there... however..

THE Con: COMBAT
Believe me when i say, there's a reason it's called "Blockuza" because of the bad porting. It's not only a problem of how many times the enemies block every single move, but also the fact that combos are NON-EXISTANT. Enemies can block in the middle of a combo, at the beginning of it, at the very end, they can block bullets of both guns and shotguns, explosives... everything. Not only the blocking can be an issue, but also the constant quickstepping and stun of such which makes some boss fights absolutely broken, more specifically (minor spoilers): Misterious Strangers' ambush, Yonashiro's training and most of all, Joji Kazama. 

It can take a huge amount of rage for me to abandon a game, which i did not, but this is possibly the first time i'll ever say something like this: i DO recommend playing yakuza 3 to get yourself ahead in the story, understanding better haruka's progression, Kiryu's storyline and the Tojo clan's Lore... but by all means, USE CHEATS when you fight certain bosses, your mental health won't thank you enough... and no it's not a matter of difficulty, but of sheer jank unfairness.

For context: I've litterally completed Yakuza 0, kiwami, kiwami 2 and now this in a row, which has taken me about 2-3 weeks.

I'll pump up the review from 5/10 to a 6.5/10 as a overall rating, but story was defo 7/10 while certain moments was just truly beautiful.

129402915.review:
As a long time Yakuza fan, I have to say that this remaster is extremely disappointing. I feel like a lot of the reviews are more focused on people trying to defend the game (since it's largely considered the least favorite game in the franchise) than actually judging the remaster itself. Not even sure I can make it through the remaster with all the issues that have been peeving me off. 

I will make this clear, Yakuza 3 (OG) is not a bad game, the combat is highly over criticized and the story is great, but the Remaster is not the OG, while the story is still amazing all round, the game does very little to fix the flaws of the OG and in fact worsens them.

If you really want to play Yakuza 3 (and not be completely annoyed at combat segments), I'd highly recommend the original as the combat just feels butchered here comparatively as combos that are guaranteed to work in the original will sometimes if not always fail on the remaster which just makes the block heavy game much less fun. It's hard to really give the port any good points when there's so many issues with it.

The only reason you should ever buy this game is if you buy it with the other remasters, otherwise it's only worth it if you want the much better localization

Video By DillionT comparing the games and showing a lot of the issues that will be discussed: https://youtu.be/PI5UPxSKjKw

[b]The Issues with the port:[/b]
[list]
[*] A lot of the mechanics have changed ever so slightly, and for the worse. 

[list]

[*] For whatever reason the heat loss is insanely fast compared to the original title

[*] Enemies turn faster which causes your combos to fail even if you're completely behind them which makes it much harder to combo them

[*] Your quickstep is shorter, which makes it even harder to get behind enemies

[*] The AI is still allowed to have super easy stun combos while Kiryu is barely able to even get hits in since his ability to stun and combo is greatly reduced due to the faster turning of the Remaster which allows the block happy enemies to basically block behind them

[*] AI is actually outright worse, ranging from bosses like Shinzaki who now quicksteps like a maniac to just extreme passiveness and 180 degree turning
[/list]

[*] Visuals are barely any better, in fact some things like Kiryu's heat aura is actively worse looking overall
[/list]

129377411.review:
When it comes to Yakuza games, I would rank this one in the top, the only thing holding it back from being a perfect game is the gameplay which most people will find frustrating or just plain boring due to the abundance of blocking and the damage of heat actions being lackluster. 
The story is carrying the game hard, more of a slice of life style with very nice character development, and it's the one game that in my opinion humanises and pushes Kiryu to be more relatable to us on a personal level.
The soundtrack is... amazing, I highly recommend using the uncensored/restoration patch for the game, the opening is so good I've never skipped it, the boss fight themes are really good, some of my favourite tracks being "Ogre has Returned" and "Fly", but other songs are nothing to scoff at either such as Kiryu's battle themes for the two different cities, they hit hard, sound great, and have a lot of love put into them by the composers. The game has a lot of love put into it in general!
100%-ing the game was not as much of a chore as I expected, the annoying part came when I was faced with pool, Yakuza 3 and 5 have PTSD inducing pool, it's not fun.
And yes, Mine has the ability to turn men gay, deal with it.
All in all, very enjoyable game, you just need to put in some effort into learning how to best overcome the abundant blocking and you will have a blast!

129144419.review:
Yakuza 3 is the Fourth entry into the series. Unlike the Kiwami's and 0 this is just a remaster and not a remake. 

The combat is frankly terrible. The enemies block non stop so on higher difficulties you have to constantly press grab. This feels terrible because the low ranking enemies have pin point pecision on their blocks, it makes every fight feel like an absolute slog. On hard this becomes a mess, and because this game is old you cant swap difficulty in the middle of the game, so i had to use a 3rd party software to change the code in the files in order to swap it. This game isnot hard, its just poorly designed. The rpg elememts are also very bad, inventory system makes 0 sense. Theirs like 10 slots and it was so bad i had to do inventory management in a fucking Yakuza game!. The skill system is the worst its ever been, it was bad in Kiwami 1 and its even worse here. Its just levels into 4 categories with random perks attached to it, theirs no choice just 4 options the entire game. The mini games are very outdated, some are super hard ether because the difficulty is crazy or because the ui for the game is terrible. There are some actual developed minigames, but like i said they are to much of a slog to really get into. 

The story takes place on a orphanage on Okinawa after the end of 2. The kids all have distinct personalities and sadly the game tells you every single one of these kids stories. It literately forces you to experance this shit, it would have been fine in a sidequest but it gets very very annoying when the actual Yakuza stuff is picking up in momentum and then it suddenly stops and the game forces you to go on a goose chase helping these kids. I have no idea why they chose to develop every single one of them cause they dont really matter at all to the general story. Kiryu already loves kids and has Hauruka we dont need to be told a million times how much of a good dad Kiryu is too these kids, we already know!. These quests with the kids generally ruined my experance with the game for half of the runtime. 

The other half is the average Yakuza stuff, where half of it is generally pretty bad. My issue is that the overall plot is it is very generic. Basically its this overarching narrative about evil secret organisations that go past the Yakuza plot. The characters you meet are killed off quickly or have little time on the screen because of this overarching narrative. It is sad, because their are genuinely some really great characters with awesome backstories that have pretty good motivations, but when that narrative comes creeping back in, those elements about those characters are ruined for some cringe inducing plot points. But that other half of the Yakuza part of the plot is actually good, because i could see the potential with what they were doing. It just that Yakuza 3 doesnot have an identity, it wants to be a orphanage simulator, then it wants to be a Yakuza crime drama, then it goes towards an action movie generic secret organisation plot. These 3 distinct plot diversions ruined the games pacing and made story elements very frustrating. It also turns the CIA into the good guys, really...

Other than the main quests, the side content expecally in Okinawa is actually very good. The first 4 chapters are filled with side stuff to do and its all up to standard side content. But by the time i went back Kamurocho, the story was so slow i just skipped over the side stuff to finish the game. 

In the end, Yakuza 3 is a very disappointing game that tries to many things with its plot, that it ends up turning into a slog. The gameplay and the minigames are outdated and unfun at higher difficulties. I would rate this a 5/10 more to a 6 than a 4, it has some good moments but the overall game ruins those moments. Only get this game if your like me, and want to do a playthrough of all of the games in the series, but please skip this if you want to just play the good ones.

128877369.review:
yakuza 3 is a game that i think is often overlooked because of its glaring flaws. the most obvious of these flaws is, of course, the combat. the AI has a tendency to block too often, ruining the flow of the game. its ability to target/track kiryu is also a little overbearing, as it makes sidestepping and hitting enemies in the back much harder to pull off. damage output is frustratingly low. all of these flaws lead fights to be ultimately less satisfying than they could have with a couple tweaks. many boss fights can drag on for way too long if you don't know the best ways to cheese them or deal more damage quickly. the game is very rigid in its approach to combat and wants you to work with it in a very specific way. but these are complaints everyone has.
...but, to be honest, past a certain point in the game, i didn't really care.
yakuza 3 is a game that does an incredible job at humanizing kiryu and its themes of trust and familial bonds feel like a natural evolution of what was explored in the first two games. rather than opening up with the typical over the top crime drama hijinks, y3 has you tend to the absolutely loveable cast of orphans at morning glory. while a lot of fans consider this segment of the game tedious, or the worst part, i thought it was incredibly well-done and found myself invested in these kids' character arcs quite a bit (especially taichi). having kiryu do the same thing his role model kazama did in the past really feels like a nice progression of his character. additionally, the supporting cast of characters like rikiya, mikio, and nakahara were a lot more likeable than past games.
the strong emotional core and the lovable cast allows me to look past this game's glaring flaws, but at certain points i found myself bored out of my mind with the main plot. while the core concept of okinawa being gentrified and transformed into something the natives can't recognize is an interesting idea, i found myself struggling to stay awake once tamiya dropped an enormous plot dump on me.
yakuza 3 likes to reuse plot points from the previous two games in the series, and there are a ton of parallels and incredibly similar plot beats, but i don't see this approach as necessarily wrong. at the end of the day, its story stands on its own as pretty solid. mine is a very good foil to kiryu and his entire mindset, and having seen kiryu's trust pushed to its limits over and over again, you can't help but respect his tenacity and willingness to uphold his ideal.
overall, while it lacks the dense atmosphere and focus of the first game, or the absolute manic pacing and insanity of the second, yakuza 3 manages to stand out as one of the most emotional games in this series for me, next to 0.

oh yeah, if you are planning on playing this, i highly recommend installing these two patches as they improve the overall experience: https://cookieplmonster.github.io/mods/yakuza-3/#silentpatch https://www.nexusmods.com/yakuza3remastered/mods/5/

This game is 100% the hardest in the mainline series if you play on hard or legend, enemies block absolutely everything and breaking their guard does nothing as they just put it right back up making you have to rely on grab spamming or dodging behind them as they attack which you will most likely need a mod for as the remastered version quickstep is bugged and is very pathetic without the mod, however the difficulty spike is not all that bad if you are willing to learn how the ai works and get good at dodging and punishing the enemies. The street fights are pretty boring on hard and legend as dodging and punishing is out of the question because the other enemies will just hit you as soon as you start doing that making you have to rely on grab spamming and using heat actions or bladed weapons so they can't block, the bosses however are really fun once you get the hang of the combat the final boss is also my 3rd favourite final boss they have ever made and has a good soundtrack and dynamic intro to top it off

(Audio/Soundtrack)

not a lot of great soundtracks but the ones that are good are easily some of the best they have made however some of the voice acting in this game is just not that good

(Audience)

A lot of people dying and getting shot might not be suitable for people who don't like that sort of thing

(PC Requirements)

Never dipped below the 60 fps cap on a 2070 super ryzen 5 5600 16gb ram and considering its an early PS3 game it probably runs well on a lot of systems even though it was remastered the changes were minimal to the graphics

(Difficulty)

can probably button mash your way through the game on easy or normal but you need to work around the blocking enemies and bosses do which can take some skill especially on hard and legend

(Grind)

you don't need anything that's grindable to beat the story

(Story)

one of the weakest rgg games but still a heartwarming story that follows kiryu running an orphanage around 2 - 3 years after 2/kiwami 2, there's a lot of filler stuff around kiryu taking care of all of his kids but once you finish that the story is pretty good and the characters are great

(Game time)

around 15 - 17 hours in length

(Price) 

every rgg game is worth its price especially on a sale

(Bugs)

saw like maybe a bug or two which isn't surprising as rgg games never have any notable bugs 

(Rating /10) --- 8/10

Pretty good certainly some flaws but you shouldn't miss out on this games story as it's pretty important for future entries

128584236.review:
How to improve your enjoyment of gameplay, instead of whining about blocking enemies and defensive enemies (that only attack you once you do the same to them) and many more annoying types of the enemies you encounter later on:

Step 1: Get War God Talisman and Calming Towel. (War God Talisman acquired through S rank Ultimate Challenges, very tedious but optional; Calming Towel is purchased through Coliseum, 7500 points).

Step 2: Get Tech level 10, Komaki Parry (Leveling, Komaki Parry can be gotten very early and you could look up a guide for it).

What do they do?
1) You can freely cancel your attacks through Tech level 10's Quickstep Cancel and follow it up with Komaki Dodge Shot which is very vital for punishing enemies that attacks instantly after you attack them (especially if you want to start No Damaging bosses and want to lean over combo than technical no damaging) - pairing this with Calming Towel makes wall-bounding, stunlocking and tech-cancelling half finisher combo very easily and gives you the flexibility that the game could not provide you because Heat gain is too much even with other Heat decrease items.

2) Heat Actions. War God Talisman is for those who wants to mix-up combos with Heat Actions; Red Heat Actions cannot be performed but it's still very good anyways.

3) Komaki Parry is the cherry on top of the cake mainly due to allowing you to immediately punish an enemy and then chain-stunlock them, some bosses have Komaki Cat-Like Reflexes but none of them can tech out of 2x Rush 1x Finisher Evade Finisher combo or 3x Rush 1x Finisher Evade Finisher combo, allowing you to playing it like one of your favourite Tekken game (brokenasfuck)

Optional: Payback Ring replacing War God Talisman. Once again - grinded at Coliseum. 15000 points. This makes all of your combo super lethal in EX-HARD difficulty as if you get hit the enemy would just take your punches harder, and if you're No Damaging bosses you're in for a ride - once you get a hit in it's already over, you need only one health and few stunlock wall-bound combos to immediately win a tedious fight in just a single minute that originally took you 8x more times to complete.

The game is very flawed, of course you still have to grind to achieve the satisfaction in gameplay, but it's well worth it. It's one of my hated and loved Ryu Ga Gotoku game to this day and I think limiting certain aspects of gameplay DO help that there are more aspect of the game that can be exploited to hell. Very recommended if you want to beat the game on the hardest difficulty with much of the enjoyment coming after the hell grind using my strategy above.

128510454.review:
To get them out of the way, yeah; I will definitely say that I agree with the common consensus that Yakuza 3 is a bit messy. The combat is much more janky then that of 0, Kiwami or Kiwami 2: dodging feels more finicky, enemies block quite a bit, and it feels like the requirements to upgrade yourself feel a little much (Even with doing a ton of the sub stories, I wasn't anywhere close to maxing out my skills by the end of the game). The graphics don't look as polished as the game's proceeding or that come after this one. And the substories, at least early on, aren't quite as compelling as those I've experienced in 0 or Kiwami 2. 

That said, despite the messiness, I still had a lot of fun here. I less than perfect Yakuza game is still a pretty dang awesome game. The characters are pretty fly; some of the new people you meet are series highlights for me, and Kiryu's Okinawan outfit is pretty rad. New gameplay elements - like revelations- are really fun, and the new essence skills they unlock are fantastically animated. The soundtrack is incredible, as usual. And while the ending had some moments  which made me laugh for reasons which were probably unintended by the developers, the story overall was quite enjoyable, compelling, and had its fair share of moments which made me cry. 

Definitely not where I'd start if you happen to play a Yakuza game before. But if you have played a previous title , are slowly making your way through the series and perhaps aren't sure if 3 is worth the slog, I would definitely say that it's worth the playthrough. 🙂 It me not be a Yakuza game. I'll come back to replay, but for the playthrough I did put in, I can say it was very much worth my time.
