128407095.review:
Having followed the modern play order of Yakuza 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2, the leap backwards from the Dragon Engine-powered Kiwami 2 to 3, a PS3 game that received only a cosmetic remaster (and restoration of cut content) wasn't quite as bad as I feared, or as people in the fandom tend to make it sound. To be sure, the change in graphics, in gameplay, in general quality-of-life is jarring - Yakuza 3 very much looks and feels like a PS3 game, lacking the polish and finesse of the PS4 era games that come before it in the series's internal timeline. However, I found that the Yakuza formula remains the same no matter what engine it's in, and the charm and appeal of the series shines through in 3 just as much as any other iteration.

Thematically, 3 is the end of a trilogy established with the original versions of 1 and 2, following Kiryu as he transforms from a lost, aimless ex-yakuza into a primal force dedicated to upholding the honor of the Tojo Clan by any means necessary, and then further on as he settles into what he hopes is a new, peaceful life. The change of scenery in the early game from Kamurocho to Okinawa is a welcome one, slowing the series's typical breakneck pace down to a peaceful, relaxing crawl for the first several hours. It's a divisive decision, in the way that it takes chances with what people expect of the Yakuza games, but I felt that the ways in which Kiryu's character is developed and deepened were vital. You see what he's like as a father figure, at peace after resolving the latest Tojo Clan disaster, his focus on the small scale of Okinawa's yakuza presence and keeping his orphanage afloat, determined to give back to society in a way he never could have before. I felt that it didn't overstay its welcome too much, though I did find myself longing for Kamurocho when the game turned back to the city.

The rest of the narrative is typical Yakuza fare, in that it's a strong, engaging crime drama with a fair amount of hyperbole and outrageousness. The Okinawa crew is a fun set of supporting characters, as are the new members of the Tojo Clan we meet throughout the story. Where Kiwami 2 felt like it relied too heavily on endgame twists, the plot of 3 - written at a different time, with different narrative sensibilities - is somewhat more straightforward, with clear, understandable motivations from the main and secondary villains, particularly Mine, an excellently written villain whose backstory elicits a fair amount of sympathy even as his actions remain vile. The Black Monday subplot, vaguely, feels rather like nonsense, but I can admit that it dovetails well into the main story, and never feels like a set of twists for the sake of twists.

Then there's the combat. You always hear about Yakuza 3 being a slog by way of the extremely block-heavy enemies, from street level goons all the way up to the final boss. I can absolutely see where people are coming from, and it's certainly a huge adjustment to make from Kiwami 2, where the combat is comparatively smooth as butter. However, I was rarely ever truly frustrated or irritated by the combat - the goons block, but they'll simply drop their blocks if you pressure them enough, and you can quickstep around them or grab most of them to get around it. The bosses are more aggressive, but I found that once you understood their attack patterns, you could interrupt them and chip damage away pretty consistently. It makes the fights take forever, but I never felt that I would unfairly take a loss - if I lost, it was a skill issue, not a gameplay issue. Fixing the quickstep distance when running at 60 fps with a mod helps, for sure, but I personally didn't think it was absolutely essential for the combat to be tolerable.

On the whole, while Yakuza 3 is a product of its time, the fact remains that RGG Studio has always known what they're doing, and the framework of what makes this series truly great is evident in their first PS3 game, the oldest game in the modern play order by release date. It's not devoid of problems - the story occasionally has goofy nonsense, the combat can slow to a crawl, the substory interface is rather frustratingly obtuse even with a quest log, and I never once found myself wanting to play any of the minigames, ESPECIALLY the comparatively-horrendous version of the cabaret club minigame - but Yakuza 3 remains a Yakuza game, and that means it's fun, engaging, and worth your time.

tl;dr blockuza 3

[list][*]Replaces the crazy side missions with "help the kids grow up" missions.
[*]The main story isn't really very good.
[*]Majima is in the story, but only a little.  They could have left him out easily without changing the story.
[*]The fighting system just isn't as fun as it is in 0, 1, and 2.
[*]The mini-games aren't as fun as before, either.  Even the bowling mini-game got dull.  I don't even remember where the cabaret club is that I'm supposed to be running.
[*]There seems to be a detailed system for modding weapons, but why would I work so hard on weapons in a game where you are such a great fighter??
[*]If you don't want to spend your money on weapons (or maybe your club?), you really don't need money for anything but a little food now and then.
[*]I don't think you get any xp for random encounters, just money and a few raw materials for weapon modding.  Both were useless to me, so random encounters became nothing but practice - and pretty poor practice at that.  Bosses act nothing like randoms.
[*]Random encounters are very difficult to avoid.
[*]Lots of QTEs.
[/list]
It's not all horrible.  If you want to play all the Yakuza games, you can plow through this one.  It will toss you a bone now and again.  Just hold your nose, resign yourself to the fact that you'll need to explain life to each and every kid at some point, and power through it.

127806083.review:
Clicking the thumbs down is because I just want to prepare you for disappointment. If you're like me and you've been belatedly working through this series, starting with Yakuza 0 and on through Kiwami and Kiwami 2, what you are going to find here is the first game that doesn't have a newer touch on its game mechanics, and it shows. 

Everything is clunkier! Combat is not as fun. Street encounters are less dynamic and harder to avoid when you reach the point in the game where you just want to run away from guys. New mechanics, like chases, are annoying. Kamurocho is less alive outside of cutscenes. Heat actions are very undertuned against bosses. Even the progression mechanic isn't particularly satisfying, with little feeling that Kiryu gets much stronger from the beginning to the end of the game. I was disappointed that the story made the decision to just write out Sayama from Kiwami 2 rather than carry over a potential love interest for Kiryu. The new location of Okinawa is not as cool of a secondary location as Sotenbori has been in prior games.

Looking over all of those flaws, I did like experiencing the story of this game, when it was there. Kiryu acting as the father figure to a house full of orphans, including Haruka, is sweet to see, how he tries to have a normal existence for them even when some of the craziness of his old life starts to catch up. I wish there was a bit more of this mixed in with the plot, which ends up being several chapters in a row in Okinawa that awkwardly try to catch up the story from where Kiwami 2 left off to when the main plot of 3 is set, several more chapters in Kamurocho, and not much back and forth until the very end. The cast is always committed to every cutscene and the plot is full of dramatic turns as you'd expect from this series. 

I'll be continuing the series, but I sure hope that 4 and 5 (which are the other games that were made before the 0 prequel, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2 came along) represent an improvement over this.

127770088.review:
Yakuza 3 is a flawed game but not to the point where I'd skip it, it's still worth it if you care about Kiryu, his story, and exploring new places. As someone who decided to play Yakuza 2 on PS2 instead of Kiwami 2 (I don't like how it's basically a completely different game that tells Y2's story) I appreciated the way it advanced the series more than others I think.

[b]Story[/b]
The story, unfortunately, feels a bit rushed and gives the impression of something that was originally going to be way bigger. You can kinda tell with how [spoiler]Rikiya's death is never mentioned or talked about after it happens afaik, not even Kiryu and Haruka paying respects to him in the ending or anything which sucks since he was a good character[/spoiler] and the infamous giant exposition scene. If you're someone that not the type to do every substory, you're gonna be annoyed with all the mandatory orphanage stories, but as someone who does do all of them I really like seeing Kiryu's new life and how happy he is as a dad. The story does otherwise have some fun moments and an enjoyable finale though.

[b]Combat[/b]
Game was played on hard, I don't know if anything significant changes in Normal or Legend.
On one hand, Kiryu's kit has improved a lot since Yakuza 2, with improved controls, getting tiger drop and parry pretty early, and powerful heat moves like Essence of Rolling. However, as you probably know, the problem with this game's combat is the enemies. Their problem isn't just that they block all the time, it's combined with some other factors. So, if they block, why not go behind them since they can't block from behind? That does work on occasion, but depending on the moveset the enemies can have attacks where they turn 180 as they do it. Grabs can work, but they're not that strong and even then there are enemies which just can't be grabbed, which sucks. 
There's also the way the ai works: enemies will mostly only attack when they know you're vulnerable, such as when you're attacking someone else. Later games' enemies do a downplayed version of this ai but combined with the blocking this can make early game group fights really annoying. Even later on this makes standard enemy fights longer on average than most others in the series. 
Now, at least it can be easy to tiger drop enemies on one-on-one fights, right? It would be if they actually attacked you. Biggest example of this is [spoiler]Joji[/spoiler] who as far as I remember just didn't attack for the longest time and waited for you to mess up, this is the same for the Coliseum enemies where if you wanted to counter them, you need to try bait their ai into attacking by facing away from them or with blockstrings, which even then doesn't always work (works pretty well on Majima though). Probably the worst offender is Komaki who I swear wasn't play-tested. There are a couple of alternate ways to whittle enemies' health down but it's not exactly efficient or consistent. 
Funny thing though, Amon and the final bosses actually attack you constantly, making them the funnest bosses in the game since you can actually counter/get behind them!
Anecdotes from my experience:
-Komaki Parry only works for punches and most weapons, but you can do it the moment the enemy enters the attacking animation compared to tiger drop where it's just before they attack, so get used to using that on enemies with punching movesets. Enemies may take forever to attack, but they'll do it eventually! I think enemies with weapons are slightly more aggressive too.
-Get some swords for annoying group fights, they can't block them bare-handed.
-Get used to heat actions that are initiated by grabbing and essence of rolling since that's basically free damage.

[b]Exploration & Substories[/b]
New to the series is Ryukyu, which is pretty comfy if I do say so myself. In a series that's so far focused on city life, it's nice to explore a place a bit more rural, with a good amount of substories focusing on its culture and how life is like there. While failable substories can be a bit annoying, There being one where you play hide and seek with Kiryu's kids is very cute.
Kamurocho has some enjoyable stuff as well, the first time you can explore it at a good run speed (compared to ps2) with a free camera and some nice substories. Following up what happened way back in Yakuza 1's intro in 95 was a pleasant surprise and the journalist is pretty enjoyable for one that's sub-story only. Rikiya's substories helped the character a lot too.
Chase missions are fine when you figure out you can quickly stop pressing run for tight turns then start running again.
Accessing the item box from pay phones started here and it's super welcome. Having to go all the way back to a hideout to sort the box with your 9 item inventory in ps2 honestly demotivated me from playing a bit.
Weapon modding came here and it's fine here too, but I'd always rather try to just continue the game than gather materials for things I don't really need. I just come here to repair my swords.
Locker keys' sparkly spots aren't as obscured as the ps2 but now require looking in places you'd never otherwise. I do wonder how many have gotten them all without a guide 'cause I certainly don't have the patience.
Hostesses are back and as a carryover from the past game you need to complete all 9 to face Amon. I don't know why so many of these games have so many, they're never that interesting.

[b]Side activities[/b]
IF7 lets you fight past enemies and they get you a few new abilities, mostly not that useful but I'd still get the 'guard against swords bare-handed' upgrade if you're planning to face Amon.
Of course there's Karaoke which debuts in this game. They didn't go too far with it yet with Kiryu only having one song but at least the hostess songs are enjoyable enough and Kiryu has cute cheers.
Pool and Darts are new, and the batting cages now require you to aim the bat as well as time it. Quick tip, Pool and Batting is way easier with the mouse & keyboard if you're into completion. Darts is easier depending on the yakuza game you're in or maybe you'll have better luck than me in 3. I found it extremely brutal on controller though, same with Pool. With batting, just remember to time it with Kiryu's hands becoming steady rather than the ball. I'm pretty sure cee-lo, koi-koi and oichu-kabu debuted here too. 
Koi-koi you'll eventually get by remembering the hands, what cards are high-value and how they combine by playing. I'd recommend turning cherry blossom viewing off.
Fishing I actually found pretty fun, didn't even have that much trouble with the tuna though I played post-patch. It does take ages with the tougher fish though, especially in Y4.
Golf I also found actually pretty fun despite the complaints I heard about it. It's harsher than, say, Mario Golf but a bit of practice should get the golfing substory done. Just remember the wind, the way the ball rolls and the downhill spots when putting. Getting -5 for completion is however pretty dang tough.
Boxcelios is a nice little arcade game where you pay attention to glowy weak points and laser them. Just remember you're way faster when not firing.
There's also hostess maker which is really boring and returns in 4 for some reason.

[b]Misc.[/b]
Soundtrack's cool, favourite tracks are Sounds Storm and Receive and Stab You. Best Karaoke song is Saturday Night Lover. In the context of 'English speaking people that were seemingly just in Japan at the time and were probably given no direction', Donald Glover did a pretty alright job compared to the 'VAs' for the Mega Man ps1 games. Revelations are fun too but unfortunately don't get much better apart from the moves you get

That's all I can cover within character limit. While Yakuza 3 definitely has issues, it also added a ton for the series in terms of controls, exploration and minigames. If you're fine dealing with annoying enemies and exposition I think there's a lot to like here.

tl;dr, it's not a bad game, but it's not the best the franchise has to offer. A mediocre Yakuza game is still a good game relative to what else is on the market.
John Yakuza just wanted to retire to an island and foster a clutch of orphans, but then, as always, the reprobates of Kamurocho drag him back into a messy fight for something it's not clear he actually believes in but feels forever obligated towards. The story is fine, but follows the same main beats as all the other Yakuza titles. This time the villain is less compelling and we spend less time growing to dislike him. I went into the final battle not even aware it was the climax of the game. Story isn't the only aspect of this entry that's notably weaker than the others, though it's less forgivable since it doesn't have the limitations of an older game engine as an excuse. Combat is button-mashy and the visuals are PS3 era (but not bad - in parts even quite beautiful). This time around the side content is especially weak. Playing through the games numerically, I typically have a completion percentage in the high seventies to mid eighties. I finished this one at thirty-six percent and will not be going back for more.

125407258.review:
Out of each of the Yakuza games I've played, Yakuza 3 has been a rather strange one, but it is very much like the other Yakuza games with their serious and emotional main story with the various strange to comedic side stories existing throughout the game. 
However, out of each of the yakuza games, 3 has been my least favorite so far for two reasons. One being there are a few segments that feel like they were implemented simply to drag out the game time, even if they do invoke some of the same emotions as the rest of the story. The second is the combat itself, which the game unfortunately makes most of the combos and abilities you can get useless in most cases, and it took me the same amount of time to learn this game's combat as it did when I first started with Yakuza 0. 
Despite the flaws Yakuza 3 has, it's still a fun and brilliant game that I recommend anyone who's interested in playing the Yakuza series to play, even if you just play through it once. It's story is memorable, emotional, and entertaining, even during the more drawn out parts, the combat is still fun once you learn how to use it, all while the substories and the rest the game has to offer still lives up to that of a Yakuza game.

124747699.review:
Another day, another Yakuza game.

I was actually pretty nervous about this one given the fact it has the lowest steam score and videos online give the impression that this is the weakest game in the series.

After playing it all the way through per usual, I can confirm this as true, however its not a bad game. It's a perfectly serviceable Yakuza title, but its one that suffers from feeling like a filler episode with its awkward pacing and piss-poor gameplay changes.

It's the shortest Yakuza game yet, taking me around 15 hours to finish even with side content added into the mix. The actual plot of the game doesn't really kick off until you're about halfway through and because of this, the actual plot feels like it goes by at a lightning pace compared to previous titles.

At this point the formula is feeling pretty predictable and nothing happens that you aren't already expecting to. It has its moments, but this mostly felt like a filler story that could've been cut out entirely and not much would've changed.

As for the gameplay changes, it basically feels like the worst parts of Kiwami amplified. The regular fights feel like for the most part, but the bosses can take way longer than they should due to overly large health bars and the fact that they block almost every single attack type in the game. Heat takes a stupid amount of time to build up unless you're under the alcohol buff, so you need to become a straight up alcoholic if you want to use your heat consistently. The progression system feels weak and restrictive, leading to a very stop-start style of progression rather than natural growth. It's probably the easiest Yakuza game, but the fights are also probably the most tedious. Not to mention that they halved the evade's effective distance, making it basically useless in all combat.

The substories this time around are mostly incredibly short check-list quests that don't offer much additional meaningful gameplay this time around.

I could go on for a while, but truth be told, its just a very weak entry. My stance is that I would recommend playing it through one time if you're a fan of the series, but its definitely not an entry I would be revisiting.

It just barely gets a positive rating out of me simply because I never felt like putting it down during my playtime, but at the same time, its the least special of the Yakuza games so far.

Playtime: 45 Hour (ingame)/ 51 Hour (Steam)
Diff: Normal

Synopsis:
A Remastered Yakuza 3 with some cut content back

A year after the Kanto-Kansai all-out war, Kazuma Kiryu and Haruka Sawamura have left the unforgiving streets of Kamurocho for the island of Okinawa to run the Morning Glory Orphanage. Despite his efforts, shadows of Kiryu's past threaten to entangle the Morning Glory Orphanage in a deadly power struggle involving the Tojo Clan and political world.

Thus begins a dramatic tale set in the ""sleepless city"" of Kamurocho in Tokyo and the tropical lands of Okinawa. Can Kiryu rescue the children of the orphanage from the looming threats emerging from the depths of the underworld and state power?

+The story

-The pacing for main story is weirdly fast

=Don Quijte song is cut (licensing issue) for this to Yakuza 5 remastered
=Haruka Trust

124270672.review:
Honestly this game isnt worth playing other than to see Kiryus story through.
I wish I could give a middle or neutral thumb because this isnt an outright bad game. It's just okay.
The story is fine but starts off at a glacial pace gets to a nice momentum around the middle of the game and then writes itself into a corner so badly that it needs a 30 minute exposition dump. The final chapters fall into the usual tropes and cliches of the series and after having played 4 games a certain tiredness of it is starting to set in for me personally. Certain emotional moments feel very artificial and cheap because of this. I generally liked most of the characters in the story and didnt even mind the orphanage parts that much. It's just a pretty standard Yakuza story overall and nothing special.

However the gameplay is where it starts to become really hairy to me. To get the obvious elephant in the room out lets start with the combat. The combat is fine in my opinion. Its much slower paced than in the other games but I generally didnt mind it most of the time. I actually had fun  in the moments the game allows you to pull of the combat techniques unique to this game like wall bounces and parries. However the combat also starts to introduce a gripe of mine that affects pretty much everything in this game. It wastes the players time so hard it becomes actively infuriating. Every street encounter starts with a forced pause of having to read the same text box dialogue and watch the slow ass intro camera pan as it introduces Generic Gangster #15152 again. It adds up to like 15 seconds of wait time before every single encounter. Sometimes you even have to start off the fight with a QTE that does barely any damage other than having you wait even longer.

This trend of time waste continues in the sub stories which are riddled with long pauses to mask loading times and annoying fetch quests. Theres a few good ones but this game really went towards quantity over quality when it comes to substories. I generally enjoyed my time doing substories but couldnt help but roll my eyes when it had me walk to the other side of the map again to look for an random NPC in some street over and over. This is made worse by map traversal being super annoying. The game misses the dash feature and the option to avoid enemy encounters the later games have. Fast travel is only a minor help in this regard as taxis are few and only placed at the border of the map.

But the actively worst part of the game are the minigames. Almost all of them suffer from clunky controls, janky physics or a glacial pace. The Hostess Maker minigame in particular doesnt just waste your time by being slow as molasses but is also completely intransparent in its mechanics. It's an unenjoyable minigame thats pretty much requires using a guide. I had fun playing Boxcelios though.

Overall I cant really recommend this game to anyone other than diehard Yakuza fans who want to see the entirety of Kiryus story start to finish.

123991023.review:
This was without a doubt the weakest in the series so far for me, but that isn't saying much considering the quality of 0, 1 and 2. The story was the strongest part of the game by far, only lacking in its pacing. By the end I was well invested and stopped pissing in order to see what happens next, but at the start I was dead ass thinking of doing biology revision instead due to it suffering from this little issue: It was fucking boring as shit. The villain and supporting cast in this game were spot on with Rikiya, Nakahara and Mine being the highlights among some of the shitter characters like Richardson.
However, The part in which this game suffered the most was in the combat and world. The combat felt less satisfying than shoving porridge up my ass, and was easy to button mash or repeat the same x x x y y combo over and over in my experience (then again that is partially my fault for being a boring ass guy and not spicing things up, although the game never really encouraged that all too often). Next, the world was nice and big yes, but I felt as though it was quite lifeless in comparison to prior games. I was never all too eager to explore and when I did it felt like a chore to engage in any of the activities or side quests I stumbled upon, which removes half the fun of a Yakuza game. So I often spent my time rushing through and trying to get to the next main story quest a lot more than in the others which kind of blows hard. 
Some of the main story quests were tedious as shit as well e.g. Finding any of the annoying shits in chapter 10 (this was the game's lowest point and was frustrating as paper stuck in your ass when you go for a shit).

Overall the game was pleasant compared to most, however, it lacked something present in the other games that led to me disliking a lot of the time I spent in between main story quests and especially the shitty start of the game. Also the karaoke sucked in my opinion (at least in comparison to 0 and kiwami 1 + 2).
7/10

123915610.review:
This game is old and rough and it shows.

if you thought the minigames in y0, yk1 and yk2 are bad, then this game would make you pull your hair out. Pool is downright broken and if you are used to darts controls in the previous games then kiryu plays darts like he's permanently drunk with parkinsons disease. you have to throw with near exact 50% power (with no power meter) or you throw WAAAAY off target. The worst part is completion actually gets you useful items, and said darts completion means beating 6 players in 3 different games each. 

This is also the first iteration of the karaoke  minigame and it is terrible. You'll constantly have to read multiple lines at a time to anticipate keypresses at the beginning of the next line, and the tempo is all over the place, so the cursor keeps changing speeds and you won't be able to anticipate any timings. There is also apparently like a 1 pixel difference between perfect, good, and bad so it's also very unforgiving this way too, and bads/misses seem to detract from your score a ton more than the remake titles. 

The screenshots on the store page make the game look worse than it really is, but you can make it even better by using HD graphical mods. Using the YK2 kiryu model especially helps. 

The combat is not as bad as I've heard, but it's still not great. normal battle difficulty = enemies block almost everything. Easy difficulty = enemies almost never attack. There is no good balance. If you want to play it to get the lore, play it on easy just to get through it.

123841273.review:
Note: I've previously played this game's PS4 remastered release. 

Yakuza 3 or as some love to call it Blockuza 3, is nowhere near as bad as people say and think it is. I personally really love it for how insane the conspiracy is and it has one of my favorite antagonists, [spoiler]Yoshitaka Mine[/spoiler]. Yes, the story can drag at times but it's a crazy conspiracy that needs time to unravel, although I will say the Okinawa parts can drag and distract (not in the best of ways) from the plot. The combat is fine considering what mainline game came before it which was Yakuza 2 on the PS2 which I played just before playing this one as I only played the remake of the game before. You can get Kiryu's greatest combat tools very early on too, if you don't just b-line straight through the story. However, that doesn't excuse the issues that can be found in this port such as poor dead zone and broken quick-stepping. That being said, you can install a mod to fix the quick-stepping. There's also mods to make it more in line with the original release visual while keeping the higher definition. 

Yakuza 3 is a solid entry in the series, if you're coming off of Kiwami 2 and playing this game. It's going to be rough because you're playing a game that predates the remake by 8 YEARS. There's going to be things that aren't as well done as they are in later entries like 0 or the Kiwami remakes. Just because it's technically crusty and somewhat dated in game design doesn't mean it should be skipped. It's just as valuable as other entries.

If I could give a 'mixed' reaction to this game, that's exactly what I would give it. When compared to the previous games of the franchise, Yakuza 3 tends to be even more convoluted, poorly paced, and it has some extremely questionable writing choices. The combat was also really unbalanced, so much so that I just gave up and played through in easy mode.

Of course, it's not all negative - the game does retain a lot of the charm that comes with being a Yakuza game, and a lot of the characters are developed quite well. The sub-stories are still quite fun, and it seems like the writing team concentrated more on those than the main plot. Heck, there were even quite a few enjoyable moments in the main plot, so long as you don't spend too much time worrying about the consistency of it.

I'll just give this one a grudging positive, simply due to how much I love the series on the whole.

123501009.review:
The worst version of Yakuza 3 mechanically

- Heat drains significantly faster than in the orignal game, making it near impossible to maintain heat
- Enemy behaviour is inconsistent with the original game, turning around near instantly. This makes most backhit and quickstep cancel combos from the original game impossible now (or RNG dependant)
- Enemy stun time after picking them up from the ground is significantly shorter now, making it no longer possible to get guaranteed combos from pickups
- Quickstep distance is halved, making navigating around enemies for backhits inconsistent (which is VERY important for Yakuza 3)

It's a shame, because this is the only way to play Yakuza 3 at a good framerate, but it's gameplay is a straight downgrade from the ps3 game.

What? You don't like the combat because "the enemies block too much"?

Sounds like a skill issue, the game gives you a wide variety of moves for a reason. Stop being stingy with heat actions and use them more (they also give you XP when you use them), use the Komaki Parry when they have a weapon, Tiger Drop their asses when they try to strike you, quickstep and attack from behind when they block too much (they can't block from behind), use Komaki Knockback when they're hitting you too much.

This is only a small portion of your abilities and these are already more than enough to make combat easier, unga bunga-ing your way through enemies won't work in this game and that's a good thing. I don't want to sound like one of those people but it really is just a case of getting good.

123081421.review:
After playing Yakuza 1 and 2 on the PS2, I have to say Yakuza 3 feels like a step backwards. Still, let's start with the positive aspects:

-This is the starting point for modern Yakuza games, tons of minigames, markers for sidequests, that huge and dreaded completion list. Some minigames are dated as fuck, yes,but it was a good addition and future Yakuza games would improve on it. 
-Being able to experience Kiryu's civilian side at the orphanage. Yeah, some missions are annoying and drag a little, but is nice being able to see Kiryu outside his tough guy persona. Makes him a little bit more interesting and enjoyable.
-Let me remind you, even if Kiwami 1 and 2 look a lot better than 3, compare Kiryu's model between Yakuza 2 and Yakuza 3. This game looks good and nostalgic, even though Kiryu's walk cycle makes me laugh.
-Combat is a mixed bag, but enemies blocking everything at least has some perks to it. You can't gorilla your way into them and you have to actually plan how to use your heat bar.

Now, let's talk about the negative aspects:
-Combat is really, REALLY annoying. I don't know why, but most enemies block all your attacks and early game is really painful. It ain't difficult or challenging, it is slow, it drags and most of all it sucks because most enemies are going to block your attacks mid combo. Just imagine a fighting game where your opponent could block your attack even if you didn't drop your combo. Well you somewhat can in Killer Instinct, but even in that game you can counter a counter. And even if you break your enemy's guard, they can guard instantly again. 
-The plot is weird and the main antagonist is not that interesting outside the memes. It feels like it comes out of nowhere and it lacks the impact from the previous two antagonists. Personally it didn't hook me that much and feels more like a filler episode just to traumatize Kiryu even more. 
-All versions of Yakuza 3 has cut content, even this version.
-Even though it demands less hardware than most recent games, framerate dips quite a bit in Kamurocho and civilians constantly bug out and their walk cycle and animations break constantly. This happens in almost all Yakuza games, but it is really weird seeing a huge group of civilians bugging out when you pick up a key or move in a certain way.
-Pacing is all over the place and the story takes a while to pick up, and once it picks up, it goes way too fast and many of its plotlines are either too convoluted or the game doesnt give them enough time to completely unfold making it feel a little too rushed.

In short, I dislike this game, but I still think it deserves to be played at least one time. Still, so far, for me, Yakuza 3 is the low point of the franchise.

Es un juego de sensaciones sobre todo si has jugado los anteriores te puede gustar o no el enfoque del juego ya que no son las situaciones de crimen de las anteriores entregas. Y tiene uno de los momentos que más recordaré en la saga.

Lo malo digo que el sistema de combate es muy tosco y los enemigos bloquean muchas veces tus ataques haciendo que sea difícil atacarles.

Me da miedo el siguiente juego de la saga porque el problema que tengo son los giros de guión absurdos que me veo venir destacando la historia del kiwami 2 que tiene bastantes problemas de historia.

122948529.review:
Being the most outdated in the mainline series thus far since 1 and 2 got remakes, It's very rough around the edges but still enjoyable. Features 119 substories, new features, great antagonists, and a great story. It definitely has a good bit of flaws. The game's biggest flaw IMO is it's lack of markers. Coming from Y0, K1, and K2, this flaw sucked a lot. Even in the main story, there aren't enough markers, let alone substory markers. God forbid I did all substories blind without gamefaqs telling me where stuff is. It gets annoyingly cryptic sometimes, even with a guide.

Still got a LOT of time out of it between all of its optional content, and I did enjoy the game. Definitely could use a remake, though.

Also it could be said that for a remaster, there's a couple things that could've been buffered out -- but they didn't. 

Make sure to get the quickstep restoration mod as the doubled framerate to 60 causes a quickstep to be roughly half as it usually is so I've heard. 

Although yakuza combat can pose some difficulty a lot of the time, this game is just very brutal. Get used to quickstepping behind enemies to their back, or else you will pay.

All in all a great journey with it's own atmosphere. The new setting introduced in this game is great.

122832431.review:
After the full remakes of Yakuza Kiwami and Kiwami 2, it now means that Yakuza 3 is the weakest technologically. The remaster improves a good number of environmental and key character textures, but it's very clear this is an earlier title. 

Altough Yakuza 3 is not quite as grandiose as the aforementioned entries, there's definitely a charm on it, this is the game that laid the foundations for the later entries, it's somewhat a different tonally from 0 and the Kiwami remakes, life in Okinawa is a bit of a different beast to the seedier parts of Tokyo, spending time in Downtown Ryukyu is a lovely change of pace from the bright lights of Kamurocho. Kyriu is different from what he was, it is great to see Kiryu in a different light.

Rest assured, that is just the beggining, there are those that love the change of pace and those that dislike the elongated length. I'm with the second portion, most downside to me was how it's pace is slow, but Yakuza 3 isn't a ‘bad’ game, as soon as you progress throught the game you are back at what you love in the franchise, an open-world crime drama with a large emphasis on gritty storytelling, hilarious substories, and allowing you to feel like a walking tank whenever you wander the streets of your chosen city, kicking the hell out of anyone that stands in your way. Upon your return to Kamurocho is where things pick back up plot-wise.

I tend to agree that it is one of the weakest in the series, the combat show their age and the enemies block too often, if you played another Yakuza before that it's definitely a let down. But it is still a solid entry and worth playing through to see the foundations of Kiryu’s later life beginning.

If you are invested in Kiryu's story, then skipping this game is a no go, each game builds and develops the world of yakuza and Kiryu. As with any Yakuza games, it's a novel story.

Going back to PS3 graphics after Kiwami 2 really wasn't that bad, I'm not sure why people were acting like it'd be such a big deal. 122750911.review:
I played this game twice, once on hard completing the story and once on legend doing nearly every single side story there is (more than 80), i can confidently say that this is the most cynical game a have ever played, i don't know what happened with the development of this thing but it came out wrong, by far the worst in the series. Every single element of this game seems designed to make you frustrated, sad, and angry.

The story simply stops so Kiryu can take care of the kids multiple times, and this is probably a me thing i fucking hated the guts of every single new character they added, first time i played this i still thought this game wasn't just made to piss me off and decided to be nice to Rikya (this game's Sayama except he always manages to find a reason to GTFO any time  he would be useful) and pay the entirety of our bill in the restaurant and the bastard set me back 60000 yen leaving me with nothing, every other new character does so little they barely exist or are even more obnoxious. And yes it is true that in the middle of their game they have a straight half an hour of exposition beacuse dumbass Kiryu is just stumbling around Kamurocho beating people up for half the story.

The enemies always play on the defensive so the only way to consistantly deal damage is to grab them again and again, it really feels like the random encounter dudes just want to not be defeated instead of defeating Kiryu, they fucking block all the time and if you try to play on punishing their attacks they will wait 45 seconds before doing the weakest, fastest punch they have, even with tiger drop and komaki parry i still couldn't get any enjoyment out of the combat, i really don't mind random encounters in any other game but in this one i wish i could turn them off.

The substories are either fighting one group of guys and reading a fuck ton of dialogue or they are spread by 5 chapters and none of them are engaging or funny, the ones that try to be fail but most of them don't even try.

So yeah if you want to save money/braincells skip this one, you won't miss any context when playing 4, 5 or 6 if you just keep in mind that Kiryu has an orphanage AND HE LOVES HIS KIDS SO MUCH HE WOULD SPEND THE REST OF HIS LIFE BEING AN ACTION DAD OR SOMETHING DON'T EVEN BOTHER WITH THEIR NAMES THEY AREN'T IMPORTANT EVER AGAIN (they weren't really important in this game either their parts of the story are paralell to the main plot) THEY APPEAR AGAIN ON THE END OF YAKUZA 6 AND THAT'S IT YOU GAIN NOTHING BY PLAYING THIS.

122651602.review:
so, just wrapped this one up and i gotta admit:
i was going into this game thinking this would be awful and yet i was surprised

id even say that this is my second or third favorite so far, due to how much I loved this game

PROS:
- gameplay is surprisingly fluid. this is probably the yakuza game with the best lock-on from what i've played and also how I like the idea of focusing more on exploiting the weak points of enemies due to their blocking addiction
- story was top class. it was so nice to see kiryu living at his highest point and spending time with his children
- majima
- most characters to me were very memorable and made me enjoy the time the game spends with them. cant say the same for most people in k1 or k2
- the music is actually pretty fire, from the street battles to fly i was jamming out so hard
- again, i knew every plotpoint and still i was crying like a baby at certain scenes. only few games can hook people despite already knowing how the story goes and i think that's incredible

CONS:
- there is no running in the game. while i think that its ok in the sense of being in kamurocho i sure as hell didnt like going through okinawa without the ability to sprint
- some bosses are bullshit as hell. for instance, one guy made me waste like a good ten items due to how BS he was with his instant counters, insane weapon hitboxes and super armor
- the sidestories and activities are honestly forgettable to an extent
- the whole chase mechanic (this will be elaborated further in my y4 review)

in all, this was an amazing game and definitely worth any yakuza fan's time. it may start out rough but trust me, the game gets better real quick

8/10 awesome sauce

122573471.review:
A very different state of the brawler game known from prior playing of the first 3 modern entries, mainly driven by the fact that the graphics are shaped from an older game engine used in the early PS3 era.  However, was an interesting difference to experience.  

The main story line (Dad simulator) and sub stories are cool as it takes place in both Tokyo and the new Okinawa setting. The pacing could have been better and other players may find some parts a drag and potentially boring, however I felt was manageable and gave the game its own unique spin in the series.

The mini games should also be better calibrated, however certainly felt a great sense of achievement once various hurdles were overcome.

Overall, I think Yakuza 3 is a nice game to play for all Yakuza series fans, just so to experience a unique title in the series and perhaps better appreciate the other modern titles down the road.

I played all of the substories but didn't do all the minigames but from the ones I played I would rank them from Favourites to boring: Karaoke - Pool - Batting - Coliseum - Mahjong and then Darts which got really annoying very quickly, I preferred the darts from Kiwami 2 but I suppose that's a ways away now considering it was a remake using Yakuza 6 as a base point.

Story was alright not the best but it has to live up to 0, Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2's story which were much better by comparison but I don't hold it against it there were moments which made me laugh out loud and moments which made me cry but I'm hoping it gets better from here.

121760631.review:
Great game for the story of Yakuza but the game shows its age now.

I absolutely love the story going through Yakuza 3 but I felt like a lot of the side content I found myself not being really drawn to like the more recent Yakuza games. While I absolutely love seeing the Father like moments with the kids at the orphanage some of the story missions that are mandatory for them felt like a hassle at time, slowing down the pacing of the main story. I think they would have be better relegated to Sub Stories.

Sub Stories at times felt very pointless and unnecessary. While some were great and had interesting stories, others would be simple and just there as fluff which felt pointless and a waste of time. The bigger sub stories like the Hostess maker you can see that they improved on in the newer games creating the Cabaret club and that the Hostess Maker was their original attempt at it, It does not hold up well anymore and is very boring.

I loved seeing Okinawa and getting to explore it (even though its relatively small), the vibe of Okinawa is a stark contract to Kamurocho. One is a bright beach like city while the other is a downtown city type of feel, I found my self wanting a larger version of Okinawa because the vibe was so different.

Overall Yakuza 3 is still a good game but definitely has its flaws from age, I would love to see a remake of it and have some of its content changed but otherwise I loved every bit of going through this chapter in Kiryu's life

121510871.review:
Games like this make me wish there was a middle ground on the review page.
[h1] I can only recommend this game for people who really want to see the story expanded after the first couple games. [/h1] 

Yakuza 3 is the first game to come out on new hardware, the Playstation 3. Unlike the PS2 games, it did not get a remake on a modern engine. It got an update to its graphical capabilities, like higher resolution and framerate.

Being the oldest, 'current' game of the series, it lacks the fighting styles of 0 and Kiwami, nor does it have the buttery smooth physics of Kiwami 2. Despite that it holds up fine, mechanically. The fighting isn't the issue I had with this game. The problem is the story is dreadfully boring.

Without summarizing the whole game, Kiryu opened an orphanage to distance himself from the yakuza lifestyle. A big part of the game is spent bonding with the children there, which ends up being going through loads of texts boxes, walking somewhere, then a ton more text. This isn't new for the series, but there's something fascinating about reading dialogue about the conspiracies and plots of criminals and scumbags.

The game could have offset the story with some more interesting game mechanics, but being the oldest of the modern games it can't hold up very well. It's a shame, because there are a few bosses and cutscenes I enjoy in this game. 

You should only consider getting this if you're a diehard fan of the series and are interested in what happens between the 2nd and 4th game, other than that you'll be fine skipping this one.

121011797.review:
The Yakuza games are all excellent, however this one in particular resonated with me the most despite the numerous flaws it might have. Yakuza 3 was the third mainline title and second PS3 title, this is important to note if you're coming from 0 and the Kiwamis, this will feel like a noticeable bump in the road if you've gotten accustomed to the modern Yakuza titles and remakes, as a result I implore you to check out the original PS2 titles before immediately jumping into this one to set your expectations.

If you're only interested in Yakuza's gameplay and never grew attached to the story nor characters, I would probably skip this one - where Yakuza 3 excels is in it's story, atmosphere and characters. Without getting into too much detail, the game definitely takes a bit to get going, and it will pull you into mandatory slice of life character interactions that won't be to everyone's taste, if you're able to set aside a few hours and really get yourself invested I think it really pays off.

As for the gameplay, I'm going to give a few recommendations now: when you get EXP, focus on upgrading your tech and body at first up until you meet Komaki (who at a specific point in the story will send a letter pointing to where he is) and relearn his moves. Coming from Kiwami 2's lack of a parry and especially K1's overpowered Tiger Drop, you might be conditioned to using the Tiger Drop as your counter of choice, however the Komaki Parry is far more effective as you'll have a wider window to hit it, it'll counter more attacks and allows you to accumulate more damage while they're stunned. The Daruma Tumbler also alleviates many of the problems with your quickstep introduced in the buggy "Remastered" port, at this point I'd focus on bringing heat and soul up.

So, with that in mind, I highly recommend this game if you don't mind some light grinding to sand down some of the rough edges, and you value the story, atmosphere and characters above all else. If you don't have the time nor particularly care to get super invested in the more slice of life aspect to the story and additionally want faster paced fights, I'd skip this one.

120700229.review:
I realize Yakuza 3 was a huge improvement over the original Yakuza 2 upon its release, but coming off the heels of Yakuza Kiwami 2, this was a bit jarring. The visuals and mechanics are definitely a "down-grade", but one must understand that Yakuza 3 is a product of its time. After an hour or two of play, the initial shock of jumping back in technical time melted away, and I was soon captivated by the story, characters, and locales.

A highlight for me was exploring Okinawa; I liked it a lot. It felt like a breath of fresh air, especially after having spent the majority of my time solely in Kamurocho in previous titles. I also enjoyed the characters and the tighter-knit relationships between them (especially the Ryudo guys and the kids at the orphanage). This felt like a more "wholesome" Yakuza game, if that makes sense. Compared to 0, Kiwami 1, and Kiwami 2, Yakuza 3's story isn't as grand, but still offers plenty of twists and turns.

Ultimately, I think the grander story and the motivations behind it isn't as compelling or as fulfilling as those found in past titles, but the well-written interpersonal developments of the kids at the orphanage and the boys at the Ryudo family more than made-up for it.

I found the sub-stories to be some of the best in the series thus far (having only played Kiwami 1, 0, and Kiwami 2, and now Yakuza 3, in that order). I also liked the slower pacing at times, playing as Kiryu and helping the kids with their struggles (at one point we all played baseball on the beach and it was a blast!). However, sometimes the greater focus on the orphanage clashes with the pacing of the main story. For example, things will come to a head in the main story, and it's nearing a climax, when that is suddenly deflated by Kiryu being forced to help the kids with mundane tasks before continuing the story. I liked the orphanage, watching Kiryu be a parent, and helping the kids, but I wish more of that was optional instead of being shoe-horned into the main campaign.

Also, a lot of the bosses resort to blocking, which kills the pace of fights. Weapons help, but sometimes I'd become frustrated trying to defeat particular bosses for fifteen minutes on end. That's probably my only gripe about the combat. I really liked the hitman missions though and the chases!

All in all, Yakuza 3, while being a product of its time (and having been developed in under a year, from what I've read), is a good game, and a good Yakuza game to boot. It's full of action, fun side quests, plenty of character development, cool locations, fun mini games (golf, anyone?), and a main story full of twists and turns. I recommend it!

120658040.review:
The general consensus of this game might be that it's the worse of the series / a mixed bag, but don't let that deter you: this is a Yakuza game like any other of the series. All the wackiness and crime drama we've come to love is still here. I got a lot of enjoyment out of it, even from the combat, which is rough compared to the later entries, but fun to master once you get the hang of it. The combat itself is more defense-oriented, so relentlessly attacking your enemies won't do much, since they block most of your attacks.

If you're planning to play the entire series for the first time, I recommend to start with this one since it's the oldest. Then progress as they released (y3 > y4 > y5 > y0 > y1 > y2 > y6 [I omit y7 since its combat system is totally different]). Even though the natural flow of the main character's development might get lost, you'll be able to feel how each game improved its mechanics. In doing so, you won't get hit with the downgraded gameplay some people experience when playing it in chronological order.

All in all, it's a great game. Give it a try at least :p

120640835.review:
Despite the spike in difficulty that most, if not all, yakuza players face after 0, K1, and K2 due to a variety of reasons such as:
1. You cannot become overpowered
2. Gaining experience is a pain
3. Heat becomes Cold in a fucking second

I still recommend this game. There's a wonderful story behind it, with its own moments and quirks that you will come to adore. Substories are always a charm, and so are some of the soundtracks of the game (D2A still haunts me).

Main complaint from pretty much everyone was the combat, some of which is genuinely fair. For instance, heat actions (blue and red gauge ones) do a lot of damage to henchmen, but barely any to boss fights. I understand why it was done like so, but it defeats the purpose of the red heat moves (for context red heat moves are meant to do a lot more damage than blue ones). So it becomes a lot more tedious than necessary. A few more savepoints and/or running in the game would have been very convenient too. 

Overall, not exactly the best experience but I'm still glad I played it. 7.5/10, gotta get through it to actually play 4, 5, 6, and LaD.

120547884.review:
I don't even really know what to say to be honest, I'm writing this review after just completing the main story line and I don't really know what else to say but wow. 

I won't lie, I was a bit worried that as I progressed through the Yakuza saga that the quality in these games would begin to fade, but I couldn't say how wrong I am so far. This game was no disappointment, and continues the pretty amazing theme of the yakuza games, as well as being able to evoke emotions just as well as the previous installments. 

As I stated before, the story of Yakuza 3 is great. I feel like it did an amazing job of allowing the player to create solid bonds and attachments to the other characters, especially that parental connection between Kiryu and the kids at his orphanage, and that brotherly bond with Rikiya. I thought at this point in the Yakuza series I would have experienced so many emotions through Kiryu, like his genuine happiness, sadness, or anger, that I would grow numb to it. Again, I was dead wrong, and Yakuza 3 accomplished all three of those for me once again. 

One thing I would like to especially address is the combat system for Yakuza 3. One of the main complaints I have seen for Yakuza 3 is that its combat system is lacking compared to its predecessors, or that people just straight up can't put up with it. I personally think it is too easy to just compare Yakuza 3's combat to 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2 just because they are so great, but on its own Yakuza 3's combat system was bearable to me, and honestly wasn't bad at all. To be absolutely fair, yes I do prefer and more enjoyed 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2's combat gameplay, but I also appreciated Yakuza 3's combat system in its own way. I truly hope that the combat system alone isn't what turns people away from this game, because those who do skip Yakuza 3 are missing out on a pretty amazing continuation of Kiryu's story. 

TLDR: I absolutely do recommend for the story alone, and once again I look forward to the next chapter, Yakuza 4 Remastered.

120470374.review:
TL;DR, Yakuza 3 suffers from some at times abysmally bad pacing, enemies block too much ESPECIALLY in the remastered version, and there are some DUMB pulls in the plot.
That said, it's in my top 3 favorites of the whole franchise, as much as I think they should be optional the stuff with Kiryu's kids is adorable and provides a really fun alternate perspective to watch him through, and Ryukyu is one of the absolute comfiest video game towns I've ever explored, bar none.

So, most of my problems with this game specifically lie with this specific port. Optimization is awful, load times take way longer than they SHOULD for how small these maps are, and... the Big One, because the game's framerate was increased from 30 to 60 FPS, Kiryu's quickstep is pitifully useless. The first two can't be easily solved, but you can find a patch on Yakuza 3's nexusmods page to (mostly) restore his quickstep to its original PS3 form.

You'll probably find yourself tempted to skip cutscenes from time to time, and you'll probably end up screaming at the screen for Kiryu to stop wasting time with his kids, but Yakuza 3 is a really, really good game, even in this compromised port. 
Pick it up, you won't regret it.

This game really needs the Kiwami treatment badly. The combat mechanics are pretty barren and the camera controls pretty unruly. It also throws a lot of mandatory minigames your way, which is really annoying. Whereas I actually enjoyed combat in the Kiwami versions, I just don't here. You do four light attacks and then a strong attack if the enemy doesn't block, and if the enemy blocks, you just have to keep hitting them with items because you're not hitting them any other way. Even then, good luck not getting constantly cheap-shotted and dropping the item you have to use in order to actually damage the blocking enemy. No, I'm not exaggerating. These enemies constantly block and you might get in one hit out of every 10 you do. Might.

Just watch the game on Youtube. I tried to push through and got to the fight at the love hotel and it was so frustrating at that point that I just didn't care anymore. This game is a slog compared to what comes before.

119850848.review:
[quote]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31884377-If-It-Is-Insane/]Check out my curator page for more awesome reviews[/url] 
[/quote]
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
While Yakuza 3 massively improved as a successor to the original Yakuza 2, it feels outdated, especially with the Kiwami treatment the first two games had. But it has some serious heart and contains a microcosm of the Yakuza series themes. 

[h1]Is It Worth Playing?[/h1]
Yakuza 3 is honestly pretty skippable. While the story advances and some important stuff happens to characterize Kiryu further, it is self-contained, having no direct consequences.
Addressing the elephant in the room:
Yakuza 3 is the oldest "original" game on Steam. It is a remaster but not a remake. Many players start Yakuza 3 after having played Yakuza Kiwami 2. And this is the single largest time difference within the series between two chronological titles (on Steam):
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a modern dragon engine game from 2017.
Yakuza 3 is PS3 title from 2009.
Ryu Ga Gotoku studios is a fast learner, and each entry improved massively in terms of quality. The exception is maybe Yakuza 6, as it was the first dragon engine to be released and shows clear signs of being rushed.
Yakuza 3 is the poster boy of the series for any growing pains.

[h1]Problem List[/h1]
Yakuza 3 has the single worst combat of any not remaked Yakuza. Enemies block too much, making battle too long to be enjoyable. Consider that damage in Yakuza 3 is relatively low: Most attacks are not impactful, leading to tiger drop and parry spam. 
Even worse: Both skills have to be unlocked, and entire boss fights become unplayable without them.
I can not stress how underwhelming most boss fights are and how many random battles become a chore.
Improvable and unfinished is a theme that permeates all facets of Yakuza 3. Minigames are not working to such a degree that players have to cheese many activities to reach a win:
Billiard and darts are barely functional because of an oversensitivity bound to the right joystick. Do not even get me started on bowling. The margin of error is utterly ridiculous. 
And mahjong...
Mahjong remained the same. Still, it pisses me off.
Even karaoke has some questionable design choices:
Why do new verses have instant button presses?

[h1]The Good Stuff(aka story)[/h1]
Yakuza 3 ties many of the themes together and showcases Kiryus softer side. His stoicism has become a famous quality of his character. 
Yet Yakuza 3 shows him at his most vulnerable and directly ties it to interact with the orphans he is raising. It is controversial for Yakuza fans how much time Yakuza 3 "wastes" on these orphans.
I agree that they are annoying, especially on subsequent playthroughs. But when Yakuza 3 hits its respective highs, it sets the bar high.
And they are a part of it. Kiryu is a good guy who chose a bad hand.
Had he given up on being a Yakuza like was told him in the past, he would not have had to endure so many hardships. 
But when does a human earn absolution?
Yakuza 3 has an answer to this problem:
[spoiler]It does not matter if someone has earned absolution. 
One mistake can and sometimes will haunt your life and penetrate every aspect. There are only some moments we get to decide what kind of person we want to be.[/spoiler]
Making Kiryu a vulnerable human is the single greatest achievement of Yakuza 3 and impossible to overstate. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Yakuza 3 is objectively a worse title than any other Yakuza title on Steam (as of writing this review in 2022), maybe even including Streets of Kamarucho.
But it contains story segments of the Yakuza series that have payoff unique to this game and makes me sincerely happy to have pushed through.

I would say it's the weakest in the series, specially the combat, but still good. 

Yes, the Blockuza nickname is accurate, and even the weakest enemies will block everything you do, making combat boring at best and a pain in the ass at worst. However, every time the game did something annoying, it made me forget it later with some really good boss fight, or a soundtrack full of ABSOLUTE BANGERS.

The main story is well written, although I did have some problems with it, like how [spoiler]Sayama gets sent to America for no real reason[/spoiler], and a few cliches that made it hard to take certain moment seriously, aside from that, the main plot is good and the characters are interesting (Shoutout to Rikiya).

Side content is nice, with some great substories and neat minigames, althought 100% is annoying.

The game is good, but don't play it if you just want good combat, and don't play on hard unless you are really into beat 'n ups.

As for the elephant in the room,the combat is the worst in the series if we ignore the PS2 Yakuza games,feels stiff,they even butchered it more in the remastered cause dodging doesn't have any distance without a fix that you have to download. And the fact that heat actions are next to useless on bosses,the only times they are worth it are on the normal goons you see on the streets.

Substories are decent and the cabaret club girls you visit at Flawless have decent backstories and what not but still.

If you wanna binge through the whole series and play it to see for yourself,go for it,but if you only care about the story and not the gameplay at all,I`d say to just skip this one.

[h1] 5/10 [/h1]

119362339.review:
I have waited for a long time to write this negative review.

It's not [i] terrible [/i] by any means--in fact, it might be pretty good for a casual/normal playthrough. Definitely don't skip this one if you're playing the series. But if you're going for 100% completion, it's a different story.

Yakuza 3 has the unenviable distinction of being the oldest Yakuza game you need to play to finish the series, since 1 and 2 were remade (Kiwami 1/2). So while the really crusty PS2 entries get upgraded to the Yakuza 5/6 engine, Yakuza 3 is still just an early-generation PS3 game. If you play the Yakuza series in chronological order, the games tend to improve on the technical details as you go from Y0 to YK1 to YK2; then you hit Y3 and turn back the clock by 8 years. It's a really difficult adjustment. Everything is worse: the graphics, the combat, the controls, the minigames, everything. Not really its fault, it's just...a much older and less refined game.

The combat stands out as especially bad. Enemies hold guard and refuse to attack--some for 30 seconds at a time, some forever. I've seen a few old heads talking about how the new games have lost their way, how Y3 is so much more sophisticated...nonsense. It's just stiff, slow, and broken. Kiryu drops objects after getting hit once, and takes 5 seconds to pick anything up, so they're useless in a tough fight. Half the enemies are un-grabbable, mashing out instantly, which makes it actually impossible to break their blocks. Especially in the coliseum, the only move that matters is the ever-broken Tiger Drop. Speaking of...the coliseum. No other word for it: just pure CBT.

The experience of "immersion" is also much worse in Y3. (Maybe I'm just spoiled by YK2, but, that's the point!) Rather than randomly generating NPCs dynamically, there is a library of maybe 30 fixed character models that get reused everywhere. It's very common to spot identical NPCs walking next to each other--a glitch in the matrix, maybe? Further, the NPCs that might aggro you are a small, fixed subset. The fat guy with the ugly red/white/blue shirt with the black christmas tree on it? 80% chance he wants to fight. Black guy carrying a guitar case? 0% chance, ever. Also, when you pan the camera to turn a corner, the street is always completely empty. Then the NPCs start to fade in over the course of 5-10 seconds. It's super noticeable and distracting.

Even the controls are messed up. It's impossible to get Kiryu to run in a straight line; instead, he swerves left and right all the time unless you're at 1.0 cardinal. I think it's this same glitch that makes pool unplayable without using some bizarro claw grip to keep the analog stick [i] perfectly [/i] centered.

I'm also really missing the "completion list" system of games past. Now, instead of using 20/40/60/80 different heat moves to tick boxes and finish the list, you have to use every single heat move (and craft every single piece of equipment). It's much more hard-core. I can see the appeal, I guess, but it's also way more tedious and made the march to 100% turn into a total slog towards the end. The scavenger hunt for crafting items for weapons I will never use was just stupid, as was roaming the map for an hour waiting for a random encounter with a sword-wielding enemy (~2% chance?) so that I could use a specific heat action that requires the enemy to have a sword.

Some of the minigames are total misses. The create-a-hostess one comes to mind: pick random dress-up items, go out on the floor and get totally ignored because you are so unfashionable, randomize outfit and repeat until you randomly find a decent setup. Good luck doing that without a guide! Maybe if you do linear algebra for fun. The hitman missions are total, absolute filler. And I already mentioned about pool...

Even after grinding for 100% completion, I still never finished leveling up Kiryu. Just seems like they didn't bother to balance the XP rewards vs requirements at all. No idea how long it would take to XP grind 2 more levels, but after finishing all the substories and the coliseum...why even bother?

There are still some positives. The substories are definitely more creative, interesting, and funny compared to YK2, and even more so compared to YK1. It makes sense--the writing is the one thing that didn't get "remade" in the Kiwamis. The plot is over-complicated, sappy, and predictable--yeah, that's right, it's a Yakuza video game plot. The bits at Morning Glory are a nice change of pace, but don't forget about all the other crap that happens along the way. (Or, maybe you did forget?) Still doesn't hold a candle to Y0 in either department.

And I have to give credit, the new location is genuinely great. You can really feel the different pace of the Sotenbori compared to Kamurocho. It's smaller and a bit gentler overall, somehow, which fits the intended vibe perfectly. Maybe that's the one part of this game that's aged gracefully.

So should you play this game? Honestly...yes you should. Whether you're playing the Yakuza series for the plot (???) or you're already on the 100% train like I am, it doesn't make sense to skip Y3 or to stop here. I'm sure it gets better from here on, right? But you should go in with realistic expectations--this is the nadir of the series in terms of gameplay and presentation.

119163935.review:
After fully completing this game from my previous review (Which was about 6 Hours) I'm finally ready to give my full thoughts on Yakuza 3: The most controversial game in the franchise.

Starting off the story is my 2nd favorite in the franchise (barring Like A Dragon), with a lot of wholesome moments for Kiryu to be himself instead of just "Cool Guy McGee", helping out in the orphanage helps you get attached to Kiryu's kids, including Kiryu himself, you see a sensitive side to the Ex-Yakuza that most games before (and after with 0) haven't shown. and by the time the real story begins, you fall in live with every character in the game, especially the Ryudo Family, which gives a hard gut-punch in the last few chapters, especially if you really like Rikiya  (we'll get to him soon). The weakest part for the story would have to be it's pacing, it feels too short, it feels about the length of a DLC Story mode, let alone an entire game, but the short pace still gives one of the best Yakuza stories to date. The voice work is great, especially the somewhat corny English voice acting, but Kiryu's VA absolutely gives what I believe is his best performance so far/since, with  [spoiler] Rikiya's Death [/spoiler], the guy you see as being the coolest sunuvabitch, gives one of the most emotional and heart-wrenching performances of all time, this time, Kiryu doesn't feel like a cool guy to insert yourself in, but an actual character.

Now to get back to the game and not the story, time to tackle the most controversial parts of the game: The Combat, and I'll be honest, it's not the best combat in the series, but I do think that it's not as bad as people say. Yes the blocking is a problem, but there are multiple solutions to stop it, to me the worst part was all the bosses who stun-lock you, and the gun users in the later parts of the game, [b] those [/b] are the worst part of the game, not the blocking. Other than that, the combat is solid, and given that this is my first time experiencing Kiryu's Dragon Style for the rest of the series, it does a good job at getting me used to a moveset I'm sure I'll get antiquated with for the rest of the series. Honestly, the only part of the game that I really hate is how wonky the camera controls are, but given that this is a remaster rather than a remake, I'm willing to give it a pass.

I'm going to avoid giving reviews to the substories and the extra content because A. They aren't as important as the main story, but are solid, and B. I didn't do most of the minigames.

And so, this game isn't as horrible as people say it is, but it isn't some hidden gem of the Yakuza series that people are overlooking, it's a solid game, that most people have trouble with. 8/10, would recommend, but wouldn't play again.
