118996073.review:
As someone who adores this series, I'll be honest, after the first few hours I eventually had to take a break from the game. The intro is nice and it all definitely has it's appeal/charm, but eventually I found it just got a bit tedious. Also, to address the elephant in the room, this is probably the worst that combat gets in the series.


With all of that out of the way though, I would still absolutely recommend the game.
While the combat may be a bit iffy — especially if you have just come from playing 0 or the Kiwami games — it doesn't take too long to get used too, and once you start to build up your collection of special moves and combos through levelling I'd argue it's not even an issue (and you can get to that point pretty early game trust me). For what it's worth I actually found myself really enjoying the combat as per usual once I had a few good moves in my arsenal.

Also, if you happen to play this game and find yourself getting tired of running around doing errands in Okinawa, I heavily advise you to see it through a bit longer, as I myself happened to put the game down for almost a year just before finishing the intro section because I had gotten bored, but once I returned to it I felt like I was playing a whole new game. If you dislike the intro then don't worry, the game immediately increases in quality once it's done (and I mean immediately).

In summary:
- Please do play game, and while it may be a bit slower at first, it gets incredible pretty abruptly and early on.
10/10

118948248.review:
Its hard to rate Yakuza 3. If you played the previous 3 games (0,1,2) then you probably should play this game just to experience the story and the progression of Kiryu as a character. The story is still pretty important and its still pretty fun even if there are a bit too many bait and switches with the story beats. The characters in the story are enjoyable and I especially really liked the main villain of the game. But the story alone is not enough to make me forget the horrible time I had with so many other parts of the game.

The combat in this game is infamous and after playing for like 3 hours you will notice why. The enemies block everything, compared to Kiwami 2 its a LOT more boring mechanically. Not only that but it seems like enemies are designed to waste your time, they will be in spots where its impossible to avoid them and their attacks will constantly knock you down or stun you. Its horrible and this is the first yakuza game where I actively would avoid the gameplay part of the game. The rewards you get for fighting in this game are laughable and the time wasted feels horrible.

In general if you are coming off of Kiwami 2 then this game will really give you a rough wake up that this is a PS 3 game. EVERYTHING feels slower, walking from location to location, finding substories, playing mini games, even something as small as going through the menu is for some reason slightly slower. All those quality of life features from the recent games are not present and result in a drag of a game to play.

I have to give special mention to Bowling and the Hostess side activities. To get all Substories you have to score 200 points on bowling, romance 10 girls and raise 1 girl to perfection. I kid you not that I might have spent like 50 % of my time just on these horrible mini games. Thats 12 substories that take like 25 hours to complete. Bowling for some reason has some of the wonkiest physics in the entire game and the hostess mini game takes like 10 x longer compared to all the previous iterations without any of the mini games the previous games provided as a break in between. It makes you want to pull out your hair in boredom. I enjoy getting 100 % substories and fighting the Amon fights at the end of the yakuza games, that makes it all the more frustrating that I can't skip these terrible parts of the game.

But alright thats enough complaining. There are some things the game does well besides the story. The game introduces 3 new things which are pretty fun, there is a new running mini game where you chase people. I really enjoyed this and constantly looked forward to seeing what parkour courses the game would throw at me. The 2nd new thing is that Kiryu is now blog posting which allows him to learn new moves, its a really funny way of learning new moves and maybe one of my favorite new additions to the game. Most of the substories are fine with the few exceptions I mentioned. The chase substories in particular are quite fun and there are also some substories which are part of the main story which also usually are pretty fun. 

The last new thing I have to mention is huge, a new location. From the start of the game you play in a completely new location with new people. Welcome to Okinawa, its a really nice change of pace from Kamurocho and Soutenburi. I think practically all the best substories are tied to this new location and its a joy to explore and learn more of the differences in cultures compared to the previous locations. Its nice having a relaxing location and exploring Kiryu not as a yakuza or how he deals with the yakuza, but instead looking at how he deals with situations where he can't just solve everything with violence. He now works at an orphanage. Raising kids is hard and I am happy to see they at least somewhat represented the constant internal anguish on what to do in Kiryus character during the game.

Like I said I thought Yakuza 3 was a hard game for me to review. Its enjoyable and can be finished really fast if you want it to, if it was purely that I would absolutely recommend this game. But I am looking at this from a gameplay perspective and a substory completionist perspective and from that vantage point I would not recommend this game at all. As it stands I would only recommend this for people who just want to play more Yakuza and want to see where the story goes after Yakuza 2. I sadly can't recommend this as an action RPG.

118937067.review:
DISCLAIMER: I only played as far as chapter 5 and my experience is based on hard mode 

Yakuza 3 is a truly miserable experience. Every single review talking about how each and every enemy in the game blocks every single one of your attacks from the front is true. And their blocking ability is pretty much absolute. Can't break that. But Yakuza fans will probably tell you to just get good and quickstep around enemies so that you can attack their backs. Too bad that the quickstep in this game moves you about a millimeter to the side while locking you into its animation for about a second and thus is incredibly ineffective. And even if you manage to hit a boss in the back in this game, Kiryus damage output is pathetic. His attacks truly just tickle bosses in this game and he has never felt this weak.
"But have you tried grabbing the enemies?" Sure, while that is a way to deal with the constant blocking, it doesn't improve the gameplay. If the optimal way to play a game is to staple a dipping bird toy to a specific button on my controller, I'd rather not play the game at all.

Okay, so the combat is terrible but if you are playing the Yakuza series, chances are, you are probably here to experience the story. Well, I've got bad news. Even that isn't very exciting. [spoiler] We've got mysterious guys in black suits with sunglasses as bad guys again, foreigners (and are probably gonna fight the chinese mafia AGAIN),
and according to a cutscene early on, the main villain is a guy with a dragon tattoo... AGAIN. Bla, bla, there can only be one dragon and all that. Come on Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio, this is the third time (if you started with 0) that you are bringing a guy with a dragon tattoo as a final boss to class to pull the whole only one dragon shtick again. It's getting really old. [/spoiler]
Some new and likeable characters get introduced in this part of the series but if they only get used to retread the same old plot threads from previous games, meshed together in a very slightly different way than the last time around, then their potential as characters is just getting wasted.

I really liked the Yakuza series up until now and even learned Mahjong to be able to deal with its minigames, but this game made me want to stop playing the series and maybe return to it at a later point since it just does not feel good to play and experience at all. Sure it is old. Sure the newer parts are better. But I am an old guy who has played a lot of old games and enjoyed them. I just really don't enjoy playing this one.

118928715.review:
I am going recommend this game on the sole basis that its part of the series. I would say buy it but don't expect the same smoothness that we have in Yakuza 0, YK1 and YK2. I really didn't enjoy the story line on the occasion to be honest because whilst I am not going to ruin any surprises but let's just say that the bit before the ending was stupid to say the least. Especially as Kiryu being a man of his caliber would have seen it coming a mile away. 

The game controls feel quite cumbersome when using a keyboard and I had to cap the FPS to 30 to stop the game running in high speed mode so if the game runs too choppy and erratic on modern graphics cards then please set the FPS to 30 as it will run stable then. 

As for the AI, the AI seems to be lacking the quantum setup with around 96% guard that forces the player to use guard break and counter attacks. It had more randomness to it on the other games in this series. One the latter boss missions without mods is another frustration as the damage ratio is way too low and being able to block Kiryu hitting him with a sofa should still take damage when it strikes. Sadly there is a lack of finesse that the previous Yakuza games I have covered have and I would only recommend this if you want the whole collection like me. 

Its an experience for me and personally I think the storyline should have been better thought out. Time to play the next one. Of course. I am open to debate and not everyone will agree with me and that is fine. 

6/10.

118686221.review:
Don't get me wrong with the Negative review, I enjoyed a good part of the game, however the stretch marks were very clear this time around. Most notably with pacing of the story. As well as a few other things.

As for the story, when the game gets to the plot, it's quite a trip, the game did an excellent job making me enjoy the new characters, for the most part, namely Rikiya and Mikio. As it stands, the plot of using a giant land deal to take over the Tojo clan is creative, and left me guessing who the major shakers were until the last.

Combat wise. Even coming off of Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 2, I found the overall flow of combat to be actually rather fun! Kiryu doesn't start out with EVERYTHING but gaining the abilities he had before, and gaining some really sick new skills was enough to keep things relatively fresh through the play through.

Here in lies the problem with this game, and it seriously mars down the feeling of it, enough that even with a fantastic finish, and enjoyable new cast... the game drags it heels [i]everywhere[/i] to an almost infuriating degree. many Substories feel pointless, others are tedious and drag on for too damn long, but even the best are generally held down by the reward problem. Most of the rewards are crap! Never mind the pittance of exp that they give!

The leveling is also a problem I find. the game is not shy about asking for a huge amount of exp to get one skill or health boost. but than rewards at most 10 points for a substory and no useful reward besides maybe a plate or some crafting material. 

The worst offender of heel dragging is chapters 2-4 and 10, where the game just stops and drags for several hours to establish the character of each of Kiryu's kids and the local Yakuza of Okinawa. Which of course, I didn't mind for some of it, it was inevitable that Kiryu would be allowed to have some time to just be a dad or a friend to Okinawa's people... but 3 chapters dedicated to extremely mundane main quests and even more mundane sub story after sub story killed the pace of a story that has not even had time to start! 

And worse, returning to Okinawa for Chapter 10, they double dip for what could have easily been a sub story in itself! 

I reiterate: I love the story, I love the combat, and I love (some) sub stories. But the game is marred down so much by content that should have been left to sub stories!

Also fuck the trust system! It's just tedious grinding for items with no in world pay off. Rikiya's tourist visit through Kamurocho was a far better trust story than whatever that ungodly meter game is.

Play the game for the story, do sub stories if you feel under powered. Don't even bother with mini games.

118076281.review:
Yakuza 3 is as much 'good weird' as any other entry in the franchise, but sadly, it also packs more 'bad weird' than others too. Coming to this one after Yakuza 0, Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2 feels like an obvious stepdown. To begin with, this is a remaster, not a remake, and after Kiwami 2's stunning Dragon engine, the graphics this time feel quite dated and janky. 

All of the above would be forgivable if there weren't massive pacing problems with the plot. The main story is far more ridiculous and over the top than ever before, but that's okay, its a Yakuza game after all. But the way that plot unravels: slow at first, then with breakneck speed, then coming to lurching halt, then dumping an enormous and boring information on your head before returning back to its careening fall to the ending. That is to say, it is insufferably bad. It has been so bad in fact, that I put the game down midway and picked it up after what was, essentially, a whole year.

There are nice things here too. The two sides of Kiryu, one of staunch and respected mafia, and other, the loving and caring fatherly figure overlap creating an unexpected amount of character growth, but ultimately, the story takes over with its sillyness. All the fun that a standard Yakuza game offers is here too, but considering the overall setting, it feels tacked on. There is an option to pursue all those activities after the events of the game have transpired, but I just can't care enough to go in the game again after I have put it down.

In summary, this is a poor title, both in the Yakuza series and as a game in general.
5/10, Buy it only if you are a Yakuza fan and want to see Kiryu's story pan out.

117838786.review:
This game is really fun. I'd heard a lot of negative things going in; mainly that enemies block and dodge too much. I put the game on Hard to start, and I find this AI entertaining. 

In neutral, you have to carefully space attacks, whiff-punish, or time dodges correctly to attack enemies from behind. The counters and parries are almost mandatory compared to other entries, and Heat attacks are extremely valuable. 

I also think the storytelling for the orphanage was handled in a satisfying and nuanced manner. That was an area where RGG Team really could've cheesed it up, but they showed restraint here. 

I've got a beat-'em-up background though, and I appreciate the extra challenge. One of my complaints with Yakuza 0 (a game I find stellar) is that it's more entertaining combat-elements can be ignored in favor of mashing. Not so much in Yakuza 3.

Tread carefully if you're just here to mash through a Yakuza story, but I'd recommend this entry specifically if you're a fan of beat-'em-ups and the Yakuza series.

117732317.review:
[h1] Whether this is the worst game or not, I still think it's a decent game [/h1]

Ah yes, Yakuza 3. The title that sparks debate amongst every Yakuza fan who has played the entire series. The title that first introduced the mold of the modern Yakuza game by adding karaoke among other extra minigames, the game that gave us the first dynamic intro in the history of Yakuza games, and the title that first employed the use of face capture to give us the iconic faces of Kiryu and Majima that we know of today. 

I'll start with the story. Story is overall really good or really bad depending on how you see the orphanage sections of the story. For context, you will spend entire chapters purely on taking care of the kids in Morning Glory and being a proper father figure to them. A lot of people have been complaining about how these specific parts of the story are dragging and completely uninteresting, but personally I actually love these parts. It shows us another part of Kiryu that's usually not too noticeable in the other games, his compassion. It's hard to imagine the same guy who was roughing up delinquents in the streets of Kamurocho cry over cut onions in a dish he's making for his kids. But the game gives us exactly that and further emphasizes that underneath that big, burly structure with a dragon tattoo, he's human and has emotions (ignoring his physical capabilities at least). Whether those sections are a big turn off for you or not, they did a pretty good job at delving deeper into the character that is Kazuma Kiryu. The characters that are introduced here are really fleshed out and the villains have a menacing aura that's unique to each one of them. The final boss is a very well done antithesis to Kiryu this time around (they even have opposing tattoos!). [spoiler]Mine[/spoiler] is a work of art in terms of video game villains. My nitpicks about this would probably be how one villain was underutilized considering his introduction cutscene and another character that could have made Kiryu and Haruka grow even more was completely written off within the first chapter and shipped off to the Land of the Free. Other than that, story's as solid as the rest of the series.

Now onto the most controversial part of the game, the combat. Now this is something that's undeniably a flaw in the game and it alone could and should warrant a Kiwami 3. I'm not sure about the lower difficulties but on Hard, everyone (AND I MEAN EVERYONE) has the reaction speed of a fly when it comes to blocking your moves. You quite literally cannot start an offensive against any enemy, even the common street thug, coz of that sole reason. To top it all off, they actually had to nerf the quickstep distance in order to keep up with the increased frame rates the Remastered collection gives ([url=https://www.nexusmods.com/yakuza3remastered/mods/22]not to worry though, as there is an appropriate mod that restores it[/url]. Heat actions deal a lot less damage than it's supposed to. There's this one fight with budget Majima where he quicksteps 24/7, only stopping to attack you (real big pain tbh, I decided to give up the fight midway coz of that). Early game combat becomes a real bore real quick not gonna lie, thankfully once you unlock the 3 Komaki moves combat actually becomes decent enough to play through. There's also the underlying problem of the chase mechanic which is just as much of a sucker punch till you get the upgrades. Later titles at least made it a lot more enticing. Overall combat is pretty bad till you unlock the Komaki Parry, after that it becomes decent.

Minigames and Substories can be pretty unpolished at times. This was where Karaoke was first introduced and frankly the songs are pretty forgettable. Fishing is a lot harder compared to later titles. Some of the substories aren't exactly worth doing at times and a lot of them are tied behind the minigames. There isn't exactly a "Be My Baby" one in terms of how much it stands out from the rest. They might have been eye catching back in 2009 when the game was first released, but now they pretty much pale in comparison to the rest of the series' substories. Graphics will be a major problem if you played Kiwami 2 before this, but you'll get used to it as it isn't that bad. Soundtrack is one of it's stronger points in terms of the experience. Still has traces of that grungeness that was prominent in the first 2 games so if you're not into distortioned guitars it will be a con for you (I'm loving it tho). Bottom line, they haven't exactly aged well but the music slaps. 

That's pretty much my take on the game known as Blocku- I mean, Yakuza 3. Sluggish combat paired with a very rich character-building story with a dash of outdated substories and karaoke. Some continuity errors will persist if you played Y:LAD first, but the experience can be slightly enjoyable once you get the hang of it.

117603696.review:
Anyone that says that they enjoy this game is lying to you. The combat is so mindbogglingly terrible that I encourage you to play on easy. Bosses are on constant guard mode, so block 99 out of 100 attacks. To inflict damage you must use the reflexes of a fighter pilot to dodge attacks and land the one or two punches before their guard resets.

Imagine fighting a guy with a gun who blocks all your attacks and shoots without any telegraphing to dodge. This is to know suffering.

Just get gud and use the counters and blah blah blah. Nah. 99% of fights in this game are against street bums, and how you fight those is with full rush combos. Attempting to learn how to do effective counters against those means you die of old age as they look at you all day instead of throwing a punch since the AI's entire strategy is to block you and counter your blocked combo. The difficulty curve between fighting regular chumps and bosses is a vertical line, and that is the result of bad game design and you will never convince me otherwise.

Mini games are bad or outright broken because of the stick sensitivity.

The story is no great shakes either. Just sell the orphanage and open another one somewhere else, jeez.

Really good Yakuza game. 

Mostly criticized for its greatest virtue, the fights. If something can be upgraded in yakuza games (at least the ones I've played 0, 1 and 2) is the fighting system, really good but without any challenge, you can just smash the same combo non stop and kill everyone, stacking health items and weapons that you almost don't even need, etc. 

Yakuza 3 has not an extreme technical fight system, it's just that it makes you try to perform different actions, look for enemies back, try to break their guard, counterattack, etc. For me it's the one with the most entertaining fights, not a challenge by themselves because this is not a saga for that but at least you can't fight with just a mental macro (with the exception of some ultimate battles and some enemies like the Amon bros or some bosses).

So, replaying this...
I kinda remembered it to be better.
The usual goofy fun and over the top cutscenes are still here, you can still be a yakuza and the best karaoke singer in town.

BUT, the story is outright just dumb, 
there is moments I really appreciate, and I don't have a problem with most plot points introduced in this game...until those plot points make Kiryu just look like he's actually pretty stupid, what happens a lot in this game, happend before in the 2 earlier entries (especially the kiwami titles, which of 2 is still very good tho) , but this one has that a lot.
Like I get the Kiryu doesn't kill and all, but at this point, how didn't he learn how to disarm ppl when knocked out or incapacitate, it just makes no sense.
And it's a shame, because even if a bit clunky when it comes to controls (I'll get to that), the game has 2 really cool maps with a shit ton to do, mostly fun to explore when you don't get like a million fights trying to make 5 steps without being able to avoid them, and the substories are just as good as ever.

But then comes another problem, the fighting,
It's decent at first, and gets really frustrating over time.
Difficulty in yakuza has always meant bulletsponge, but that's fine idc, the fighting is fun! No it isn't, enemies constantly block, have invincibility frames, instantly turn around 180 on you, counter punch that you cannot avoid...bosses with guns while throwing huge crowds at you...I know I could have played on easy, and I played on hard by choice, but as I say a lot, hard in souls games is fun, hard in yakuza is bullshit.
I like to fight bare fist, weapons break fast, picking up weapons will often get you punched and stunlocked for a bit, building weapons is a thing, but I just don't want to play with weapons and they take inventory space, space that I want for my 15 Staminan Royale...because there will be a shit ton of pain in the ass chain battles....

In conclusion, I still like the game, because, it's  yakuza how can I not? It's all there, funny substories, amazing ambience for both maps, so many mini games, I didn't even play most of them...but then all the frustrating parts are also there, and to top it off, much worse then as you might know them after playing from yakuza 0 up to here...it's a fun game to play, if you bought it in the bundle or got it for cheap, but don't buy it for full price, I don't think it's worth it.

Hence why I don't recommend it.

116905069.review:
I heard a lot about Yakuza 3. Some people have said it was the worst in the series, some people said they liked it or had mixed feelings, and some people just couldn't get into the graphics. Having fought my way through three games prior, I finally got to play this little gem wanting to find out for myself. I honestly believe this series is very well structured and a blast to play, and I have nothing but great things to say about it so the only logical game to review, if any, would be this one.

Although it didn't have a lot going for it graphically I would go as far as to say Yakuza 3 had some of my favorite combat mechanics out of all four games thus far. It's a lot more methodical and the abilities you learn feel much more rewarding. It was less about smashing square and triangle and more about countering the enemy or finding unique ways to use your heat. It struck me as everything a game should be. Having consistently played Yakuza on hard mode, I expect the need to utilize every tool at my disposal. If I have to do that then it's a pass. Of course, the game got easier, but that's what being rewarded for putting in the time is all about. Every point spent and skill chosen creates more possibilities and better improves Kiryu from faster attack speed to much-needed heat moves, and those heat executions are wild. Most importantly, you [i]feel[/i] the strength as you gain skills and new methods become accessible. 3 begins very slowly, but the ramp feels smooth and fun.

I think the story is strong. It has shoddy parts but all of the themes that it presents definitely circle back around and the symbolism is on point. The kids are symbolic, and you get to know the family as Kiryu's struggle continues. Some of it is too on the nose though, like [spoiler]Joji. He's a copy. Why.. ?[/spoiler]but I did like the antagonist(s) and thought some of them were comical. The heavy themes in this one are pretty brilliant.

It's very weak in the mini-game department for me. That's about all I have to say about that. I found myself spending hardly any time on mini-games this go around.

It's a shame that this didn't get the Kiwami treatment because I think it could have been incredible if it did. Either way, Yakuza 3 brings something a little more old-fashioned to the table and fits comfortably in the series with its own unique and classic style.

I appreciated this and look forward to the next.
As always, thanks for the game.

116769996.review:
So many people call this the worst one of the series, and in my opinion if this game is the worst that the Yakuza series has to offer, then it's actually a good thing. So first off, let me just say that this game is definitely not as bad as a lot of people may lead you to believe. I do agree that it's the worst one, and I'll get into the flaws later. But no way in hell is this game a skip.

One thing is for sure, I really do wish this was Yakuza Kiwami 3. The main problem with this game is that it suffers from being the "revolutionary" game in the series. It was the first game making the jump to the PS3, and it did a whole lot of stuff for the first time ever. The minigames that are one of the most iconic parts of the series? Yep, started in this game. The problem is that you can tell that these are very early, unpolished minigames. Honestly I was pretty disappointed when I saw like 8 karaoke songs, and only 1 you sing yourself. I've heard all sorts of complaints about the mechanics in other games such as pool, I didn't try them myself but keep that in mind. Long story short, remaking this game and modernizing all of its side game mechanics would've helped a lot.

Now about the most controversial part of the game, the combat. It doesn't seem all that bad, up until you get to boss fights. At that point it's such a slog, you hit for no damage, the boss doesn't even hit that hard either. Yeah there will be a lot of blocking from the enemies. Regular/non boss fights are still the same fun as before, but maybe avoid the coliseum as they follow the same boss fight damage properties. The upgrade system is bang average, not bad but I think that it lacks the efficient/not totally unbearable exp grind that Kiwami had in Majima Everywhere. Honestly revelations are pretty cool and a funny way to get surprisingly useful moves. 

Onto the story. One of the issues I had with this game was how long the filler orphanage sections were. The first 4 (!) chapters are almost entirely spent doing mindless chores in Okinawa. Then, when the plot and conflict start to heat up, you get smacked in the face with another random filler section. Ignore those parts and I actually really enjoyed this story. The new characters introduced such as the Ryudo people are great. Yoshitaka Mine is probably my favorite villain of the series so far, his character is just really dope and I like the integrity and respect that makes him stand out from some of the other bad guys in this series. One thing though, without getting too spoilery, the last scene makes absolutely no sense. At all. It's like the writers wanted to have some shock value in the story but realized that the conflict is supposed to be over, so they took some shots and then wrote whatever came to mind. Serves no purpose to the story, just leave you incredibly confused as the credits roll.

Anyways, I'd still recommend this game to those of you playing along through the series like I am. It's alright to play it like how I did, speeding through and skipping almost everything besides the main story. Usually I like to go through at least maybe 50-70% of the substories but knowing that this is the worst game I didn't. For one last note, get tiger drop as fast as you can. This is the game where it's easiest to land, you can get it relatively quick, and overall just makes the boss fights a lot more bearable. Don't let other people convince you this game is unplayable, it's honestly really overhated.

The first thing I must say is, don't listen to people that tell you the game is just bad. The story by itself is perfectly fine, and I enjoyed it quite a bit, especially since 4 and 5 afterwards become more complex, so 3 by comparison is pretty easy to follow if you have already played other Yakuza titles. The beginning can be slow, IF you're not invested in Kiryu's orphanage, but I think it's important to his character.

The combat? Yes, it's the weakest of the series, but it's by no means bad. There ARE ways around its seemingly slow and stiff nature, even if they are pretty essential to not getting your ass kicked. Attack whiffing and wall bounding are your most essential tools, and if you're reading this, I urge you to learn these two techniques. Attack whiffing especially will help the game be less 'Blockuza 3', and make sure to get your Revelations and spec into the Tech tree to help you acquire moves that make the combat more fluid. Also MAKE SURE to use the Quickstep Restoration patch, otherwise your quickstep becomes nerfed (it has something to do with the framerate).

PS: Another patch is recommended that fixes a broken background sound in Ryukyu, unless you like really loud engine idling sounds.

115766973.review:
Very fun. Only played like 150-200 hours; the rest was me being AFK. This is the first game in the series that I won't be getting 100% completion in. This is strictly because pool functions terribly and the Coliseum requires you to fight hundreds of matches to get all the modding materials. I don't like this game that much to waste my life trying to do those things.

Overall, the story was good, but the gameplay was meh.  For some reason, Kiryu can't walk straight. I presume that's also the issue with pool-- the stick sensitivity is way too high and slightly off-center when going straight up or down. The fighting was very bare-bones. Do a combo, block their attack. Do a combo, block their attack. Grab them, throw them, then do a heat move. Every fight is like that in this game; it's as boring to do the millionth time as I'm sure it is to read me typing it out.

Haruka's Trust is another thing I didn't finish because it's honestly shocking how good at certain minigames you have to be. I've literally never seen someone get 3000 batting, 9 strikes in bowling, 1500 in Near-Pin, or any of the other SSS tier challenges. It's not tied to a trophy so why bother? Plus, the other aforementioned stuff that makes it so I can't Platinum it anyways.

Also, early PS3 models on current gen hardware/software is terrifying, but that's just me. It's very Uncanny Valley at times. They're like porcelain people.

And something weird happens to the game if you alt+tab out of it, or close it in any way without hard quitting the application. The menus start scrolling endlessly and the minigames with aiming mechanics don't function. By menus, I mean literally everything. The pause menu, dialog choices, emails, your inventory... It's really weird. The only fix is to save and exit, or to settle for being out of control in most menus. Don't open the controls display, either; I did that and the inability to control it got me stuck in that menu. 


EDIT: I also just realized I never got the 30 completed substories achievement?? I have the substory completion achievement so I don't know why I wouldn't have the prerequisite achievement...

I'd give it a 6/10. Not great, but don't skip it either. The story is fairly short compared to the earlier titles so just power through, if that's all you're in for.

What I love about the Yakuza series:

Great storyline
Open world map where there are tons of quests, and mini games to play.
Combat is challenging, but not over the top difficult. Requires some skill.
Japan Culture

What I really hated about Yakuza 3 and why I feel like its the weakest link in the series:

Lots of fluff in this one but I feel they really wanted to showcase Kiryu doing something else, almost like a normal life. I just found it boring and uninteresting.

Blockuza. The mobs in this game block so much that it made the combat which is usually painless, very painful on this one. The legend mode was easier once I got the golden pistol though, total cake walk. Minus those damn running scenes which I swear would be the end of me.

I would still recommend this game, because the Yakuza games are probably the best series of games I've ever played, but just beware that this one is the most annoying, but, Majima makes an appearance, so, that helps a little.

114737828.review:
[h1]Qué malo es envejecer y que te bloqueen[/h1]

Yakuza 3 Remastered (que no Kiwami) es el juego más viejo de la saga si excluimos a la primera y segunda parte por su versión Kiwami, lo que hará que el cambio sea bastante brusco en muchos sentidos, eso sumado a los famosos enemigos que bloquean hasta el infinito, hace que sea un juego no muy querido. Pero vamos por partes.

[h2]Gráficos[/h2]
La saga Yakuza nunca se había visto tan mal. Okey, no se ve tan tan mal, es bastante jugable y con sus momentos que se ve bien, pero se siente bastante esa bajada gráfica. Pasar de Kiwami 2, con su motor nuevecico a esto, uf... Cuesta un poco acostumbrarse a esto, sobre todo a ese modelado de Kiryu que parece sacado de Roblox.
Y probablemente lo peor gráficamente hablando, sean algunas acciones de calor. Se ven muy cutres, los golpes en esas escenas no transmiten sensación de fuerza.

[h2]Historia[/h2]
La historia de este Yakuza es bastante rara. Está dividida en dos partes, la primera, la parte de Okinawa que es ver el nuevo estilo de vida de Kiryu que dura hasta el cuarto capítulo. Y segunda parte, la vuelta a Kamurocho en el capítulo cinco, en el que la historia principal comienza (y el juego acaba en el capítulo doce).

Mi problema con esta historia, es que a duras penas es una historia hasta el capítulo ocho. Tiene bastante relleno, y va lenta porque se pone a dar vueltas en círculos porque no hay realmente mucho que contar. Y no me mal entendáis, a mí sí me ha gustado ver la nueva vida de Kiryu, pero creo que ese contenido podría haber sido secundario, y haberlo expandido más, quitando misiones secundarias por estas (porque el juego tiene muchas secundarias insípidas), y arreglando el hecho que una vez vuelves a Kamurocho, la magia de ser cuidador de niños en un orfanato se pierde.

Empieza con que el gobierno quiere expropiar a Kiryu de su orfanato para construir un centro militar y defender Japón [spoiler]cosa que no dura mucho, y se nos revela que era un plan para acabar con unos terroristas traficante de armas de EEUU.[/spoiler] mientas una guerra dentro del clan Tojo por usurpar el mandato empieza; cosa que fracasa rápidamente y sin que hubiera apenas tensión, porque Kiryu claramente se podía bajar a los tres señores intimidantes. Luego entra el misterioso hombre que se parece a Kazama (el juego intenta que creas que puede ser él, pero venga ya: Si es él es una mierda porque lo han revivido, y sino pues también, porque no cabía en la cabeza de nadie que siguiera vivo) [spoiler]es el jodido hermano de Kazama, y resulta que es de la CIA ni más ni menos. Parece sacado de un fanfic pero no[/spoiler].

Sin embargo, a partir del capítulo ocho o nueve, es cuando la historia se pone buena, con un par de giros de trama y sin que los malos sean tan malos, siendo más interesante que la de Kiwami 2 (aunque el cómo es bastante malo, porque es básicamente una cinemática de 30 minutos que te explican todo, así, sin vaselina).
El capítulo diez y unce son mayormente relleno, y el doce es pegarse y créditos. [spoiler]No entiendo la muerte de Mine. No entiendo qué aporta que muera en vez de quedarse como personaje de la saga, porque tenía bastante potencial, y ni entiendo eso de hacerle una llave a un tipo y tirarte al vacío en vez de que Kiryu vaya a pegarle otra vez o aparezca el jodido hermano de Kazama que ni vuelve a aparecer ni hace nada.[/spoiler]

La historia es efímeramente buena, y se nota mucho que este fue el primer juego donde los desarrolladores querían darle más importancia a la historia. De hecho, si miráis en How Long to Beat, veréis que es el Yakuza con la historia principal más corta, y a eso hay que sumarle el relleno dicho y que la historia principal tarda horas en aparecer.

Y la escena final es una mierda absoluta que encima no aporta nada porque se resuelve con la escena post-créditos.

[h2]Minijuegos[/h2]
Para mí de lo peor de esta entrega. Se nota eso que es el más viejo actualmente, porque quitando los dardos y el béisbol (que los he disfrutado más aquí que en las precuelas), son todos peores, o directamente una mierda (bolos y golf, cof cof).
Cada Yakuza suele tener dos minijuegos tochos, y este no es la excepción.
Podemos pescar, en un punto concreto en el orfanato, usando anzuelo, anzuelo cuya cada unidad ocupa un espacio y solo se pueden conseguir comprándolos en la ciudad, y que el pescar no sirve para absolutamente nada salvo para ganar un poco de dinero.
El otro es el cabaret que... simplemente está destrozado. Tienes que dar una vuelta por el negocio, leer qué quieren los cliente, meterte en el vestidor, ver una guía para saber qué accesorios suben qué atributos porque el juego no te lo dice y darte cuenta que la mitad está bloqueado por progresión así que vas a hacerlo de pena como te pidan un estilo que no puedes maximizar, entrenarla con un alto porcentaje que no haga nada el entrenamiento, sacarla a pasear y así en un ciclo sin fin. Me encantó el cabaret de Kiwami 2, y ver esto es hasta doloroso.

[h2]Jugabilidad[/h2]
La jugabilidad es básicamente la de Kiwami 2 en cuanto a los movimientos que puede realizar Kiryu pero con menos habilidades y menos habilidades interesantes. Lo que pasa es que el combate en esta entrega está roto.

En Yakuza 3, con cualquier combo puedes ejercer una presión bestial a cualquier enemigo, impidiendo que puedan actuar. Y como el estudio lo vio, decidieron hacer que los enemigos especiales (los importantes), bloqueasen como aunténticos cabrones para que no pudieras abusar de ellos. Es más, aún si quieres intentar encerrarles en un combo infinito no podrás, porque tienen ataques imparables que te mandan a la mierda si no les dejas. Y peor, aquí el calor se va con el tiempo, con cada golpe que recibas, y si estás en el suelo o te agarran, puedes ir despidiéndote de tu barra de calor, y encima los enemigos te pueden meter en un [i]stun lock[/i] que da bastante asco. Esto hace que los combates importantes sean muy zzz. Y si juegas así el juego se te va a hacer una bola inmensa, así que...

Resulta que en este Yakuza, Komaki aparece muy temprano, en el capítulo cinco, dándote las dos habilidades parry de Yakuza. Ah amigo, aquí es cuando el juego cambia y para bien. Ahora contra los enemigos especiales les podrás jugar a esquivar y pegar (no suele salir bien), o matarlos a parry, cosa que créeme, quieres hacer. Quitas mucha vida, es divertido, te da mucho calor, y gusta el ver cómo [i]cheesear[/i] esta mecánica en los enemigos.
El problemón aquí es que para que parezca Komaki hay que hacer un par de secundarias medio escondidas, y a muchos nos ha pasado el dejarlas y desbloquear estas habilidades muy tarde.

Por cierto, el inventario de este juego da mucho asco. Todos los objetos, salvo los que el juego considera clave, están en el mismo inventario pequeñito (curas, regalos, equipo, anzuelos, objetos para entregar).

[h2]Resumen[/h2]
Historia efímeramente buena, pareciendo más que una historia una ilustración de cómo es la vida de Kiryu ahora. Un combate más centrado en [i]cheesear[/i] enemigos con los parrys. Bastantes minijuegos malos. Y exceso de secundarias innecesarias. Disfrutable, pero en la cuerda floja del aprobado raspado.

114464833.review:
I really want to like this game, especially after so many hours of gameplay, but I just can't. People say it is the worst of the series, and they are right. Fanboys huff my balls.

Despite a somewhat decent storyline, pacing is really sloppy in certain areas (ie. being prompted by the game to go to the Okinawa airport, only to be pulled back to the orphanage twice for extremely mundane plot filler, and THEN FINALLY being able to go to Kamurocho)

Fights are a goddamn nightmare, even streetfights in late game when you have more skills. Heat action prompts only show up half the time despite fulfilling requirements, and even then, they do next to no damage. Parry doesn't work at all (R1 then B; I never got the prompt in the 100+ hours of playing) and blocking is useless because even street thugs immediately break through it and beat the shit out of you before you can even raise your arms again. Blocking doesn't even raise your heat like it does in other games, so what is the point in having the block if it never works? 
Weapon attacks are more useless than trying to use your fists to break through the enemy's guard (even weapons with high attack do next to no damage), so there's hardly any point in buying/modding weapons, or using them at all. 
Grabs only work a quarter of the time (even street thugs just push you off and stun you) and do hardly any damage when they do. So the only way you can do any damage AT ALL is to spam shitty heat actions until you can use Hell's Gauntlet (the only attack worthy of being called a 'finisher'). 
There's no way to be creative or actually have fun with this fighting engine, except with some of the earlier hitman missions. If you don't fill your inventory with Tauriner ++, you're fucked. 

FUCK THE CHASE ENGINE
Holy shit guys I never experienced a gamer moment until I had to fucking chase Mac S I X TIMES on N O R M A L. The opportunities to tackle are so few and far between and dashing is completely useless because they just speed up when you do, and slow back down when you don't dash. And, because of course it is, it is EVERYWHERE in this game. Yes, I know you can train chasing with Mac, but the only course that is actually doable is the first one, which extends the amount of time you can dash for. At least the chase engine gets cleaned up a bit in Yakuza 4 (check out my lengthy review for that one too).

Let's talk minigames:

Fuck pool and its entire life. This game clearly hates hot girls with iron deficiencies like me, where you have to keep the trigger COMPLETELY straight in order to make a proper shot. I can't believe how sensitive they made the curve for pool. I've poured hours into the pool minigame alone and can only beat the beginner pool challenger half the time because of the stupid curve. My ego is in the fucking ground because of how many fouls this baby can fit in it (I do not get nearly as many fouls in other Yakuza pools, excluding 4)

Baseball and its accompanying substory is easy enough, it's not nearly as much of a grind as Kiwami, but unfortunately there isn't a prompt to hit the ball at the right time like there is in Y5 and 6 (and probably others), so it is more of a headache for some. 

Fuck the bowling pin physics, guys. Why they so heavy and also not move like pins. It's so whack and I can't believe I got the turkey achievement. It only took me 2000 tries to bowl over a 200 and now I am procrastinating the substory that comes with that burden.

Darts is fine. 

I've never raged so hard at a claw machine teddy bear before

Don't @ me about any of the gambling mini games or shogi/mahjong. Who the fuck knows how to play Mahjong. 

The hostess club mini game is,,, Once you accrue enough items to actually be able to dress up the hostess, it's okay. Though, for how expensive some of the items are, your hostess really doesn't make enough money. I'm almost done training my 4th hostess and I barely have 400,000 saved... how the hell am I supposed to be able to buy things that actually boost stats if, after that much gameplay, I have that little and a flower ring is 32,000,000. How do you make money? Am I missing something?

At least street fights, though way too frequent, often give you decent money to ball a little bit (I was able to start hitting up hostess clubs and buy luxury healing items very early game)

Visiting hostess clubs is fine. It's easy enough without a guide for some of them, but a couple of the hostesses were so fucking insufferable and nonsensical that I didn't want to finish them (But I did) (It was Saya and Yui; especially Yui's substory holy shit what a self-entitled brat)

Apprehending all the hitmen is easy enough. It is certainly a grind, but these fights actually have different styles, and a good amount of them don't require just heat actions to be able to do. 

Anyways, I think the only redeemable part of this game is the substories. Some people may hate how many there are and want to focus on main story, but I like side quests, and a lot of them give you money, so sue me for being a bourgeoisie fuck.

Putting so many hours into completing this godforsaken game just shows my dedication to this series. Anyways, Majima game when?

113448169.review:
I bought and played this game because after playing through Yakuza 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2, I wanted to play the games chronologically before moving onto more recent titles. However, this game should probably be skipped. I'm a fan of older PS2 style games, so graphically this game doesn't bother me, but the story and mechanics are so weak.

Let's talk about the story. Spoiler free, the story is by far the weakest in the series so far (not counting 4, 5, and 6, haven't played those yet). It really does feel like the whole game is just grabbing at straws to make things make sense, making some very obvious and cliche "twists", needlessly killing characters just to make the game more "dramatic", and having character motives seriously out of left field. Kiryu's motives make sense throughout the game in SOME aspect, but in others it really just feels like he's obligated to proceed with the Tojo Clan shenanigans just because. Maybe it's just culture differences here, but it feels like he should be way more obligated to taking care of Haruka and the kids than solving mysteries for the Tojo Clan, which he left long ago. If SEGA decides to remake this game like with 1 and 2 (Kiwami and Kiwami 2), then I really hope they change some of the story to actually make sense as to why Kiryu would be involved. While I haven't fully beaten the game yet (halfway through currently), I don't have high hopes for this getting better.

Mechanics time. The battle isn't in any way difficult, but it is Boring. The characters are constantly blocking, so defeating them takes a very long time. Typically in other games, you could just grab blocks and throw the enemies to do damage, but in this game if you grab, the enemies will just break the grab about 90% of the time. So when an enemy blocks, the best thing you can do is punch until they aren't. This naturally takes a long time. Heat actions are difficult to use and there aren't a lot. From what I could find in the menus, there isn't a list telling you which actions do what and what triggers them. So unless you're memorizing all these moves like an elephant or writing them down as soon as you learn them, you're probably not going to be using heat actions a lot. This is a huge disappointment, since a highlight of the games is seeing Kiryu slam a dude's head into a toilet or break someone's arm and stealing their gun right before shooting them. The action in this game is very weak because of the mechanics. 

Side stories. I personally loved doing the side stories in other Yakuza games, but this one has little to no benefit. They're not very exciting, funny, or rewarding. Before, you would get EXP, unique items, or at the very least a good laugh from doing side stories. While you DO get EXP for doing side stories in this game, it's so insignificant that you'll be lucky to level up once from doing a side quest. Since most upgrades require 50 or more levels halfway through the game, this is an insanely small amount. I wouldn't really complain if you at least gained 3-4 levels from doing the side quests. Then you could at least upgrade an ability once after doing a few battles and side quests. Just progressing through main story and putting all your points into Body is your best bet for beating the game quickly, which you'll want to do if you decide to buy this. 

Mini games. They're godawful this time around. The cabaret club management game, which had grown on me previously, is straight up frustrating in Yakuza 3. It requires a lot of money, nets you almost no money, and takes a lot of time to play. There's no benefit to doing it, unlike in other games where you could use your earnings from the mini games on EXP upgrades or other benefits.

Pros:
- Haruka and the kids are cute. The side stories with the kids was very heartwarming. 
- There are SOME very entertaining and silly moments with the blog moments.
- Rikiya is so goofy, I love him. 
- Kiryu is grade A dad material.

Cons: 
- Characters who follow you will SCREAM at you when you walk too fast. You almost always have characters following you. 
- Practically every other thing.

As a dedicated Yakuza fan, take it from me when I say this one can be skipped. If you really want to know the story, just watch a play-through on Youtube.

113056446.review:
Yakuza 3 is not a bad game.

The areas of issue with this game can probably be found in most reviews: the combat is weird and too rigid, the graphics are bad, some of the story decisions were weird. I get it, and I can agree with some of this to a fault, but Yakuza 3 is not a bad game.

I loved this game dearly. It is such a breath of fresh air in the series and where they take that story with Yakuza 3 is interesting. For fans of the first three games, 0, Kiwami 1 and 2, some things will be a payoff, while others will feel a little weird. There were parts where I laughed, cried, smiled, was angry... this game made me feel every emotion. The story is so emotional, and gripping at that. When the twists hit, they HIT.

The direction Kiryu was taken in this installment is perfect. I love what they did with his character. Not to mention, the supporting cast is amazing as always. You get tons of new, lovable, unforgettable characters, and of course, you get your Majima's, Date's, and Haruka's back. The soundtrack was certainly fun, but I admittedly was getting tired of the random street fight music, as well as how often those would happen.

The substories are strong in this one, especially with some of them having their own animated cutscenes. Some can last a few minutes while others last as long or close to the length of some chapters in this game. 

Yes, the graphics are not up to par, especially if you played Kiwami 2 right before this. Yes, person who has played this game all the way through as well, I felt your pain at the beginning. It does not take long to get used to this change though, as graphics shouldn't be a reason you hate a video game. Yes, if you played the other games before playing this one, the combat will feel bad. And it is... in comparison. Enemies block A LOT more in this one, and that is no exaggeration. 90% of their moves are blocks. This was something I felt throughout the entire game, and I guess would truly be my only gripe.

With all of this said, if you are a fan of the series and have been wondering how this game is, or if you're coming off the heels of Kiwami 2, do not let the bad reviews fool you. If you love Yakuza, you will love this game. I highly encourage you to play it! Have your own fun with it, and enjoy it in its purest form.

112462971.review:
Easily a recommended game, specially if you’re a fan of the Yakuza series. 
However, we have been spoiled with Yakuza 0 and the Kiwami versions, this game was so hard to get into after the first experience I had with the series was Yakuza 0, hard in this case being less than 30 minutes. Graphically it didn’t hold a candle to the recent ones and there were many poor QoL design choices which reflects some of the not-so-great design of older days. 
The enemies specially boss fights were too cheap with constant guarding, no reliable way to break it and if you do they take minimal damage making the fights tedious and a lot of times boring. The story was ok but the characters and dialogs were incredible as always. Soundtracks were okay as well, nothing as catchy as Yakuza 0. 
The worst parts were the fact you cant save anywhere like Kiwami and must find phonebooths, as well as, not being able to sprint and the running speed being fixed.

TLDR;

Pros:
- Great Writing.
- Fun gameplay minus some boss fights
- Insane amount of minigames
- An "Exit to windows" option the older games lacked

Cons:
- Not as visually appealing as Kiwami
- Tedious game designs like walking back and forth or clicking something and waiting seconds before it opens etc.
- Poor boss fights.

111107126.review: I do not understand the hate for Yakuza 3. This game has a lot of charm, great story and amazing characters, what more could you want. Let's get the elephant out of the room real quick, the combat in this game is not bad. The combat might be outdated but the only real time it got frustrating was fighting the Snake Flower Triad and Lau Ka Long, I like to see it as the combat forcing you to approach the game with a different strategy and not just mindlessly spamming combos and tiger drops, when you're fighting a boss one-on-one the combat is a lot of fun. Since this game is technically "outdated" it makes the game pretty goofy at times, I think the goofiness just adds to the charm of this game so I do not see it as a bad thing. The only real time the goofiness is a detriment in my opinion is the "beautiful eyes" moment, this is supposed to be a super emotional moment for Kiryu, the man that raised him, or at least that's who Joji appears to be, and died in his arms makes eye contact with him again and. This moment is supposed to be really emotional but it's instead made fun of all the time. Now I think the story is just a way better version of the 1 story. The game revolves around trying to fish out some organization that ties back to the Tojo in some way, the difference here being that the organization actually has something to do with the Tojo and the main plot unlike Jingu and the MIA thanks to the whole military expansion bill forcing Kiryu to give up the land to his orphanage putting some pressure on us. Now while the story is good the game would not be nearly as good without the amazing supporting cast, the characters are truly what add to this game and give it more of the Y3 charm that I love. Finally, Mine is a fantastic antagonist. Like Ryuji, his entire motivation and backstory is revealed almost at the end but it's done in such a way that puts him as yet another of the fantastic antagonists that RGG is so good at writing. RGG takes the boring "I'm doing this because I want power and money" and applies it to Mine in such a way that makes his character more tragic. Without Daigo, the one man he respected and gave him meaning, his life goes back to being empty and being just about him getting as much power, as much as he doesn't need it. Y3 is easily one of the best Yakuza games and whoever skipped it deserves to go in the electric chari.

111003870.review:
[h1]Overall = 7/10[/h1]

4 games in, I thought the formula would be getting stale by now, but after the first dungeon sequence, everything was back on form.  It’s a great story with the same drama and memorable cast of characters, but with a slower, much more relaxed pace.  It does drag on a bit as you unlock more and more content but never seem to complete anything, and it is a real slog to truly finish the game, especially as some of the mini-games don’t work as intended.   The new settings and variations on the mini-games offer some variety, but the locations, atmosphere and game play doesn’t look or feel as good as in the Kiwami games – you can see how much polish they’ve added to the formula over the years.  A lot of the content also seems to be saved for the premium adventure and there’s a lot of grind and repetition to fully complete the game. 

It’s really enjoyable and the remastered graphics look good, but the menus are dated and the cities don’t feel as alive as in the other games.  The combat is a lot stiffer and more drawn out due to all the blocking, but not that bad once you get the hang of it.  Weapons don’t seem useful, unlocking all the moves again takes ages and levelling up is slow, but it’s still the fun and meaty combat you’ve come to expect.  A great addition to the series with enough variations to keep it interesting, and plenty of the charm, humour and glamour you’ve come to expect.

A great entry into the Yakuza series, continuing Kiryu's storyline and introducing new characters. 

The story was a lot of fun and very interesting, especially exploring the new locales.

This remaster is very pretty given the age of the original game and holds up well with the current series, the framerate and gameplay runs smoothly.

The only downside i experienced was the combat, the AI is programmed to block infinitely. This paired with the fact that they have no break limit results in all fights (Including no name npcs) taking a very long time where you do little to no damage and they block non stop. The only way to get around this is to learn a couple of special moves and spam them, which is very boring, or alternatively spam guns.

If the combat was updated or the ai programmed to not infinitely block, i think it would have helped the game out alot.

To date i've played: 0, Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2. Yakuza 3 is the worst out of the lot solely because of the combat and i couldn't wait to rush to the finish line.

I'd recommend to pick it up to continue Kiryu's story, but be prepared for the awful combat.

109534759.review:
Compared to the previous Yakuzas, 3 has a hard change of pace. Aside from the fact they didn't remake it like 0,1, and 2, it also takes place in Okinawa which is away from the big bustling city and more chill. In the beginning of the game is feels really slice of life and it's pretty chill. Some people might find it boring but i thought it was pretty fun and interesting. Later in the game it returns to its roots and you visit Kamurocho from the previous games. 

The story is okay, but of course it has the same tropes as the previous ones. It's a good story with plot twists and the such. (Spoiler Warning; Not too specific though) [spoiler] After Kiryu lost many many loved ones in previous games and he once agains loses people in this game, it's no surprise. But for the characters that die in this game it doesn't really feel Kiryu built a good bond with them and you don't really feel too sad about it because of that. [/spoiler] If you've played the previous games then you're pretty much expecting it.  If you haven't then I guess you're in for some plot twists. In a way it seems unnecessarily convoluted. I mean Idk maybe I'm just getting tired of the same Yakuza plot used for every game but it's just my opinion. 

Aside from the main story there are a vast amount of different side missions to do. Some of them are much more interesting than others. There's actually a murder mystery side mission that I genuinely found more interesting than the main story, Some of the side missions aren't marked and it's kinda confusing on what you need to do. They let you get stronger and add more spice to the game so for the most part they're pretty good. There's also a lot of minigames like karaoke, golf, fishing, bowling, and a few others.

The combat is pretty much the same as the previous games. This game does add chase and escape scenes where you have to run and vault obstacles to evade or catch someone which was really interesting. The beatem up fighting was a bit painful though. I felt like some bosses were just block monsters and too repetitive. Sometimes I would easily dodge out of their attack and as they were hitting they would 180 turn and somehow connect with my character. Upgrade points are pretty hard to get late game and I have no idea how you'd be even able to get max upgrades without hella grinding it out.

Around Kamurocho there's random people on the street who will try to fight you just like the previous games. In this one it feels like they're on every other corner and it gets annoying real fast. In Okinawa it's not so bad. They give very little exp so grinding with them is super tedious. 

Overall a good game. If you enjoyed the previous games then you'll most likely enjoy this one. If you haven't I highly recommend playing them because why would you start at 3. Worth full price.

109500319.review:
[h1] While a divisive entry to some, Yakuza 3 remains a highlight of the franchise for me, and it feels good to see this much love given to its restoration. TL;DR at the bottom. [/h1]

I’ve just finished Yakuza 3 after playing through its remakes/prequels, and up to this point, this definitely seems to be weakest entry in the series so far. Sure, comparing Yakuza 3 to latter entries is a bit unfair, but that is the context that I have, so be it. Kiwami 1 and 2 is a Remake of Yakuza 1 and 2 plus Yakuza 0 came also after. If you're a newcomer to the yakuza franchise - don't start here - play Yakuza 0, Kiwami 1 and 2 first:

https://store.steampowered.com/app/638970/Yakuza_0/

Someone else once stated that Yakuza 3 is more like a "gaiden" (side-story) version of the Kiryu saga, and I have to agree. Everything is a bit slower-paced compared to the prequels; from a slower-pace Okinawa beach and smaller-city setting taking a large chunk of the gameplay. It's fine for what it is, but does feel a bit off compared to the other sagas.

Presentation is appropriate for an early PS3-era game, so if you keep your expectations in it's fine, but it didn't quite teleport me back to kabuki-cho/dotonbori like its prequels but thats completely fine because its just a REMASTER of the Original and not a REMAKE with new Engine. If you expect Yakuza 0, Kiwami 1-2 type of quality then its obviously your fault.

The fight gameplay is fairly average - it just doesn’t have the bone-crunching effect of the earlier entries mentioned, and the moves and the play seems a bit… plain and kind of "boring" since it doesn't have the variety-palette of yakuza 0. Mostly button-mashing with a few dodges thrown in here and there for the tougher fights, but nothing that will make you sweat for an extended period of time.

The main story is absolutely decent and better than what I expected from the Reviews here. Your typical crime-drama storyline here with some melodramatic plot points (with you running an orphanage and all). I can’t say the storyline was exceptional like that of part 0, but there’s nothing wrong here. I absolutely enjoyed every second of it!

The side-story missions are okay, but I feel the formula is starting to wear thin. I found myself just wanting to move on with the main story as I didn't find the side plots particularly compelling nor all the mini games interesting.

All in all, Yakuza 3 is up to par or above average in most aspects. Some will complain about the lengthy cut-scenes, but I think this is a bit overblown. The game always gives you an opportunity to save before showing you a long cut-scene, plus the scenes themselves are skip-able, and you can also re-watch them from the menu. So there's a good deal of flexibility there. Even without the removed content, Yakuza 3 has upwards of 50 hours of content to enjoy. If you're only interested in finishing the story, this takes about 20 hours.

Some Reviewers also mention to just skip this: DON'T! This Game is absolutely worth it and no one should skip this. People who say "SKIP!" are definitely trash at video games becuase there is nothing wrong here!

★★★★★ Story
★★★★☆ Visuals/Graphics

★★★★☆ Level Design (Environment and Space)

*RECOMMENDED*

109446772.review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]The 1st game of the Remastered Trilogy, Yakuza 3 takes a more slice-of-life approach to Kiryu's story; setting takes place shortly after the events of Kiwami 2
    [*]Alongside Kamurocho, explore Okinawa; new map since 3 games in
    [*]An overwhelming amount of substories both hidden & marked around the world, what makes Y3's substories so enjoyable is that most of them have multiple endings & even dialogue differences depending on when you start them
    [*]Heat actions have more interactive prompts which make for extended combos, additionally, there are a veritable amount of new heat action animations mainly involving weapons
    [*]Ultimate Match (formerly "Climax Battles") returns, honestly, with the serious downgrade in systems these challenges are some of hardest you will encounter so far in the series; which makes overcoming them a true test of patience, skill, & understanding of the AI
    [*][b]Rikiya {Best Man}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Completion List does not carry over in any capacity in NG+, it will in premium adventure mode; however, players looking to complete their list during subsequent story NG+ will have to re-do everything
    [*]Combat is fundamentally flawed, when enemies block they are hyper-immune to most forms of damage; have higher chance of blocking in harder difficulties; makes for heat generation & combat to feel disconnected
    [*]The modding system although interesting is completely ineffective & inefficient due to inventory capacity limitations, lack of fast travel points, inventory management sorting options, & scarcity of certain resources
    [*]Item box has an invisible hard cap, despite having a system that encourages the looting of modding materials to create enhanced weapons/gear
    [*]Minigames have the most horrendous physics so far, games such as pool, darts, & the true endgame = UFO Catcher are quite frustrating to understand
    [*]Lack of fast travel points & no sprint button (despite it existing during chases) which forces for slow mobility across the world
    [*]Kiryu is getting too old for this, he can no longer eat or drink an entire restaurant menu in one visit; the most effective method for clearing out the food completion list is to consume fish bait to lose health then eat at a restaurant & repeat (Do not try at home)
    [*]Haruka's Requests are back for revenge, toughest requests so far, mainly for the subsequent reason that the minigame physics are flawed; her EX requests are the hardest in the series
    [*]The guy in Mahjong that calls "Riichi" on the first discard and "Ron" on the second discard (Part 4, but its actually not as bad as Pool or UFO Catcher)
[/list]

109416109.review:
[h1]🤢😞🙁😐🙂>😊<😍[/h1]
🗾Yakuza 3 is the only entry in the series so far which definitely doesn't deserve the 😍 rating. It wouldn't be fair to call this game [i]mediocre[/i] or [i]disappointing[/i] or what have you – it still delivers a unique Yakuza experience and it's really good in its own way, but it falls short in just [b]two[/b] crucial areas which are way too important to be overlooked. Since I'd like to end this review on a positive note, let's get all the bad stuff out of the way first – we don't really have a lot to talk about here, just the [u]minigame design[/u] and [u]issues with pacing[/u].

You can also read what I had to say about [b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nuitcalme/recommended/638970/]Yakuza 0[/url][/b], [b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nuitcalme/recommended/834530/]Kiwami[/url][/b], and [b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nuitcalme/recommended/927380/]Kiwami 2[/url][/b] here.

[h2]Minigames are a complete and utter mess[/h2]
🀄Since you've played at least 2 Yakuza games before this one, you know very well how important minigames are in this fictional universe. They offer a welcome distraction from a hectic pace of an intricate criminal drama, a much-needed comic relief among a three-ring circus of neverending schemes, murders and betrayals. Unfortunately, in this iteration of the franchise, they sucked most minigames completely dry of all the fun that made them so great and memorable.

🀄Bowling has messed up pin physics; they feel like they're made of paper and constantly clip through each other and never fall when they're supposed to. Darts is still broken, much like in 0 and Kiwami, but also has absolutely insane completion requirements. Karaoke, my favourite minigame of all time, has such substandard interface and unsatisfying mechanics that I didn't enjoy it at all; Kiryu also sings literally 1 short song and that's it. Balls in pool feel weird and change trajectory seemingly at random. Batting seems ridiculously unfair with extremely short reaction times required from the player. UFO Catcher is the worst one yet. And they even ruined the most sacred minigame of all – Hostess Maker. It went from one of the most engaging side activities to a dreadful snoozefest. I mean, should I even continue? You get the gist.

🀄One could argue that of course Yakuza 3 is gonna have worse physics – it's a much older game than Kiwami 2, so what am I talking about? True, but many issues that I've listed above have nothing to do with when the game came out. It's just bad design choices. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2740345076
🀄You can still have fun with fishing, gambling, and maybe even mahjong if you're a masochist like me, but the overall impression is tarnished nonetheless. So, minigames suck, okay, but the main plot has to be good then, right?

Right, but sadly,
[h2]there are serious pacing and storytelling issues[/h2] 
🎭What if I told you that at the very beginning of the game, when things just start to get interesting and you're ready to be immersed in a typical yakuza storyline, the game's pacing is brought to a screeching halt, and for several hours you're forced to deal with boring kid problems – this boy gets bullied at school, this one is allergic to buckwheat, someone had their pocket money stolen, yadda yadda yadda. So, when in previous games you've already done 10 years in prison, foiled several assassination attempts and are now in the middle of a clan war, here you've taught some kids how to say sorry and be brave. I mean, it's not bad per se and I welcome this change as it shows us how Kiryu is developing as a person, but good Lord above, this thing is sooo... looong... and tedious... [u]especially[/u] when you need to complete the game several times to unlock the Legend difficulty. 

🎭Moreover, imagine that you have a 30-minute cutscene in your game (I'm not even kidding) with some guy telling you about all important plot details, who is who and what everyone's motivation is. This is so unbelievably lazy; it's creative writing at its worst. Don't just [u]tell[/u] me what kind of person everyone is and what they want – [u]show[/u] me! You might not actually [i]show[/i] as much as you can [i]tell[/i], but there's no need to lay all cards on the table – stop chewing my food for me, I can arrive at my own conclusions and I don't need anyone sitting me down and going, [i]"Okay, listen up, this is how it is... He killed him because... They are an organisation called... blah blah blah..."[/i] I love Yakuza cutscenes and I think many of them are brilliant, but this 30-minute slog had me yawning and begging for the torture to end.  

[h2]Finally, let's talk about the good stuff![/h2]
⭐To be honest, if you start playing right after completing Kiwami 2, you'll have a hard time getting used to how old this game looks and feels. Gone are the glorious ragdoll physics and [i]whatever[/i]K textures; despite that, Yakuza 3 can still be gorgeous in its own ways – there was neither a sandy beach in previous games nor a breathtaking view of the night sky full of bright stars – and it still has a solid gameplay foundation that will keep you from getting bored. Unless you're stuck in the middle of a neverending cutscene, that is...

⭐There are a whopping [b]119[/b] (!) substories – almost twice as many as in other games, and they are really – [i]really![/i] – riveting and imaginative. At some point you even solve a murder case, Agatha Christie style. Just be careful not to start too many substories at the same time – this may prevent other side activities from working properly, and you'll be stuck in what I call a Vicious Substory Loop of Death. While researching how to get out of this, I accidentally saw some pretty heavy spoilers. So, just finish any substory that you start and then move to another one if you wanna be safe.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2737134758
⭐The music is as great as ever – that's definitely something this franchise will seemingly never stop delivering on. Isn't it just [b][url=https://youtu.be/CiwMh6DOEjs]one of the most charming melodies[/url][/b] you've ever heard? Simple, yet elegant and melancholic. It gave the Agatha Christie substory that special push to make it even more emotional.

⭐Have I mentioned that there's finally a new city to get lost in? Since we already know both Kamurocho and Sotenbori inside and out, having a new place to explore was a much-needed breath of fresh Okinawan air. It's kinda small though, maybe half the size of Kamurocho, but I don't think it matters that much. You'll be learning a lot about people living in Okinawa, their language, customs and outlook on life in general. 

⭐There are many other things I could cover here, like Revelations, chases, levelling and combat systems, Ultimate Matches, et cetera; however, I don't want you to know absolutely everything before you start. It's always good to go in somewhat blind and let yourself be shocked (in a good way) – Yakuza is the perfect franchise to have your jaw dropped or your thighs slapped in an uncontrollable fit of laughter. Have fun!

P.S. A completionist would naturally find that it's too late to stop now, having already perfected three games before this one, but I feel obliged to say it anyway – Yakuza 3 will be absolutely [i]brutal[/i] to anyone who strives to achieve 100% completion. It's head and shoulders above all other entries in the series simply because of all the broken minigames. However, take heart – if I did it, you can, too! 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2736559390

109403637.review:
Yakuza 3 is one of the most--if not the very most--controversial games in the Yakuza series. But for what it is, it's enjoyable.
The story is good, Kiryu receives excellent new characterization, the new characters are great, the overall plot is somewhat familiar but has enough intrigue to keep itself interesting throughout. There are few moments that could've been executed better, but overall it's a good experience.
The gameplay is mediocre, especially compared to gameplay titans such as Yakuza 0. Enemies block and reguard to much, but this causes an emphasis on grabbing in non-boss encounters which is actually fascinating. I learned some unorthodox but interesting physics-based damage options with grab-throw-far heavy kick-far heavy kick into a wall for extra damage. Blocking is mostly a problem on heavy enemies who you can't grab, but you can generally get behind them (or use weapons) to make your life easier. The actual main problem is that heat generation is way too slow, but you can get a lot of heat by throwing enemies into groups of other enemies during large encounters--still, this is unreliable and you want to pack heat-giving items, especially for boss encounters.
Speaking of, boss encounters are mostly fine once you get a hang of the quickstep, but you should always pack weapons to make your life easier. For enjoyment purposes, combo speed and double-finishing blow upgrades are *essential*, yet for some reason are missable on the upgrade menu due to having alternate options for their slot? The ability to miss these upgrades might be my chief complaint with this game, as they should be mandatory upgrades due to how much easier it makes your life.
6.5/10, worth playing for the story, the gameplay isn't winning any awards but it is serviceable for the most part despite some hang-ups. I really liked this game, but it's flawed.

If you've been playing the Yakuza series this far, and have fallen for all the characters like I have, buy the game (on sale maybe) play on easy mode and muster enough focus from ur ADHD brain and get through the slow-ish start of the game.
