108840983.review:
TL;DR - Good game, bad timing. You having to play it after Kiwami 2 which is on the newest engine for Yakuza games makes it feel and look bad. It will take the first few hours to get used to this look and feel of this game, but I feel like it still can be good.
Don't get me wrong, I really love this game, but it has to be the weakest in the franchise for me.

* This review does NOT contain any spoilers for the story

In terms of story, I actually really loved it. There were very many moments when I cried, when I cheered and I felt really invested in the story. So for the story alone, this game is worth playing.

The combat is nothing to really write home about. It's just Yakuza, doesn't feel like it has any new things, though it is to be expected, as this is a Remaster, not a Rework, like Kiwami and Kiwami 2. It needs a little bit of time until you get used to it, but the game is still good.

Of course, you can't have a Yakuza game without side content, but, to be honest, whilst there is a lot to do in this game, because it's technically the oldest in the franchise now, its mechanics feel aged. I feel like this game would be appreciated more by someone who played the original game. Coming from the spoiled goodness that was 0, Kiwami and Kiwami 2, this feels like a major downgrade, because it is.

Yes, I am sure you have heard of the insane amount of blocking the AI does in this game. Yes, it is frustrating. This is why I recommend you play on an easier difficulty than you would normally: if you want to go with Hard, no you don't, just go with Normal. For your own mental health and future anger issues developments.

Also the movement is clunky. I'm not sure if they reworked it or not, but it does feel old-style.

If you love Yakuza, I recommend playing this. but it will take some time to recalibrate from how spoiled you have been playing the first 3 games. If you find it a pain, you could just watch all the cinematics or something on Youtube and skip to Yakuza 4 which is better in every way yet still has an old-school feel, but don't worry, it's the good kind.

108647278.review:
After 0 and Kiwami 1 + 2, was expecting a huge drop in quality given that this game is now the most dated in the main series + this entry is often regarded as worst in the series.   I found it to be surprisingly excellent. 

Story:  The main story does have kind of a slow burn early on, but it adds to the plot in a deliberate and meaningful way that allows the story to build on itself and have events carry more weight.  If you enjoyed the other Yakuza game stories, there is a high chance you will appreciate this one.  It fits in well as continuation from Kiwami 2.  If its your first Yakuza game, it works well as a self contained story, and it provides recaps on the main points of past events.  

Graphics:  At 4k max settings 60 fps this game actually looks amazing for a 2009 Ps3 title.  It is close to par w/ yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1.   Also, there is the added visual variety from having a new major location (Okinawa) in additional to Kamarocho .  

Sound:  Top tier soundtrack that compliments the experience well.  

Gameplay:  The overall game structure is actually really similar to Yakuza 0 to Kiwami 2.   If you liked the gameplay in those, there's a high chance you'll appreciate it here.  Enemies do seem to block more than in other entries; however, this entry allows you to acquire extremely powerful moves pretty easily and early on (like the Komaki Parry + Tiger Drop + most of the tech abilities).  The combat might be also a little stiff compared to other entries, but it did not feel like a jarring change at all.  It actually felt like it made sense, because at this point in the story, Kiryu is almost 40 years old.  

Last, mods improve the experience even more.  Here is the list of mods i used:
-Silent Patch
-Yakuza 3 Licensed Music Video and Uncensor Restoration Patch
-High resolution character textures (for nearly all characters) mod
-Quickstep Restoration
-Removal of the loud ambient audio in Downtown Ryukyu to better match the PS3 and PS4 versions.
